												Way to ♥♥♥♥ up your sequel Crytek. Honestly, I blame EA more for it but still. The original Crysis had complex sandbox missions with multiple approaches and secondary objectives and plenty of bad♥♥♥♥♥suit powers. Crysis had an enjoyable cast of characters that I actually cared about. Crysis had varied vehicles, all of which were drive/flyable, Crysis had BLUE aliens that froze things. Crysis had a unique blend of strategic, tactical, intense, fun combat. Crysis had an original and interesting multiplayer.This is not Crysis. This is Call of Halofield 7: Future Warfare. They traded in EVERY SINGLE THING that made the first game great. Whether it's the linear as all hell story missions, the characters that were one-dimensional, cliche and predictable to the end, the dumbed-down nanosuit that somehow manages to feel less powerful than the marines you fight with, the HORRENDOUS checkpoint system, the aliens that are the exact opposite of the first game's, the lack of Psycho's presence, the removal of the ability to carry two primary weapons AND pistols AND use your fists (in fact, fists are completely gone), you can only use humvees/APCs instead of, oh, I don't know, TANKS and VTOLS and HELICOPTERS and other awesome♥♥♥♥♥♥ the bland/generic EVERYTHING, the multiplayer that is a complete rip-off of Call of Duty (and is now full of hackers that nobody does anything about), the list goes on.Anyways, the point is DON'T BUY THIS GAME. It is an insult to the original and in fact an insult to games in general.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												The main strength of the campaigns of Crysis is their sandbox, unrestricted nature, and Crysis 2 is a step back from Crysis 1 and Warhead in this regard, as you run through cities with closed-in walls instead of trek through jungles. However, each specific battle (and there were many times I felt like I was facing "boss" enemies) takes place in a pretty large area, so I never felt particularly restricted.The guns and combat are as crisp and satisfying as they were in the first two Crysis games. The suit's powers are now accessed with keyboard shortcuts, which makes their use feel more isolated, like sprinting in other games, and power jumps are accessed with a single button (holding down space), instead of requiring an activation of strength mode, making me feel less like I was operating a special suit, and more like I was just a superhero - it's less mechanical-feeling, for better or for worse, I guess.Towards the end of the campaign, I became extremely dependent on cloaking, which is overpowered. It's much faster to sneak around the enemy strongholds, going straight for the objectives, than it is to run roughshod over every enemy one-by-one. Maybe I became so objective-oriented because I was enthralled with the campaign (wishing to finish it as soon as possible), because, in other games, I generally take the time to kill every enemy I see.My most significant complaint about Crysis 2 is that, with the closed-in areas, specific, restricted routes are required to arrive at objectives within each mission, but there is no guide system (line on the ground) to show you where to go, which would have been appreciated at several points in the campaign, as I found myself trapped in rooms, going in circles trying to open doors that wouldn't budge. If you get stuck and resort to searching online for a level guide, you'll find many other people commenting that they were stuck at the same point as you.Dying can set you back annoyingly far. Don't die.The suit's upgradability is neat, but generally not integral, and unlikely to scope an individual's tactics.There aren't a lot of people playing Crysis 2's multiplayer, although there are more than enough to have a few big games going at all times. Still, this is a game to be bought for its campaign, and I highly doubt you will be left disappointed after completing it. It's exciting, engaging, and challenging, and ranks among my favorite 10-11 hour spans of gaming.

												Crysis 2, like the original is a first person shooter. The game was released in early 2011. It also follows on from the plot of Crysis 1 as well. Although you don't really need to have played the original in order to follow the story. Crysis 2 was also the first game to use the CryEngine 3.The game play has all of the regular FPS style features. You play the role of a Recon Marine, called Alcatraz. You are able to customize your weapons to match the situations you are in, as well as customizing your suite to the same too. Crysis 2 is set in New York City, which is often referred to by many as an urban jungle. This does however offer various different tactical options when it comes to planning attacks; allowing players to navigate between floors and buildings, and ruined buildings.  We also see a few changes in the Nanosuit used by our character too; this time you are able to use more than one suit power at a time, the strength and power modes have been combined into the same mode, and the stealth suit has been improved slightly.Crysis 2 has AMAZING graphics; this could easily pass as a game being released recently. If you put all of your settings up to full, you are going to be in amazement at how good this game looks. You will need a beefy rig to keep a steady 60 fps, but my oh my it is worth it.I sadly see no replay-ability in Crysis 2, there are the addition of a couple of difficulty modes, but to be honest; once you have played it the once, there is no reason to play it again. The single-player campaign is a decent length though - we are looking at a 18 hour long story mode which is very good for an FPS.Thankfully I had no technical issues with Crysis 2 (unlike I did have with the original), I was able to play with every graphical setting on ultra and still had 60 frames the whole time. The only thing I will mention is there is no longer any multiplayer support since GameSpy shut it's servers down in May 2014.If you enjoyed the first Crysis game, you will basically enjoy Crysis 2, it's the same just with even better graphics, more compelling story, and stellar FPS action and did I mention the amazing graphics? People may think £20 is a bit steep for a game of this age, however I am completely happy with this price as it almost fits into the £1/hour ratio. 1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Crysis 2 is a first-person shooter developed by Crytek using the Cry Engine 3.  It serves as a sequel to the critically acclaimed 2007 game Crysis and is the first game on the franchise to be released on the consoles as opposed to the first game that was PC exclusive.The game puts the player in the shoes of a U.S. Marine named Alcatraz whose team was sent to Manhattan to assist in rescuing civilians after an epidemic has infected the city.  Shortly after arrival, an unknown enemy attacked their Submarine, thus forcing the team to swim to the surface only to be gunned down by an Alien gunship.  Luckily, Laurence "Prophet" Barnes, former team leader of Raptor Team (Crysis 1) and known Nano-suit user, finds Alcatraz and bestows upon him his mission (along with the Nano-suit), before shooting himself in the head.  Alcatraz now faces a city at the brink of collapse due to the on-going battle between the US Military, Cell Paramilitary Forces and the Alien race called the Ceph.PROS:+ Beautiful graphics and User Interface+ Excellent sound quality, voice acting and music+ New mechanics like cover and quick activation keys (to access Nano-suit abilities for a more dynamic gameplay)+ Good story line that delves into the true nature of the Nano-suit and the Alien Invasion+ New customization options for the Nano-suit but...(See CON #1)+ Expanded weapon selection and upgrades+ Challenging but fair difficulties which highlights the use of each Nano-suit functions and upgrades+ Collectibles that expands the story+ Multiple ways to complete an objective despite the more linear mapsCONS:- Nano-suit upgrades are limited with some of them being outright better than the others- AI glitches at some areas, especially after reloading from the last checkpoint- Gun models take up a quarter of the screen (as if the gun was being held directly near Alcatraz's face)- Horrible FOV (Field of View)CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME.  Crysis 2, like its predecessor, has some of the most amazing graphical fidelity of its time which still holds up even today as it can be seen in its high-resolution textures, dynamic lighting, and beautifully crafted levels and sceneries.  The game introduces new mechanics such as a new cover system, Nano-suit upgrade system, expanded weapon selection, and a revamped Nano-suit ability activation mechanic. Despite the occasionally glitchy but challenging AI, you'll have an intense and action packed experience.The game could last you at least 8 hours of game time with your average difficulty setting and around 10 hours with the harder ones in single player.  Do you buy this at full price?  Sure but I highly RECOMMEND you buy this as a BUNDLE (Crysis Collection) which would include Crysis 1 and Warhead.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? 												If you've played a FPS in the last few years - then what Crysis 2 has to offer should not be mind blowing. Machine Guns, alien swarms, sniper rifles, grenades, headshots, shotguns, etc. Shoot a red barrel and it'll explode...yeah, it's all there. Personally, I would describe myself as quite "over" the FPS genre as a whole. However, that being said Crysis 2 manages to do all the typical FPS shooter mechanics extremely well... and throws in a couple of unique (although still not exactly not mind-blowing) little tweaks which is what makes this a really great game, and subsequently worth your time and money.First off the single player campaign is both lengthy and well paced. The story (I have not played the original) is solid for the archetypical "Stop The Alien Scourge" type of deal. Coupled with really tight controls and a good swatch of weapons - it makes for a rewarding experience. The whole differentiator for the Crysis series is the suit that you are in control of. You can enter two modes which change the way you face each challenge. Being able to go "Stealth" (vis 'a vis the Predator effect) means that you can approach enemies unseen. Upgrades to your suit eventually allow you to perform more stealth kills and even walk through crowds of enemies unseen.The second mode is an Armored mode. This basically allows you to go whole hog for a time and survive for a couple of hits longer then you normally would in a firefight. Doesn't make you invincible but it gives you a definite edge in both taking hits and dealing them out as well.You can also run and jump which is considered "Power" mode, but honestly it's just another thing to drain your energy so that you can't zip around and be super armored at the same time.Combining these two modes with a variety of customizable weapons, suit up-grades and tactical approaches provides a really interesting and robust way to tackle each encounter. You can literally approach the same scenario differently each time. I found the AI in this game both challenging and interesting at the same time. Enemies actually react to getting shot, hide well and as frustrating as a stealth kill that doesn't go unseen (although you think it should be) is - it's good that game doesn't mess around. There will be times when the AI just stands there or runs around sporadically but pound-4-pound it's more of an aberration than an annoying norm. And as someone who is generally kind of over this kind of game in particular that's high praise.If you're a fan of the FPS genre then this should definitely be something you play. If you've never played a Crysis game and are burnt out on the FPS shooter genre (like myself) - this is still a great way to pass a Sunday afternoon. The graphics are indeed great, the gameplay is really tight and overall it's a really fun game.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
The following covers only the single player portion of Crysis 2.For many, the graphical powerhouse Crysis is more notorious for its tendency to bring even cutting edge PCs to their knees, than for its gameplay. While it offered tons of eye candy for those that could run it, the fact remained that most were forced to watch from the sidelines as it was simply impossible to play on anything but the best hardware. But all that changes with Crysis 2, a ruthlessly optimized machine that finally lets all those wondering about the series a chance to see what it’s all about. Unfortunately, it never lives up to its reputation in any way than being a pretty face, and once you look past the visuals quickly evaporates into a game I couldn’t wait to leave.Everything in Crysis 2 revolves around the Nanosuit, a secret military project which grants the user superhuman powers and provides both tactical and medical support. Armor, invisibility, super strength, and Nanovision (a combination of solar and night vision) round out the list of your abilities, and for the most part you are given free range over how you use them on the battlefield.This is what sets Crysis apart from other shooters. While still linear in progression, there is a lot more freedom in how you tackle situations than you are typically allowed in a modern FPS. Maybe you’ll choose to go in guns blazing, armor at its max as bullets ricochet off like water drops, or perhaps opt for a stealthier solution and sneak through the water ducks behind enemy lines. Experimentation is encouraged by way of a helpful visor reminiscent of Metroid Prime, which highlights enemies, weapons, and different points to begin your assault. When everything is working right Crysis 2 can be an incredibly rewarding and exhilarating experience where each fight becomes its own puzzle for you to unravel. The real problem though is that these moments are few and far between.One of the main reasons for this is every feature of the suit is tied into an energy gauge. When you use one, the meter depletes leaving you completely exposed and unable to cloak or use armor. While clearly designed to keep the game from becoming too easy, it also does a fantastic job of taking away from the feeling of being a super soldier developer Crytek tries so hard to create. Getting stuck in a firefight without the suit’s abilities is a common occurrence that almost always results in a near instant death, and even passive abilities such as meleeing enemies and sprinting are tied into the bar, which leaves you essentially helpless once it runs out. Using the energy bar to regulate abilities isn’t a bad idea in theory, but the execution is constantly working against the player to create a frustrating experience constantly stifling its own potential.The other big issue are the enormous amount of bugs, most of which revolve around the comically bad enemy AI. Cloaking highlights this most, as enemies are entirely oblivious to you when you are cloaked, going so far as to ignore you taking out their comrades mere inches away (I can only assume they are used to seeing their partners suddenly fall to the ground for impromptu naps). Fall into an enemy’s line of sight however and all of a sudden every living being knows where you are. Cloaking then acts as something of an on/off switch for enemy fire which comes grinding to a halt the second you cloke, a useful if entirely unrealistic way to exit a firefight that is equally unsatisfying. Finally you have the moments when the enemy AI simply breaks, getting stuck on geometry, running in endless circles, and all around being complete fools that are almost more fun to watch than to shoot, because truth be told shooting them just isn’t very fun. When everyone acts like a broken robot it’s hard to feel as if you’ve accomplished anything when you outsmart them, and for as intelligent as Crysis 2’s mechanics may be, every enemy you come up against seems to have drawn the short straw for brains.The narrative also left me wanting, hitting every cliche in the book and topping things off with some of the most abysmal writing and voice acting I’ve had to endure in a very long time. The interesting premise and opening scene where you, a soldier on his deathbed, are given the nanosuit and along with it the memories of its previous owner, is quickly swept aside in an endless stream of betrayals, convoluted twists, and an inability to ever explain what is really going on. I lost count of the number of times you lose consciousness, only to awake with your allies once again swapped and your motives changed. The writing is overly simplistic and juvenile, turning a lackluster plot into a cringe worthy affair. Rounding out the package is the flat voice acting that never could hit the right emotional tone nor bring any life to the script, but I suppose you can only do so much when given so little.But if there is one thing everyone is wanting and expecting from Crysis 2 it’s another benchmark graphical showcase, and in that regard it does not disappoint. The level of detail in each scene is astounding, with the lighting effects in particular standing even higher above the rest. Seeing the sun breaking through the dilapidated buildings of New York is awe inspiring, and although I won’t spoil them, the later half of the game is filled with some of the most impressive set pieces I have ever seen. Few games can match the visuals found in Crysis 2 even years after its release, and the amount of optimization wizardry done to ensure it runs well even on lower end machines is nothing short of impressive. Sound design is equally well done, with deafening explosions and gunfire which threaten to blow your subs and does more than anything else to provide a much needed wow-factor to the proceedings. The great score grabbed me right from the opening menu, setting the tone for the game and adding to the overall epic feel of the game.Undeniably beautiful, Crysis 2 has a lot of good ideas but does a poor job bringing them together. The bevy of bugs and glitches, most notably the terrible enemy AI, took almost all possible enjoyment out of firefights, and the few instances where the game actually worked as intended only further displayed just how much wasted potential was left on the table. What we are left with is a below average shooter wrapped in an extremely pretty package, but one that can’t hide the dull and lifeless game underneath. It’s hard to dislike something that throws so much eye candy at you, but in this case beauty is only skin deep.Disclaimer: If you are curious why my gametime is so low, it's for the fact I originally played Crysis 2 on the Xbox 360. However my time with the PC version has confirmed that it is very much the same game, aside from the obvious graphical upgrade. If you find anything I said to be inaccurate, let me know and I will look into it and update my review accordingly.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

Action packed and beautiful to look at, but too linear for its own good.Crysis 2 was developed by Crytek Studios and released by Electronic Arts in March 2011. Four yours earlier, the same developers scored a huge success with the first game in the series, which was well-known at its time of release to be the most demanding pc game ever made. But apart from being a technical masterpiece, pushing graphics to a lever far beyond anything which had been yet achieved, the original Crysis also offered good gunplay in a fairly big theater of operations. While not being without some problems, the game impressed me and so I started playing Crysis 2 with high expectations.And that's probably exactly where the problems started: from the beginning, I compared this game to its predecessor. And so I expected a gorgeous looking, extremely demanding shooter within a rather open world, allowing for several routes to achieving one's objectives. Crysis 2 definitely managed to impress me on the visual and technical side: visually it offers anything one could wish for, taking into account the game was released over five years ago. The setting has completely shifted from the lush jungle of the first game to an impressive rendering of New York devastated by war. Although visually still impressive, with tons of details and lots of smoke and debris, the urban setting does diminish the large-scale feeling of the first game quite dramatically, and the different levels felt more constricted and definitely a lot smaller.From a purely technical point of view, this game still stands firm, although it does show that it was a console port, rather than a game originally developed for pc. The controls are less fluid and intuitive, and seem geared towards playing with an xbox controller. This was actually the first first-person shooter I've ever played with my controller – normally, I definitely prefer keyboard and mouse in this type of games. But in this case, it simply offered better and more naturally laid out controls. As far as graphical settings go – often a problem with a game first developed for consoles: they were fine, offering enough possibilites to crank up the eye-candy to stunning levels and giving (just) enough options to scale the settings for those wanting to do so. It's not the most demanding game out there anymore, but it still can tax any medium-range system: don't expect it to run at full HD on the ultra preset with anything less than a recent, fast i3 and a good midrange gpu. Given the fact that the game has been used so often as a benchmark for computer systems and graphics cards, I was slightly disappointed not to find some sort if benchmarking tool included, but that's a very minor issue.Much more problematic is the complete transformation as far as the actual gameplay goes. Gone are the open areas where there are several, often radically different, routes to one's objectives. Instead, Crysis 2 offers a series of set pieces: medium-scaled area's with primary and (sometimes) secondary objectives with one or two lines of approach. By using the "tactical mode" of your high-tech suit (more about this in a minute), you can scan the battlefield for enemies, supply stashes, but also for "tactical options", such as the ideal route if going for a stealth approach or the way to go if you want to flank the enemy. In other words: the game wants to hold you by the hand as much as possible! While this might be ok in a very linear first-person horror game, where scripted sequences are of the essence, it is in no way desired in a first-person shooter. I often tried to ignore the tactical suggestions, but mostly found out that there were no viable alternative routes, or that another approach than the one suggested almost inevitably resulted in a quick death. And with its horrendous system of saving only at set (and very irregular) waypoints, dying is something you definitely want to avoid in this game.Fortunately, not all is bad: the story definitely kept my interest throughout the game and often made me persist through a difficult section. It's not a great story – there are a lot of unbelievable plot-twists and too often a mission ends rahter abruptly – but it's better than in most "super human rescues the world from bad guys and aliens"-games. The most interesting aspect of the game is actually the special combat suit (the nanosuit) which you use as the player throughout the game. Just like in the original Crysis this suit offers several modes of operation: strength, armor & cloak – the last one of course ideal for a stealth-approach. Since I like being stealthy, the cloak-mode turned out to be my best friend, but it's also a tad overpowered if used correctly. The nanosuit can be upgraded during the game with energy provided by killing aliens, but those upgrades often felt tucked-on and didn't offer anything really new.As far as the actual gunplay goes, Crysis 2 surely delivers big time. There are a lot of different, often high-tech weapons out there to try out, and after some playing around with them they proved to be very well balanced and offering more than enough firepower for any chosen playstyle. Especially the energy-based weapons, ideal for mowing down aliens, were great fun to use. In the end, I did enjoy this game, if taken on its own merits: I sneaked up on several guards from behind, killed them with my knife, dashed for cover when I ran out of energy for the cloak mode only to be discovered by an alien who then started to throw emp-grenades at me. Very often I could just hang on in a firefight, having to make split-second decisions in order to survive; at other points, I could move forward at leisure, popping in and out of cloak mode. It was great fun, but it wasn't a gaming experience which I'll remember for years to come.Cautiously recommended: don't compare it to the original game, but enjoy it as a decent first-person shooter. And crank up the volume: the music is fantastic.

												Ever since its initial release in late 2007, Crysis has been touted as one of the most visually impressive games to ever to be released on the PC. But no one really talks about the gameplay too much. That could have something to do with the fact that in order to experience the wonder of said graphics and not just look on in awe as demo reels were shoved down your gullet, you needed the world's fanciest PC gaming rig. Still, there were plenty of people who did have a good enough computer to run Crysis and even more who wanted it to be available on the home consoles as well.Crysis 2 made that nanosuit-boosted leap through the air to the console market in a brilliant and impressive manner.For part two, the fight has moved from the imaginary island of Lingshan to the very real New York City; the only difference being that in this version of The Big Apple, there's a virus going around that melts people into a pile of goo and an invasion from some very squid-like alien beings. It's now up to you as the man in the fancy nanosuit to give these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s a run for their money. This time around, though, instead of just wandering around an open world and blowing all the pretty bits up, you're guided through a level-based experience that keeps the plot fluid and creates a more streamlined gaming experience.Somehow the team over at Crytek has found a way to make their sequel just as visually remarkable as the original and without the need to spend a fortune on a fancy new video card and extra RAM.The desolated streets of Manhattan have an eerie presence about them. The once bustling metropolis has a sense of recent and sudden abandon written all over it, like everyone just stopped what they were doing and disappeared. It's the most "living" dead city I've ever seen in a game. Anyone that's ever been to the five burroughs of NYC will probably agree with me that the essence of the city has been captured in the graphics.From a visual standpoint, the whole vibe of the game is Planet of the Apes meets Escape from New York while the gameplay itself is more Halo meets Metal Gear Solid. You can choose to go balls-out guns-a-blazing through every level like a suicidal badass, all the while utilizing the suit's armor mode much in the same way a Master Chief would, or you can use the suit's stealth mod e to sneak by the enemy undetected, creep behind him, and stab him in the head like a sneaky Snake might. It's up to you how you want to carry out missions and you're given a variety of ways to deal with situations. You could even skip combat all together and just sneak around everything if you're good enough or just bored with fighting. Obviously, there will be points where fights are unavoidable, along with some moments where you're forced to drive vehicles and run over stuff while blowing other stuff up, but overall Crysis 2 does a good job of letting you choose how to handle everything in your own way.As you progress, you can customize your nanosuit to better fit your playing style whether it be for longer lasting stealth mode, quieter footsteps, or a flying stomp attack to get the drop on enemies.For the most part, the AI does a good job of not letting you walk all over them, but there are a few times where I found myself blindly punching the crap out of my opponents with the armor mode engaged to get out of situations.The plot is also a bit boiler-plate and most of the shocks or twists are pretty easy to see coming. But even though you'll figure out that Darth Vader is Luke's father long before you should, there are still some very surprising things in store for fans of the series, though most of them seem to occur earlier rather than later in the plot.Crysis 2 has done an amazing thing here. It's a sequel that while borrowing heavily from the first Crysis, plays out absolutely nothing like it and creates its own standalone experience.This is one of the few games that dramatically enhances its previous installment.

Great gameplay and beautiful scenery with a terrible (bad) scenario!That is basically Crysis 2 in one sentence. But let's go a bit further!The good, the bad and the ugly--, I mean the derp.	The good :It's gameplay.The gameplay is what makes this game so fun to play. I'm not a huge fps fan of brainless killing and I prefer my fps to be intelligent and have a good and long interesting story. This one compensate the story part by it's very entertaining gameplay and huge variety of weapons (WICH IS GOOD FOR A FPS AM I RIGHT?). I expected this game to be more like a derp shooter where you kill everything, but I actually quite enjoyed the stealth part. But of course, the gunplay is also great.The stealth part is absolutely not forced nor necessary, but I found it the most interesting part for me. Hearing the soldiers screaming and being all scared is a sadist joy that I don't hide. It just feels really good to sneak around all stealthy with our superior armor and killing them in style.Speaking of the soldiers, there are 2 main enemies in this game. Human soldiers, and Aliens. The gameplay is quite different when facing them. When you fight soldiers, you feel like... a hunter, a predator hunting his prey. And every kills is really rewarding as you feel powerful. Op even. And feeling powerful is a good feeling (because the game is not that easy on hardest difficulty!).When facing the aliens, it's quite the opposite. They are numerous, strong and almost scary. This time I often choose to hide. Not because I enjoy stabbing them in the back, but because I'm genuinely scared to face them and their superiority. In this case, I feel like the hunted. Aliens also have some huge boss and they are pretty challenging.But all this talk about the weapons would not be enough if we don't talk about the ARMOR! Because yes, the armor has such a big role in this game. It's actually it's core mechanism. Other than having the most badass voice you ever heard for an armor, it is also packed with lot of skills and uppgrades. Stealth, superior armor, thermal vision, scanning abilities, superior jump... There are a lot of differents functions. The game is made so that you will need them at least once during the course of the game at some key parts. For instance, I often find thermal vision to be more of a gadget in most games, but here it feels really good to be able to see in heavy smoke or being able to see stealth opponents... But of course, they are usefull for the whole duration of the playthrough. Never made useless.How do you uppgrade your armor by the way...? Well, here is an interesting way of working. You get more energy by killing aliens! Seems easy right? But aren't they the kind of enemies you would rather avoid? Yes! That's the trick. It's easier to avoid them, but more rewarding to actually kill them!The graphics :Crysis 2 has always be known for being a very demanding game when it was out in 2011. And... well, even after 4 years the game is still insanely beautiful. It's not just that it is plainly  "looking good"  but, the scenery and the actions are absolutely brillants, unique and gorgeous. You will see some scenes in this game that you never saw before in any other games. New York having a tsunami? Huge tentacle robot coming through the ground and destroying the city? Flying island? Absolutely epic collapsing of buildings and huge explosions? Yes, this game has them all and it looks astonishing.Miscs :You can also customize your weapons a little bit. Always nice to have. The game lenght is pretty good if you play a bit more stealth wise and play on hardest difficulty. I would say around 17hours for me since steam misses a few hours.The bad :It's story.Oh boy... oh boy. Well, where to start? The basic story is that Aliens are attacking earth and you are a marine in New York that is going to fight them back.And well, that's it! Enjoy!No, actualy there is a bit more. But it's just extremely cliché and uninteresting, and mostly poorly excecuted. They tried to put some "conspiracy" and "betrayals", but the characters are so stereotyped, blank and annoying that you just can't care about what is happening to them and the story. Your own character has absolutely 0 charisma and personnality. The only "interesting character" is actually... your armor. Yup!The game also have a kind of repeating scenario for the whole game. Something like I'm alone >>> I found my crew! >>>  I lost them and I'm almost dead D:  >>>  REPEAT! >>>  I'm alone >>>  Another crew found me! The Ai :The ai has in my opinion only one and major flaw. They kind of always know where you are even if they don't see you. This is extremely annoying and is a stupid way to try to artificialy increase the difficulty. How does this stupid functionality works? It's simple, even if they never see you or hear you, the ai will tend to move where you are and either, search, pattrol, or stand there like nothing. It makes them finding you unfunny and not "deserved". This almost always happens with the humans ai. Rarely with the aliens though.The design :Even though the aliens are looking great, they have a major flaw. Most of them looks very close to each other so it's very hard to know if it's a "basic grunt", or one very advanced type of aliens. Only a few ones have really unique look.The army feels :Here is a personal opinion. It's simple, if you love american army stuff, you will like the general feeling of the interraction with your character. If you don't, it's pretty annoying. This game has a "oh wow army is awesome we are heroes" feels and people seems proud to call you "marine", or "soldier" at each possiblities and you know it's done because they think it's "awesome to hear it", and it keep showing the american flags very often and other details like this. Also you're pretty much the most cliché "super soldier hero" character you can think of.The derp :Some stuff in this game are neither impressive nor bad. Like the music. It's not bad, but there are not many and seem to repeat themselves. If you are interested in the multiplayer, know that it's not working anymore. I didn't have any glitches, expect a few enemies falling from where they were (like next to a cliff or on a window). It was more funny that annoying. I heard there are modding with this game, but I didn't try it.Conclusion :If you're a huge fps fan, just take it. I think it's a good game, but being now an old game with such heavy competitors.., I only reccomend it on sale for everyone else. However the game is very fun to play... and actually, isn't that the most important?

												To be honest, I never liked Crysis. I always looked at it as a techdemo. It was one of those games that had numerous glitches - BSODs and audio glitches were frequent and I do not remember any other games with which I was having similar issues at the time. Also, my rig surpassed the system requirements for the game so I never understood what could have caused these issues. But the various websites and forums on the internet confirmed the same.In any case, the jungle environment was already familiar following Crytek's Far Cry. So, when the news came that the sequel to Crysis would take place in New York (now an "urban jungle"), I looked forward to seeing and playing it. The game delivered: the destroyed cityscape of Manhattan looks superb thanks to CryEngine 3. We are to navigate between the floors of destroyed buildings and combat on the city streets is common. Finally, the aliens appear in the form of regular soldiers, too - it's not just the big monsters that you need to fight like in the first part.As for gameplay, the protagonist's nano suit has been streamlined. Strength and speed modes are now combined. We can now perform silent takedowns so following a stealthy playing mode is more rewarding. Upgrading the suit's features is a possibility based on the alien kills we perform - this is an unnecessary role playing section of the game but it does not represent any issues.Overall, I was satisfied with the sequel. Single player campaign lasts for 12-13 hours which is quite long these days. Cutscenes are frequent and Hans Zimmer's excellent score helps us with the immersion into the world of Crysis. Too bad that starting from June multiplayer mode will be unavailable for good (following the announcement of GameSpy), so, should it be discounted, it should be purchased with only the single player experience in mind.

												Even if I'm giving it thumb down I could recommend this game to certain people. Its a decent shooter, with nice graphics, and some great moments.However, personally, I didn't like it very much, and theres a lot of reasons for that. Comparing to its predecessor it has improved story, multiplayer, and alien design, but overall, original was a far better game (but still far from my favourite game). Original Crysis was obviously a game designed with PC in mind, and you could see that in every aspect of it - graphics, huge levels, level of destruction, and other stuff. It was ported to consoles years later, but in Crysis 2 version of engine, and with no surprise. Instead in the jungle on islands Crysis moved to the jungle on concrete, how they call New York, and very popular thing to say during this game's advertisement period. Levels are now far more stiff. Here and there you may stumble upon some more open area, but rarely, soon after you will return to your usual corridor roam. No matter how wide its corridors are, corridor shooter is still a corridor shooter. Initially, it came with only dx9 assets. It got dx11 facelift later, but even after that you can still see a lot of hidious textures, especially on the walls. Here and there you may break some glass, TV screen or a vase, but generally environment is indistructible. You can use carboard boxes as a solid cover or even hide behind cellophane wall. Which is just ridiculous comparing to the original, where you could level down structures, or even cut down the trees with shooting. But this is just a nitpicking, mostly. Despite all of that, even without highres textures, its a pretty looking game, theres no doubt about it.AI in this game is brain-dead, and I'm not even exaggerating. You may not notice it initially, because of the sheer numbers of opponents you'll be facing most of the time. But sooner or later you have to see how they love that cover... They love it so much that they won't move from it even if you stand right before them, or even after putting a bullet in their body. It happens that they forget about you after you run past them, you or they hide behind the cover, or ignoring the fight which happened just couple of metters behind them. Sometimes they won't acknowledge your presence until you shoot them, even if you are in the open in front of them, in their sight range. Other hilarious stuff includes your marine ally getting killed because he accidentally stopped where scripted event occured and jeep runned over him, killing their colleagues (or even themselves) with their own grenades, blowing themselves up after accidentally shooting the red barrel behind which they were hidding...But what I hate the most is that camera movement. PC designed original had nice and smooth aiming, unlike Crysis 2. Its not that bad, but no matter how much I'm tweaking mouse sensitivity, I just can't get rid of that feeling like I'm moving controller thumbstick, and not a mouse. Like something drags me down. Lowering settings to get some extra frames doesn't help either (game runs smooth on highest settings anyways). In SP with laughtable AI its tolerable, but in MP its a killer. Yet another sign of its console design. Similar problem I had with Halo 2 PC port, or Bioshock Infinite, yet another console-infested game.As I said, story is better this time, but again - nothing for an Oscar. You are some US Marine grunt, infiltrating New York via sub with your team. But soon hell breaks loose after alien incursion, your whole team gets killed, and you are saved by Prophet, character from the first game. You will see him just  briefly at the beginning, he is infected by the alien virus, and can't last much longer. He gives you his nano-suit, and puts a bullet in his own head to break the link with the suit. But before that gives you the order to find certain scientist, that guy who your team supposed to find anyways. For some reason, your character doesn't say a single word for the whole durration of the game, not even "I'm not Prophet, God damnit!" to all those people trying to murder him screaming "Its Prophet!", but eh.Nano-suit went through some changes. You still have the option of modding weapons with various attachements, and armor and cloak modes are working as you used to. There's an additional option: by eliminating filthy xenos you can collect nano-catalyst points from their dead bodies (aliens are coming in several types, and how much you get depends from the type), and you can use them to upgrade your suit. Abilities are divided into 4 classes, with 3 potential upgrades for each, and only one upgrade at the time can be chosen per class, (such as improved health and energy regeneration, improvements for cloaking, bullet tracing, etc), and in that way it gives you certain amount of customisation. If you have enough patience you can easily farm catalysts on certain locations, where  you can just run around and melee alien grunts, since they are no challenge anyways. Strenght and speed modes are now combined into one "Power" mode and its active all the time. High jumping, grabbing and kicking your opponents/items, and running is using your suit energy. While for strenght mode it makes some sense, why someone decided that simple sprinting is using your suit energy - I really have no idea. Not to mention that running in this game is on par with walking in majority of other games, and walking is painfully slow, plus when we combine that with console treated aiming... Since levels are smaller and far more linear now, designers probably thought there wasn't any need for that super-dash, or normal walking. Maybe its more realistic that way, and I'm nitpicking again, but I'm playing games for fun mostly, not for their realism (as much as the game with setting like this can relly on realism).MP is fairly basic, and fun for a while, but nothing that kept me for too long. Btw, you are required to create a 3rd party account, since this game doesn't use Steamworks. Since MP in this game is almost dead, ranked matching is not an option if you plan to play at all, so you are stuck with the custom server browser, which often results in playing with far more leveled players than you, with far better unlocks and perks (besides regular aim-bot users). You can play either in nano-suits, or as regular troopers. Playing with nano-suits is not particulary fun, its just a bunch of ghosts shooting each other, because cloaking is far too often used, and no wonder - you are literally invisible. But even without it its hard to spot someone most of the time, because design of uniforms easily blends with the envronment. Besides several pre-determined classes, with your unlocks you can create your own custom loadout, only one is available at the beginning, and if you bother to play enough you can unlock more by leveling. EDIT: With Gamespy service shutting down Crysis 1 and 2 are losing their MP support on the PC, so you are only stuck with the SP from now on.And lastly, I have to mention great sound assets, and fantastic soundtrack. You can unlock it completelly in extras by finishing campaign levels, so nothing costs you to give it a try. I recommend tracks "SOS New York", "Chase", "Rampage" and "One Way In".

Teal DeerDevelopers: Crytek StudiosPublishers: Electronic ArtsInitial release: Mar 2011Genre: FPS, Action#Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationThis is a Far Cry from the original Crysis.. is that not funny? Too soon? Anyways..Let me explain first by telling you why Crysis 1 was far more than a tech demo.  It was what marketing teams now popularly refer to as yielding something know as “emergent gameplay” Sure, I'll grant you it was a technical showpiece when real time shadows on foliage was ground breaking not only for technical achievement but also for your wallet regarding the new GPU you'll need to run it properly. There was real strategy to be had while playing Crysis. From cloaking yourself, sneaking behind someone and grabbing them by the throat, switching to strength mode and throwing them off a cliff. To tanking and switching in between maximum armor, strength and speed to jump over a fence and blasting unsuspecting fools with an automatic shotgun or on the fly switching between different scopes, applying a silencer, crouching, taking aim (maximum strength, to steady fire) and sniping on the fringe of a base. These are just a small percentage of what the game allowed you to do. All this was combined with a huge open terrain of varying topography. All of this is exchanged for a easy to grasp corridor shooter in Crysis 2. Now, don't get me wrong I love a good corridor shooter but the freedom of play granted in 1 turns the “freedom” into clearly labeled things within your visor such as get up high and snipe or stealth through the sewers, leaving any guesswork or self discovery out of the picture. I won't harp on the story of either as I don't think either are truly interesting however nor are they offensive. They are just or sort of latent. Regardless I still prefer the original narratively speaking because I believe the pacing to be a lot better as well as the mystery of what exactly is going on on the island. This is feels more like where else can we take this idea we started with. After all this reasoning as to why I like Crysis 1 better. Crysis 2 is still worth playing. I haven't played the multiplayer but I don't play much multiplayer anything so that info is better commented on by someone else. What I can say is the gunplay feels great, combined with the exo suits abilities. I'm sure the multiplayer is as fun and competent as the campaign and certainly will extend the life if that sort of thing floats your boat.Follow my curation for more

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Reality 2.0. A review from New York.There is this morbid fascination with seeing New York destroyed in movies. This game does just that and does it really well.The graphics.Nothing to say here. Cry Engine 3 is going to dominate the graphics department until Frostbite 2 comes out I guess. It's going to be an interesting stand off. I did however notice some inconsistencies with water. Most water still looks great. However, some parts of the water are just outright consolish looking. As I was playing the game, I found myself constantly being distracted by the graphics whilst I was getting shot at which was annoying. However, when you are invisible, you still cast a shadow and your floating gun is also visible to the enemy. Now the game gives you the option to run around in third-person view.The story:Well, you still play as a mute character named 'Alcatraz'. Nomad actually had a voice. And they do attempt to tie in the story with the first game, somewhat. But hey, on the positive note, you can actually cast a shadow and you have legs this time around.The locations:There are 19 missions. You start off at Battery park and then you advance towards the downtown area of the city through the East side. You will visit many historic locations and some of them are going to be blown up. The scale of the buildings in the game and reality is almost 1:1. One thing is that the skyscrapers in the background are randomly picked. Apparently the devs did not wish to go through more trouble of placing the real skyscrapers in the corresponding locations. Let's get one thing straight. This is not a sandbox game. At the end of the day, you are given an area that you have to navigate through to get to the next check point. So even though that makes the game linear, the fact that there are several approaches to your destination kind of makes the city your playground. I loved seeing the old closed off Brooklyn Bridge 6 train subway stop. They have only recently re-opened it by the way.The NYC subway maps that are in the game are wrong though, not to mention some geographical errors. The devs also put the train tracks on the streets, and NYC does not have those except for the old abandoned old track that was delivering coal to a plant a hundred years ago; now it is a museum.But at least the intersecting streets and historical locations are correct.The game does give you a significant area to run around when you approach the Grand Central terminal, otherwise the entire game consists of isolated carefully constrained few blocks that you have to go through.The bottom line is that, it is not really New York as I hoped to see it, but it is New York enough.Times Square has been pulled off very well, but of course, most of its blocked up by the mysterious US Army cement blocks, seriously? The US army can barricade NYC in the matter of hours of alien attack with thousands of these blocks?Hint, when you find the head of the Statue of Liberty, go inside of it.The sound:The sound is great. Distant shots, shouts, explosions, alien growls, your gun shots - it's all there. Can't comment on the music however, since it ruins the immersion for me, no music necessary.The gameplay:Extremely smooth. Quick load times as usual, responsive keyboard and mouse. The recoil is extremely realistic, unlike other FPS games. Even throwing a grenade is bound to give your screen a shake. They slightly augmented the role of the nano suit here. This time, the energy regenerates much faster. Not only that, the energy regenerates no matter what. So even if you are swimming, your energy will eventually recharge even if you do not surface. Needless to say, that makes the game easier than the first one in that department. There is also a cover system even though I didn't use it a lot. It is reminiscent of the Killzone franchise, wherein you remain in cover and you are able to peek out and see what's going on ahead, instead of being able to see everything if you were playing a third person shooter.You can still grab the aliens by their throat and choose to either knife them, throw them or use them for cover. But you can't just take any alien by its throat. You have to either soften the alien and pump it full of lead first or punch it a few times, then you have the option to grab the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Sliding. Not really that useful but it's nice to have the ability.The ability to climb up if you just can't reach that ledge. I found myself jumping from building to building just to grab onto the ledge and pull myself up.The strong kick. Useful in kicking large things around.You can upgrade your suit and your weapons based on your progress in the game and how many enemies you killed.Introducing the nano vision. No more night vision. This time, you can see traces of water vapor or traces of heat or enemies while everything else on the screen remains black and white.The game gives you the option to bypass your enemies completely, and most of the time you can pull that off.There is some driving, but it only last a few seconds at a time.The ammo caches are scattered throughout the city. So even though you cannot carry as much ammo at a time, you will easily find ammo elsewhere.There are a few types of aliens, but most of them are infantry. You will find some big fat ones and a tripod. You will also see a couple of cloaking aliens.Also, there really aren't that many enemies to fight in the game. In total, you will perhaps only kill around 150 foes. On one side, it will never get frustrating of getting swarmed by aliens and dying constantly. There is always plenty of room to maneuver. On the other side, it does not really feel like there's a lot of fighting going on. There's a couple of companies of the Army and the Marines roaming the city and there is only a handful of aliens.The weapons:The weapons are plenty, probably as many as in Crysis:Warhead. The ones are also introduced. I am only happy to once again comment on the realistic recoil of all weapons.The negatives:1. The aliens aren't really that menacing, but they do look like the aliens from Battle:Los Angeles.2. The invasion does not really feel like a real invasion, but a series of isolated skirmishes.3. Fighting aliens is a lot like fighting humans, not that I know what it would feel like fighting aliens. But regardless, they do take cover, they do retreat and they don't really have any special abilities.4. There is a slight re-spawn of enemies but not anything like in Call of Duty series.5. The game is not an exact replica of New York City. Maybe only 50%-60%.6. There are some bugs there and there especially with the AI. The AI is good for the most part. But this one time I was laughing my♥♥♥♥♥off when I saw an enemy soldier jump over obstacles when he actually tripped over the obstacle and fell head down and then got up. I don't know if that was just a crazy physics' engine bug or actually part of the AI algorithm that has a % 0.00001 chance of this happening.Finally, the production values are off the charts and there really is no good reason why you shouldn't buy this game. And I haven't even played the multiplayer yet.

												Crysis 2 is one of the most graphic intensive games available (besides it's seuqle Crysis 3) Crysis 2 consists of Run & Gun/Stealth elements that combine together to create a satisfing gaming experience, the story is engaging and new features are introduced as the game progresses, this is done to keep the player engaged in the game as they continue through the story. content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												It is rarely that I have played an FPS that managed to impress me and keep me on the edge of my seat with its action and at the same time completely impress me with its storyline. Mind you Crysis storyline might seem generic and cliche as they come and there's a definitely an element of truth to that.Having played this game in 2016, almost 5 years after its release, I can certainly say that if you told me this was a 2016 game I've would have believed you. Sure the player models might seem a little stiff and dated, especially in a gaming era where facial animations are scrutinized constantly and Crysis 2 is worthy of complaints in that matter, the textures and the environment however still look as beautiful as ever. The times of old memes (WILL IT RUN CRYSIS) are perhaps gone, but this game is certainly worthy. Still looks good, especially in the maximum edition where it features the High Res textures.Crysis 2 gameplay is also pretty damn good. There's smooth movement, decent aiming, the action flows greatly and constantly at your own pace; you can take a stealth route to eliminating your enemies or you can go guns blazing. Naturally in higher difficulites a proper combination of both strategies will net you a quite satisfying and intense experience. The gunplay is great, there's a variety of different weapons to use, each one with their own stats and modifications. Don't worry, it's super simple to customize your weapon and you can do it on the spot too! No need to go back to a bench/whatever to modify your gun.You want to stealth this part of the mission? Add a silencer and a scope. You want to fire more bullets? Add extended clip. You want a secondary function to your primary weapon? Add a grenade launcher! It is important to note that not all weapons have the same modifications and some unique and powerful weapons might not have any at all, but still this is a great feature which has unfortunately been completely ignored in the modern FPS.Last but not least, your nanosuit is essentially what makes you an unstoppable soldier. There's armor mode to reduce damage taken and stealth mode which makes you invisible and allows for a more stealthy approach. The modes are mutually exclusive which makes sense and use energy. Furthermore you can upgrade your suit as well with different enhancements which can also be done on the spot as well! Improve your armor absorb, make you stealthier, decrease the energy drain etc. Admittedly there around 15 to choose from but they are there and they can define the way you play through missions.For completionists, there are several collectibles scattered around the different levels which include: emails to expand on the lore, collectible dog tags, collectible car keys and souvenirs from New York.The level design is magnificent. The city of New York looks wonderful,   even after the Ceph invasion and destruction, the map progress allows for a semi-linear if you will completion of objectives. Don't think that this is not a linear game. It totally is, however there's a degree of freedom in which you can complete some of these objectives. You can avoid enemies if you will, flank them, use vehicles, detach turrets from barricades etc. The gameplay is absolutely great, never a dull moment and it keeps you on your toes constantly.Now for me of course, since I'm a sucker for 90s/early2000s blockbusters (The Rock, Independence Day, Armaggedon, Crimson Tide, Black Hawk Down) the story is pop-corn entertaining fun. The dialogue is as good as it gets, you get your epic speeches, your betrayals, your arrogant villains, basically all the tropes you'd expect in a movie. And you know what? It ♥♥♥♥ing works. It works so well in the concept of the game and it fits perfectly. And I cannot stress enough that all of this would otherwise seem silly if it wasn't for the exquisite soundtrack by no other that the master himself, Hans Zimmer. Hanz Zimmer is one of my favourite music composers and he's also the primary reason why I fell in love with the Single Player campaign of Modern Warfare 2. The soundtrack is epic and it intertwines with the gameplay, superb dialogue and the game itself in such a way that I think that any other soundtrack would have seriously affected the way I felt after I finished Crysis 2.Now the negatives which definitely exist but by no means take away the joy of the game. The enemy is AI is a little bit weird, don't expect smart enemies who will try to do everything in their power to kill you. Even at max difficulty, they behave is a rudimentary way. They hide behind cover, they fire, sometimes they might throw a grenade or two and they will try and move towards you. Nothing fancy and a bit on the silly side at occasions especially whenever stealth is involved. The models look a bit dated as I mentioned above and lip-syncing might be non-existant at moments. Notable example is the soldier talking to you while wearing a surgical mask, really shows that the developers didn't want to bother with lip-syncing and facial animations with the exception of some key characters. Most of the dialogue is transmitted to you via voiceover in the suitcomms however said dialogue I believe is vey well written  for the context that the game is based on.I'm not saying that this is the best dialogue in the history of gaming, but for the cheesy action packed game Crysis 2 is, the voice acting and the dialogue is brilliant.Lastly the game is a bit short, not as short as such of the 4-6 hours of modern FPS single player campaigns (I estimate around 8-10 hours if you also want to get all collectibles), there's very few Quick Time Events but there are there, cutscenes while great tend to border on the unnessecary at times but overall Crysis 2 is a one of the greater games of genre and you should have the pleasure of playing it. I got this at less than 5 euros during a sale and I think it was a steal compared with the entertainment I got out of it.tl;dr: Crysis 2 is a brilliant FPS and you should definitely have the pleasure of enjoying it yourself, strongly recommended, a true classic.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Crysis 2 is a first-person post-apocalyptic shooter developed by Crytek Studios and published by Electronic Arts. The game was released in March 2011. The story continues from Crysis 1 where the Ceph invaded the Lingshan Islands into them invading New York, USA. The player plays as Alcatraz, a member of Force Recon One, whose mission to infiltrate and capture Dr. Nathan Gould goes terribly wrong. This review will discuss the campaign and the dialogue, the gameplay and the features, performance and graphics, and the issues with the game. I did not test the multiplayer component as the online portion went offline in 2015. In addition, the Maximum Edition aspect of the game is irrelevant as all of the contents were related to multiplayer.Crysis 2 encompassed a good and logical storytelling campaign. The story expands on the Ceph invasion into America from the Lingshan Islands and the inevitable counter-attack by the Americans. Furthermore, the game provides great insight into the background of characters that carried before and through both games, notably Prophet and Jacob Hargreave. For instance, Prophet reveals that following Crysis 1, he found out it was not the last of the Ceph, rather the beginning of a new war. The story in the game made sense by the end of the campaign so I commend Crytek for elegantly telling the story. However, I do not like the massive logic gap from Crysis 1 to 2 because the sequel does not mention the aftermath of the cliff-hanger in Crysis 1 as the aftermath is explained through the Crysis comics series, which irritated me and I feel is an unwise business move. But, the dialogue in the campaign was excellent in telling the story. I completed the campaign in 10 hours and my favourite component was the team-based missions alongside the US Marines because many post-apocalyptic games result in a lonely protagonist. My second issue within the campaign was the lack of real excitement in cut scenes that clarified a major part of the overall story. For instance, when Jacob Hargreave reveals his knowledge about the Ceph, which I will not spoil, it comes across as another cut scene, not as a great storytelling moment, even if it was. Lastly, this game features some collecting aspects such as collecting dog tags on missions, collecting flashbacks, and so forth. It's not overly filler but it's not overly interesting to invest the extra time into finding the extras. Overall, the campaign is good because the story within the game, not the overall story is told with depth and precision and has minimal loopholes. The main issue of having to follow the comic series to determine what happened in the cliff-hanger from Crysis 1 does hurt my overall experience of the campaign.Crysis 2 possesses a variety of gameplay features to mostly improve the game. First, the game features a levelling system in which Alcatraz can kill the Ceph and garner Nano Catalyst points to upgrade his nanosuit. There are four different tiers with three upgrades in each, which is separated into tactical, armour, power, and stealth module tiers. This is a decent system because it allows you to improve Alcatraz's overall combat effectiveness and it has a nice balance to not overpower him but improve him because as the campaign progresses so does the difficulty of the Ceph. My major annoyance with this system was the lack of clarification if an ability is active or not once you purchase it. For instance, if I buy threat tracker, the game does not mention whether its active. The second gameplay feature is the layout of missions in the campaign. I really like the layout of the missions because despite the game being linear, you can approach a mission in a variety of ways. For instance, when Alcatraz opens his visor, he can see his tactical options for the mission, which may be going 100 metres to the right through stealth to complete the mission or going forward 30 metres and grenade the enemy. Furthermore, the weapon customisation system expands on the variety of approaches in a mission because Alcatraz can alter his gun depending on what approach he wants to take, ie. Stealth approach and a silencer. This freshens the gameplay and missions because Alcatraz has various options in completing a mission and can suit his equipment towards that approach. Lastly, the weapon combat, melee system, and vehicle movement and combat are all smooth, fluid and enjoyable. Vehicular combat does spice up the game, particularly on long distance missions. Overall, I commend the gameplay and the variety of features because it all does enhance the game experience.Crysis 2 has very consistent performance and beautiful graphics. This game reinforces why Crytek were the leaders in gorgeous games because this 2011 game is truly a stunning game. The graphics are superb, from the destruction that affects the landscape to the realism of characters to the overall tone of the post-apocalyptic atmosphere. Furthermore, I like the simplicity of the UI, which is the main menu. The performance as mentioned, is very consistent. On my mid-tier system, which specs are highlighted on my profile page, I played on very high settings and drew a constant 35-50 fps. When there were FPS drops throughout a mission, there was no stuttering, making performance steady throughout a mission. However, at the beginning of the majority of missions there would be a major freeze probably due to a massive fps drop for some unknown reason. Loading times varied in the game. Some missions took longer to load than others, which was annoying on some levels but not a major nuisance. Overall, the only hitch in performance was the start of the mission stuttering, but for the most part this was a smooth game. Likewise, the graphics was top-notch.Despite most of the review containing positives and some containing negatives, this game had a ton of bugs and glitches. I encountered six bugs and/or glitches that occurred frequently throughout the campaign. For instance, the worst was the sound engine dying, resulting in me restarting my computer. The second worst annoying bug was dialogue showing up on the screen as I had subtitles enabled and the characters that were meant to say those lines went silent, pointing to more issues likely with the sound engine. And the other bugs and glitches was mainly relating to dialogue, event sequences and gameplay. All in all, the issues did hurt the game for me.Overall, Crysis 2 is a good game that features a logical and competent campaign, great gameplay and features, a beautiful atmosphere and environment and consistent performance for the most part. This game had a deep and logical story that explained the specifics and the broader picture. It provided fluid combat and various approaches to tackling missions, freshening the linear aspect of the game. The main issues was the logic gap from Crysis 1 to Crysis 2 due to the business idea that the story should be advanced through Crysis Comic series and the amount of bugs and glitches infested into it. This game is $29.99 and you can get up to 18 hours in my opinion on the game fitting in the campaign and the extras. At $29.99, I recommend getting this on sale. However, if you are completely new to the series, I recommend getting the Crysis Collection at full price of $44.99 because there is three different games that tell a massive story and all of which have been well received.Ratings:I calculate the point system by rating each component I discuss and then averaging the total and deducting marks depending on the amount and severity of issues within the game.Campaign: 8/10Gameplay: 9/10Graphics and Performance: 9.5/10Overall: 7.75/10Thanks for reading my review! If you liked this review, rate it and join my review group. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page.

												It's late 2016, putting this game at up to 5 years old, and it still shines. Before I go too far, read the last paragraph on the complaints of linearity.Crytek have an amazing grasp of engine technology, juicing more visual prowess, AI and performance from a PC than many other games on the market, and it helps drive an amazing game.The setting is a well-realised New York City in the near future, with an alien attack ongoing, and several parties trying to vie for power to eliminate this threat and the various enemies in their own agendas. The story is excellent, and well acted (personally, this is my favourite SC/shooter/Super suit game - Sorry HL2), visually stunning (although a few updates now would truly put it back atop - it still is beautiful though, surprisingly so) through great texturing and lighting, and wonderful set pieces (Times Square in the soaking rain has a boss battle which oozes atmosphere, and the final level is a breathtaking idea, I won't ruin it), excellent sound (atmospheric, and great voice work), and liquid performance and controls to run it.This game jumps from £6 to £12 (figure out your own currency, folks), and it's very much worth it at either price - a much treasured gem in your collection.Now many people call this game "linear", compared to the first game. Honestly, you do run through streets, which feel like gauntlets, but every location has a number of options for stealth, attack and supply routes through (using your visor to plan & scan), the only real difference is that you can't wander off AS FAR. The first game was just as linear, it just had "wider" areas to explore, but still required you to end up at the same space to perform the same actions, from within the same level. So yeah, it may feel enclosed, but the only difference is a little less space to mess around with.I highly recommend this game. Crytek make (or did) make fantastic stuff, and this is one of the best.But can your PC run it? There's fun in the question before you even select "campaign".Oh finally, you may want to read up a little on the events of the first game if you never played. Some self-referencing from the start throughout can leave you questioning things.

-Quick Review-Crysis 2 is an Action FPS with various degrees of stealth and environmental combat. Crysis 2 Maximum Edition was developed by Crytek Studios and Published by EA, Crysis 2 was released in 2011.Disclaimer: Multiplayer is gone, so that whole aspect of the “Maximum Edition” just went down the drain.Reference: http://www.pcgamer.com/crysis-and-crysis-2-pc-multiplayer-will-shutdown-with-gamespy/-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You are the Marine “Alcatraz”, Alcatraz inherits the Nanosuit 2.0 from it's previous owner whom calls himself “Prophet”, and now everyone in the game will call you prophet for half of the game.(This greatly annoyed me... to the degree that after an NPC exclaimed, “It's Prophet! Kill him!” I would promptly turn around and pummel him to death with my rifle stock.)The story itself is a little bit tough to follow if you've not played the first game (like I haven't), but having a large repertoire of sci-fi media background I easily caught on to what was being discussed within the game. The story is about as interesting as you can expect from a FPS from 2011 (in my personal opinion that's nothing to be proud of).I've also felt that architectural cues are being lost on me, you play through the destroyed streets of New York City. I have been to NYC once, but I felt like a lot of the geometry in the game was referencing the city, but was ultimately lost on me since I'm not very familiar with NYC.


Crysis 2 Maximum Edition 
A Screenshot of Crysis 2 Maximum Edition
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: The gameplay was the most enjoyable feature to Crysis 2; the Nanosuit 2.0 has a variety of upgrades which can be purchased after you kill and collect samples from the extraterrestrial aliens.There are several ability enhancing traits the Nanosuit 2.0 offers: Sprint, Jump, Armor, Stealth, and Nano-vison. All of these abilities require suit energy, so there is a limited amount of time you can use these abilities, using multiple abilities drains energy even faster.


Nano-site-mode (*cough cough* Heat vision *cough cough*) 
A Screenshot of Crysis 2 Maximum Edition
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are no Steam achievements for Crysis 2. There were achievements for the Xbox version of the game, so someday there might be an update with achievements, but at this time there are none.


Taking Damage (there's no health meeter, it's demonstrated with the blood on the edge of the screen) 
A Screenshot of Crysis 2 Maximum Edition
By: Atratzu




Price: Crysis 2 – Maximum Edition is priced at $29.99. Unfortunately “Maximum Edition” is a fancy way of saying “here, download extra junk you can't use, because there isn't multiplayer anymore”.Buy the game when it's on sale, the game itself should be priced lower for the content and the amount of time it will take to play through the game. One play through will take approximately 6-9 hours, depending on the difficulty and how “completionist” you are.Conclusion: All in all, Crysis 2 was a good game. Mediocre sci-fi story. Entertaining and rather flexible gameplay. No steam achievements at this time. Over priced, wait for a steam sale or bundle deal.I recommend this game to people who enjoy FPS, but unfortunately this fall into my “play and forget” game categories, so ultimately it doesn't have any niche that sets it apart from other generic story-driven FPS's out there.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update September 26, 2015:Spellchecking, thank you Angfucious.

												A visual treat of a follow-up to Crysis, the sequel completely changes direction and almost suffers from it, if not for its otherwise excellent game-play. Whilst Crysis and Warhead did very little truly interesting in the narrative department (with Warhead at least trying to do something about addressing that) the sequel quickly puts you into an entirely new environment and situation with very little explanation into a world that is a mess. Being ferried from one set-piece to the next on a strictly linear and far narrower path, I quickly realised that I was losing focus on what was going on with a conflict that seemed to spring out of nowhere and whilst there are obviously connections to the original, they seem tenuous at best. Crysis 2's narrative is a mess and whilst Crysis got away with its minimalist approach as it didn't shove it right up your face, it's hard to ignore the silliness going on in 2 as it, unfortunately, does shove it in your face.The plus of all of this is that the core game is still very fun, if not severely reduced in scope and potential variation. Replacing open objectives are checkpoints along a trail that mostly replaces the how you approach an encounter with where you approach it from; the game does at least provide different routes for you to approach fights from that can give eager travellers an upper hand. This is particularly important given that the nature of your enemies have changed and whilst you're still fighting a lot of humans, you also have various alien enemies to take out, from foot soldier equivalents to large walking annoying bosses. The removal of island openness does at least make way for some truly fun set-pieces though as the further you get into the game, the more interesting they become culminating in an extremely fun final level. As memorable as some of them may be though, there is an inherent reduction in the replayability in the game; you can only approach encounters in so many ways, set-pieces are only unique the first time and weapon variation (both in what's available and how many you can carry) limit the empowering craziness of the original and Warhead. Ultimately, 2 feels very much like an extension of the ideas in Warhead, but at double the length and losing what made Warhead a fun in-between point of Crysis' openness and general FPS linearity. By the end of this game though, whilst I had felt satisfied, I was in no rush to play it again, nor even consider how I would attempt to go back to that particular set-piece and try completing it in a different manner. Essentially, there's one good run here before the game feels like it has expired.Whilst Crysis 2 does look fantastic and has a great sound-track to boot, it lacks much of the uniqueness that its predecessors had whilst only providing minor boosts to the things that already made it a great shooter. Fun overall, but a greatly reduced experience overall.Multiplayer: There's a greater push for the MP component in 2, but it essentially plays out like many small map-based shooters. A few interesting quirks here and there, particularly in your suit-enabled movement, but otherwise an extended feeling from the main game, that of competency and not much else.
