												Damn I love this game.Some will argue that this game is a shadow to what Crysis originally was, however this game was a different approach to the franchise and was not meant to be like Crysis 1. Instead of having that semi-linear "open world" gameplay C1 and CW had, it's a linear campaign. But it's not like Call of Duty in the sense that you're just in a small corridor for the entire game, in Crysis 2 you're in one of the world's largest cities- NYC. You can go into many shops, houses, hotels, and like Crysis 1 you can hide in bushes and shadows. Using that Crysis style of gameplay, you can get through enemies however you want- You can cloak through them, run and gun with armor, or just spam grenades or run away entirely. The main villains of the game, the CELL corporation and the Ceph are a bit less intimidating than the enemies you faced last time around, but they aren't stupid either. CELL will have enemies that rush you in numbers while the Ceph has giant robots, sumo wrestler aliens, and extremely powerful gunships. The story is so much more in depth and detailed than it was in the first game. Not to bash the first game, but all it was is "the KPA is hiding something Annnnd it's aliens" but this time around the characters are much more memorable (I really only enjoyed Psycho in the first game). It is ridiculous that Alcatraz, the guy you play as NEVER TALKS and if he could talk CELL would have never been hostile to him. You'd have to play the game to understand what I'm saying, but trust me you'll be thinking the same thing. But other than that, I found the story to be pretty good. The campaign itself is around 7-10 hours depending on difficulty, and it's 17 missions long (18 counting that the first mission is just a long cutscene).Multiplayer isn't even online anymore so I don't have much to say about it.Since multiplayer isn't a thing anymore, and I don't hear it was that much good to begin with, I'd say 19.99 isn't really worth it. I got this for 8 dollars so I think the price I paid for it was worth it.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Many fear Crysis 2 to be the franchise’s turn from an open-ended objective-based shooter into a linear shooter that parrots the gameplay trends of all the other AAA shooters these days. For the most part it is, but that doesn’t stop it from being better than almost all those games. It’s very different from the original Crysis and Crysis Warhead, but Crysis 2’s level design still has a certain quality that’s rare these days.If you can find my user reviews of Crysis and Warhead, I described those games as possibly the last examples of sandbox-style mission design where you’re free to tackle objectives how you want in absolutely massive maps. Crysis 2 chucks that whole approach for something more similar to Call of Duty or better yet Halo. Crysis 2 has obvious chest-high walls for cover everywhere, quick-time events, a storyline about aliens and mercenaries that’s generic despite having been written by a published sci-fi author, upgrades bought with experience points, and generally gives players fewer options than its predecessors. It doesn’t however shove you down straight corridors, but maintains some semblance of the franchise’s open-ended nature.Where in the original Crysis players would get a full map of an area and multiple objectives at a time, Crysis 2 will display a single waypoint at a time at the other end of a medium-sized area with maybe three or four routes through it. You might see a sky bridge flanking around some enemies, a hole in a barricade, or a small tunnel underneath the area. And the game will directly tell you all this by highlighting weapons and routes on your tactical visor, assuming you’re used to more linear shooters.For what they’re worth Crysis 2’s levels are pretty well-designed. It’s still possible to sneak through most areas of the game and play the whole thing stealthily. When firefights do break out, instead of just popping in and out of cover you have a lot of room with which to employ some positional strategy on enemies. Effectively it’s like fighting in a Halo game’s combat arenas but with fewer vehicles.The nanosuit’s powers have been adjusted a bit from the earlier games but the same general strategies apply: use cloak to sneak by or flank enemies (prone is gone by the way), throw objects and leap around with strength, etc. The main change is that armor mode is no longer the default but must now be switched on manually, so you have to factor it in when managing the suit’s energy. Speed mode is pretty much just the sprint which automatically consumes suit energy. Strength is actually just a super jump and a melee attack.The aliens in Crysis 2 are simultaneously a bit more interesting to fight and more boring in how they work. In the earlier game Crytek tried to make them feel more “alien” by having them float around in the air with vague shield abilities, which could often make combat with them feel odd. In Crysis 2 they behave a lot more like humans as they walk on land, use what look like guns, and generally behave like your human enemies. Because they have different weak points and can sometimes disable your suit energy though, you still have to approach them differently. There’s one interesting new boss-type enemy that appears a few times throughout the game, and Crysis 2’s final combat sequence manages to be an unusually interesting and challenging fight.One area in which Crysis 2 is unquestionably an improvement over the original is its visuals and its strain on your hardware. The sequel both looks and runs better than the first game, especially in DirectX 11. I guess being released on consoles meant Crytek had to actually optimize the game this time. Crysis 2’s use of lighting, post-processing, bokeh depth of field, and tessellation put it above all but a handful of games released since 2011 in terms of tech. It’s probably one of the earliest games to reach the threshold we’re seeing on PS4 and Xbox One now.On my i5 and GTX 760, on maximum DX11 settings in 1080p the game runs at 60 frames per second almost all the time, occasionally dipping down to 50, and never going below 40. However, like its predecessors Crysis 2 does suffer the problem of locking to 24Hz when played in fullscreen on a TV. Forcing a borderless windowed mode with external software can fix this.To compare, in my earlier reviews I called Crysis and Warhead simulations of 80’s action movie tropes where you can manipulate the mechanics of Predator and First Blood Part II however you want. Instead of a simulation, Crysis 2 feels like a game -- everything about its levels and mechanics has been transformed into a smaller set of rules Crytek wants you to follow, but within those rules it’s still one of the better games on the market.

												Well, where to start? This game is a great example of corperate greed. Yeah, that sounds about right.First off, the storyline is mediocre. I wish I could understand it, I really do, but to me this is like an epilogue to a poorly written spin-off of crysis. That isn't even the beginning.Gameplay...Basically, it's Call of Duty with a nanosuit. Gun play and other mechanics mostly found in multiplayer are extremely close to CoD style, Crysis was it's own game and didn't rely too much on other games for ideas. That has come to a close with Crysis 2. Oh, and I almost forgot that everything is much more linear in the campaign than the original one was aswell.Multiplayer, yet again it's CoD with a nanosuit. In Crysis 1 you had tanks, vtols, and helicopters, and you had a CS styled buy menu, everything was bought with points you earned. Now, it's default weapons with class loadouts and unlocking new weapons requires leveling up, sound familiar? Oh, not to mention killstreaks such as Radars and Radar jammers, air strikes, and a ton of other things. Oh, and Mesa, the biggest MP map in the original crysis, is probably bigger than all of the MP maps in this game combined."But if it's so bad, why did you get it?" It was part of the EA Humble Bundle, I didn't have to touch the keys for it but here I am, wanting to try and play SP again to see if I can make more sense out of it than I did when I first played and beat it. TL;DR: Don't get it if you're a huge fan of the first game in the series. If you love Cawadoody but you're looking for a little bit of change in your life, this will take the cake and your wallet.

												W10 Defender: HOLY CRAP IT'S A VIRUS OH MY GOD NO NO NO NO BETTER CRASH THIS THING BEFORE EXPLAINING WHAT A FALSE POSITIVE IS. Yes, the game crashes because W10 thinks it's associated with a "severe" malware type. I don't believe Steam would have left it on the store if that were true. Just make sure to have the Crysis 2 folder under the Common folder (SteamApps) set as an exclusion to Windows Defender and you'll be fine. Also, because of this random crap, you'll probably have to change how your admin notifications appear. Since I don't mess with piracy, torrenting or what have you, I always set the notifications to OFF. They came back up, always asking me if I wanted to make changes to ANYTHING on my hard drive before opening up any sort of application. That was annoying...Jokes aside, not done with the game but it's pretty solid. Nice combat, tactical opportunities, great visuals. The downside is that the story is dull and the performance is kinda inconsistent. I'll get random screen stuttering and artifacting but it's only occasional. Also the game does NOT like an OC'd GPU so keep that in mind. I got rid of the bizarre artifacting by going back to my factory clock speeds (ZOTAC GTX 1060 AMP). My system is well within the recommended specs so, yeah, you tell me if 16 GB of RAM and an i5 4670k @ 4.2 GHz aren't enough.Meh. Whatever, it's fun but it's not perfect. 7.5/10 baby

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Sadly, I was disappointed with this game, it has little to do with the original. Yeah, the suit and weapon customization is there, but it's basically COD with crysis paint over it. This is one of those games where "consolization" can ruin a once beloved game (same thing happened with Deus Ex Invisible War, except that game was terrible) into a casual-friendly, graphics blazing, linear focused game.How much equipment you can carry?In the original crysis, you can select fists, dual wield pistols, carry 2 two-handed weapons, an RPG, different types of grenades (Flash, Frag and Smoke) and C4 charges. Here, you can't select fists, you can carry only 2 weapons (includes pistols, which is CODesque), an RPG, Frag grenades and C4. Nothing else.Weapon customizationIn the original, rifles, shotgun, sniper rifle, smg, minigun and alien minigun can be equipped with laser sights which prove useful for the hardest difficulty, where there is no crosshair. Here, laser sight completely overrides how you handle the weapon. Worse, it's almost impossible to aim properly with it and did I mention it takes the scope/sights slot?What about sights and scopes? In the original, any two-handed weapon (minus the minigun and alien minigun) can be attached with any scope or leaving them scopless.Here, you can't attach a sniper scope onto a SCARAB, SCAR or an LMG (later in crysis 3, they added that functionality again from the original, but it's too late).What about fire modes? In the original, if you had a tactical attachment or a grenade launcher on your rifle, you can select any fire mode you want - from Full auto to Semi-auto to tactical attachment or grenade launcher.Here, any attachment you attach is going to replace the Semi-auto fire mode. How does that make sense? It's designed for consoles to qucikly switch between modes.Finally, the last part.The engine - CryEngine 3It's designed for both PC and Consoles, but you can clearly see that it's optimized for consoles. Not only that, but the engine itself is really buggy. You will see sometimes dumb A.I. enemies and partners that aid you in battle by simply standing and doing nothing, shooting at walls and sometimes they go in a t-pose or simply freeze. There is also a glitch where you can carry multiple weapons (i. e. a pistol, scarab, shotgun, sniper rifle etc. instead of 2 weapons), and also there are occasions where you have to reload the checkpoint or a level, because some levels can halt your progress if you don't play in a specific way.OverallOverall, the game is not good, but not bad either. It shows how the "consolization" process can ruin games by removing features, making the game sometimes linear focused so that the game works good on consoles and also simultaneously disappointing PC fans of the original. Sure, you can have fun with this game, but if you loved the original, keep in mind these things I mentioned, if these disappoint you, skip this game. But if you don't care about these problems, then I'd say give it a shot, but expect bugs and glitches. Most of them are patched, but the rest are still relevant. As for my personal recommendation, I say skip it.

content:
Posted: January 24
												=| Disclaimer |=I have never played a Crysis game before nor do I have that much experience with storybased shooters on a regular basis. This also is a first impressions type of review that I shall update when I finished the game. I realise that the game is out for a few years now so the "First Impressions" wont matter all that much to you but I cannot just put out a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥review of a game I barely played, so instead I will write my first impressions down.=| Review |=After loading the game for the first time, it stopped loading and I had to restart the game. After a restart however it seemed like everything was fine and it loaded up right quick. With the usual logos popping up that got annoying in Metro already. That sidehit out of the way, no big problems after this occured. Saying this I should also mention that a few people seemed to have problem with the steam installation. Enough problems for another user to post a discussion on the matter that it would be easier to activate your key on origin and download it from there. That being said, the gameplay awaits.[Warning. The following content of the review may or may not contain spoilers. Read at your own risk.]As I hop into the game I am greeted with real life cutscenes and soon after the first intro part of the game. I am a Marine and I am supposed to save a grand man because he seems to be important to, I honestly have no Idea. I know that they talked about Aliens and that is all that was stuck in my head. That and the behavior of one member of the team acting like a total dumbass on a team of trained professionals. But instead of actually getting on land we are being attacked by an unknown force. Most likely Aliens as I assume. We have to get out and the usual intro mission stuff kicks in. Duck, Run, Hold this to open door and get out only to get the team shot and you being the sole survivor. And then I am greeted with a quite awesome cutscene with quite awesome music.But of course, getting shot by a alien Drone (?) also has its benefits. Because now a man in a cool looking armor scares the thing that attacked you away and carries you to safety. You wont get to know him for all that long because as soon as you wake up, you not only wear his armor but also see him dead on the floor. As you pick up his gun you are greeted with what will be your mission and information about the armor. The information is broad and not explained in detail as the game wants you to learn it in active combat, which I prefer greatly. It gives you little points in the game that dont break away from the immersion (due to the fact that the tutorials are portraied by the suits interface and AI) and gives you small tutorals on how to go into stealth mode, how to activate armor and how to use the suits visor. From there it is all you and how you play the game.And here we go towards the gameplay. Apart from the usual small tutorials the game runs very nicely. My PC not being the best gaming PC to be had I dont have a full on 60fps but I also dont know if that even is a thing for the game. For all I know, it could be capped at 30 as some games do. If so, please let me know in the comments so I may correct the review for that matter. Going through on scenario after another I finally reach a bigger street with a bunch of enemies all over the place. I thought that I would just die there and not get through it in one try. Seems like I thought wrong as it was easier than I thought. The enemies after all are not bulletsponges and grenades can make the journey through the city also a fairly enjoyable one at that. Sure you will scare off all the birds but if you see one of those alien cockroaches, I am sure that you are happy about that as the aliens will have to feast on human flesh instead of those birdies. Oh wait, its equaly bad. Well at least you saved one being for now.Getting through the first part of the campaign was rather easy to say the least. I am playing on Normal difficulty and find it still challenging enough. Now having entered the second part (just after loading) and getting to fight my first enemies in the new area I immediately died. And that is where I stopped to write this review.Now to a thing that happens to not only confuse me but also upset me. You know, optimisation is a huge issue when it goes to games of this scale. And I am not talking about games that just lag like hell. No, the game runs fairly smooth all things considered. But no matter if that is the case, the optimisation of the game could be better. You cannot fully adjust your sensitivity to one specific number but have to choose between 5-10-15 and so on up to 100. The cutscenes as well seem to have a higher sensitivity when looking around which can be a tad confusing as well. That aside the main controlls are also kind of not complete for that matter. Of course the game tells you what you have to use in combat, ingame but there is no way (or at least I couldnt find one) to remap those controlls. No option to remap stealth or armor function. And bloody hell can people stop putting crouch on C? Who uses C anyways? Jokes aside, that can still cause little issues while playing when you can barely pay any attention because everything looks god damn amazing and you are overwhelmed by it.The last thing I want to mention, which is a thing that annoyed me with GTAV as well. Graphical settings. The game (for me) turned on its lowest settings. That is just fine for me but there is a little problem there. Lowest, isnt "lowest". Lowest is "high". There are no options to choose Low graphical settings which seems to be a bit confusing for such grand titles. Because for GTAV, even if it says that you can run it on the lowest possible settings, that is about all you can do. Playing it is another thing that cannot be done for that matter. But of course this isnt GTAV (which still is a good game) and its playable no matter what. Its just that these are the things that I happen to find out while playing it for about an hour. And that is all.Thank you for reading.

												The game starts out decent enough where you can stealth and approach obstacles with different strategies, much like the first Crysis. With that said the stealth system is broken, where you can destealth behind a cement divider and a guy 100 meters away will just start shooting at you.However the game eventually turns into a horribly paced non-stop action filled shooter (that's not a compliment) where the only thing you can do is just shoot enemies and run to the next check point. Now this wouldn't be so bad but the gun play is awkward and the suit powers are pointless besides using stealth and armor if you are dumb enough to stand in direct fire.There is so much happening every second that you just stop caring about a building falling down or another alien ship crashing or defending your comrades from attack for the effing 100th time.The story is paced poorly as well and incredibly predictable. A large poriton of the campaign feels like pure filler. About 3/4 through the game the entire plot is frozen and you spend what seems like an enternity assisting the remaining marines in evacuating a dozen civilians and performing frustrating missions.I do not recommend as a Crysis fan I did not want a COD experience. I got maybe 5-6 hours out of this game before it turned into a shooter on rails. The first part of the game wasn't exactly 10/10 either.

												Great addition to the Crysis franchise. I should have played this much sooner but you know how it is, more games than time to play them I guess.The game takes place after the events of the first game and warhead. The story isn't anything amazing but it does a good enough job and is better then many other shooters I've played. The graphics are not on the same level as the original Crysis when it first came out in terms of advancment from other games at the time. However, they are still great and the game looks awesome. That is using the official Dx11 ultra upgrade that is built in to this edition. The suit powers you pick on the fly are Armor, Stealth, and power is is just automatic when needed so you can't just pick it anymore. There is also a suit upgrade system that you earn points for by killing the aliens. There are 4 categories and you can have 1 upgrade from each of the 4 active at a time. None really stood out as awesome or anything but they offer gameplay enhancements llike longer lasting stealth or armor, etc. I should mention that I never bothered playing Multiplayer as it is just something I'm not interested in, so I can't comment on how that is. Overall the game is worth what I paid for it for sure and I really enjoyed my playthrough. If it goes on sale and you are wanting to grab a good shooter, pick it up.

												Crysis provides both a unique and engaging premise for its campaign and top-notch graphics that once again raises the graphical benchmark for gaming. Well, kind of. It may not appear as instantly striking in terms of awesomness the original did with its lush, tropical setting but it's in the finer details and when things really escalate in the single player that will blow your mind. The sheer 'destructional' splendour of New York under alien siege has to be seen and played to behold. Seeing screenshots and a few gameplay trailers does not do it justice unless you're sitting there, at your desktop, plugged into your HDTV or whatever, with full surround-sound and maybe even 3D, escaping a sinking sub yourself. This being said, graphics don't make a game. And with such refined gameplay, it sure as hell doesn't make Crysis 2.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Transferring the system demanding open world FPS mechanics of Crysis to the consoles brought us Crysis 2 - a dumbed down, much more linear game, that plays like a blend of Crysis and COD/MOH/whatever other console FPS out there. It's not always a bad thing, as the funneling can lead to more intense/concentrated fights where you can't just dart off in any direction when you hurt your knee. And besides, there ARE some pretty open parts where it feels farily open worldish (almost).The audio and visuals are terricfic - especially the graphics. I played it in DX11 mode on "Extreme" (there's also a "Ultra" setting) as it seemed like a good framerate/eye candy compromise. The blend of scorched city, lush grass/trees and alien tech looks amazing. The campaign lasted me a little short of 9 hours, which I found appropriate in length, but the story itself is pretty generic alien invasion gibberish with an attempt at a plot twist when someone you thought was your ally was actually plotting against you (oh noes!).The only really bad thing here is the A.I. Sometimes it's just plain broken. Here are a couple of examples:I come up on a fight between soldiers and aliens, and decide to let them duke it out, and then kill the hopefully few suvivours. The last 2 NPC's standing is an alien and a soldier, who apparently found friendship while trying to kill eachother and just stood there 2 feet apart facing eachother - doing NOTHING. I put them out of their misery.Two aliens standing atop a container scouting for enemies (me). The guy nearest me apparently didn't have the keen eyesight of the one behind him, because he just stood there like a statue, while somehow managing to block the path of the alien behind him. Judging by his hyperactive movement he REALLY wanted to run towards me, and climing down the container to either side to circumvent his mime colleague was just not an option. After a giggle I vent into stealth mode and sneaked off.[SPOILER ALERT]The final fight with the 4 cloaked super aliens was just a (not funny) joke. They all more or less just got semi stuck in the terrain/invisible wall and figured the best thing to do was to insist on not shooting back, but instead trying to hide by turning on the cloak, which worked 0.02 seconds until my next bullet hit it. Jeez.[/spoiler alert]For the most part I really enjoyed the experience though - 80%.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												A visual treat of a follow-up to Crysis, the sequel completely changes direction and almost suffers from it, if not for its otherwise excellent game-play. Whilst Crysis and Warhead did very little truly interesting in the narrative department (with Warhead at least trying to do something about addressing that) the sequel quickly puts you into an entirely new environment and situation with very little explanation into a world that is a mess. Being ferried from one set-piece to the next on a strictly linear and far narrower path, I quickly realised that I was losing focus on what was going on with a conflict that seemed to spring out of nowhere and whilst there are obviously connections to the original, they seem tenuous at best. Crysis 2's narrative is a mess and whilst Crysis got away with its minimalist approach as it didn't shove it right up your face, it's hard to ignore the silliness going on in 2 as it, unfortunately, does shove it in your face.The plus of all of this is that the core game is still very fun, if not severely reduced in scope and potential variation. Replacing open objectives are checkpoints along a trail that mostly replaces the how you approach an encounter with where you approach it from; the game does at least provide different routes for you to approach fights from that can give eager travellers an upper hand. This is particularly important given that the nature of your enemies have changed and whilst you're still fighting a lot of humans, you also have various alien enemies to take out, from foot soldier equivalents to large walking annoying bosses. The removal of island openness does at least make way for some truly fun set-pieces though as the further you get into the game, the more interesting they become culminating in an extremely fun final level. As memorable as some of them may be though, there is an inherent reduction in the replayability in the game; you can only approach encounters in so many ways, set-pieces are only unique the first time and weapon variation (both in what's available and how many you can carry) limit the empowering craziness of the original and Warhead. Ultimately, 2 feels very much like an extension of the ideas in Warhead, but at double the length and losing what made Warhead a fun in-between point of Crysis' openness and general FPS linearity. By the end of this game though, whilst I had felt satisfied, I was in no rush to play it again, nor even consider how I would attempt to go back to that particular set-piece and try completing it in a different manner. Essentially, there's one good run here before the game feels like it has expired.Whilst Crysis 2 does look fantastic and has a great sound-track to boot, it lacks much of the uniqueness that its predecessors had whilst only providing minor boosts to the things that already made it a great shooter. Fun overall, but a greatly reduced experience overall.Multiplayer: There's a greater push for the MP component in 2, but it essentially plays out like many small map-based shooters. A few interesting quirks here and there, particularly in your suit-enabled movement, but otherwise an extended feeling from the main game, that of competency and not much else.

Steven Spielberg's War of the Worlds and Arnold Schwarzannager's Predator are big inspirations for the writers of this game, definitely. The story takes place after 3 years of the Crysis 1 and Crysis Warhead. To be able to understand it completely, you have to pay full attention to the in-game dialogues and watch entire of the Prophet's Visions videos, which are available in unlockable section in main menu. Otherswise you'll be confused with big gaps on the fiction, therefore you may not like the story. It's like a puzzle. My only criticism here to Crytek might be the bad presentation of it. And if you don't like the science-fiction/aliens genre, this is not your game.Crytek also appointed a science-fiction writer to write a novel, thay may help studying the story in a wider perspective. Lastly, Crysis Wikia will be enough to "veneer" your knowledge of Crysis universe, especially the page of Jacob Hargreave.And even though the game imposes the usual alien invasion theme, Nanotechnology is an important research are in 21st century, so I kinda like it how they built the story of the nanosuit and its capabilities on it. A huge potential area to tell a story, via a game.Gameplay: My biggest concern on the gameplay was "spawning enemies". Yeah, when you're beating the game on the hardest difficulty, spend your 30 minutes to clear a part of the map with huge effort, and after all seeing spawning enemies out of nowhere is not a nice experiment.So FFS Crytek, drop spawning enemies from your future games.There's no savegame function, but that's okay. My only complaint about it is the long time periods between the checkpoints. Dying after a large progression can take you back to a so early portion, which can ruin your gaming and enthusiasm.Lastly, abouth the "Nanosuit Improvement" part... You can access this part by pressing H in-game. You're granted catalyst point by killing Cephs throughout the game, the with enough accumulation, you can buy some cools improvements. But some of these improvements are so pointless. For example, de-cloaking your invicible enemies... There were only 4 invicible enemies in the game, all of them were in the last mission, at the last part of it. Which took 1 minute for me to kill them all. Unlocking this feature took 16000 catalyst points, which was also the most expensive feature of all.What were you thinking Crytek? Have you released the game without being finished?  With the distributor being Electronic Arts, that's a high possibility. EA is known for putting stress on the developers to release unfinished products in a pushed calendar.Musics composed by Hans Zimmer, who's known for his works in movies like Batman Trilogy, Rain Man, Gladiator, vice versa. The Main Theme was perfect.Graphics are alreadly critically acclaimed.So 10 points for visuals, 10 points for sound effects and musical score.And my overall score for Crysis 2 is 8/10 with all pros and cons summed up.Post Script: I haven't tried the multiplayer experience, I'll give it a shot when Crysis 3 hits.Cheers, Can

Posted: March 21, 2015
												      Ah, Crysis. An Instant classic in my book. Gamebreaking visuals of 2007 that even some of the best PCs found to be a bit of a challenge. Amazing visuals, stunning environments - particularly the alien space ship, and every level that was completely snowed out and frozen. Great alien concept, though apparently there were people ♥♥♥♥♥ing that they resembled War of the Worlds aliens too much (as if that really matters? It was a great enemy in-game).**** TL;DR at Bottom of this Review ****   I have great memories with Crysis 2 when I bought it on xbox360 the week it came out. Stunning visuals, Still a pretty good story.    While I recently purchased C2 on steam for nostalgia purposes (although it seems I am unable to use the crysis 2 login feature for multiplayer atm..), I must say that I still have my disappointments with the game.    I'm going to go head-on with what I consider to be the CONS of the game.    Unlike the original Crysis and Crysis Warhead, Crysis 2 (and 3) change up the overall HUD/viewpoint. Crysis 1 felt more realistic to me. In Crysis, your weapon was lowered and, visually, it looked further away from your head. In Crysis 2 and 3, your weapon feels like you are hugging it with your face 24/7.    I preferred how the weapon was positioned in the first installment. It felt more realistic to me, and therefore helped immerse me.    To add to that, while they still look killer, I much prefer the original look of the weapons in the first game. The Scar looks a little too futuristic in comparison to the original Crysis 1 scar which still looked futuristic (like an updated M8 Assault Rifle) while maintaining that solid modern look. The weapon designs in Crysis 1 and 2 do look great, but my preference, flat out, is the weapon design of Crysis 1.    Again, visually, I also dislike the changes they made with the nanosuit powers. The first Crysis had a "Maximum Speed" power, which was completely removed as a standalone feature, and instead, sprinting drains your energy. While this feature still works well for the game, I miss the overall individuality of Max Speed, and the other abilities. In addition, Crysis features a color changing effect when those abilities are activated.Using Max Strength empowered your nanosuit with a red glow, a glow that my eyes seriously enjoyed to look at. It just looked great.And using Max Speed surged your nanosuit with a vibrant yellowish glow that as described, surged through your suit. It looked astonishing even from the fiew parts of your body you could see in the first person view.Max Armor had no effect, and of course stealth made you stealth. These two maintained between both Crysis 1 and 2.    Visually the nanosuit looked better with abilities in use, and overall more realistic from my perspective. Whereas in Crysis 2 and 3, it seems almost like Alcatraz / Prophet is too buff. The muscles of the suit are almost exaggerated, and it just bugs me, the suit still looks iconic and great.    Previous statements involve cosmetic differences between the first and second game. However, my biggest complaint with Crysis 2 is the change in alien design.   Crysis 1 featured blue-lighted robotic aliens (with pilots inside) that flew around the sky with tentacles flailing about, as the aliens shot ice projectiles and ice beams. Their entire premise was freezing the environment while flying around. This was iconic and part of why Crysis 1 is and always will be in my mind a classic. Crysis 2 features red-colored robotic aliens with a premise of basically biological warfare instead of ice-age warfare. While the premise is just as, if not more effective story-wise for mass homicide, I cannot help but dislike this change. I much prefer Crysis 1's enemies to Crysis 2.    If you're still reading this, I give you a thumbs up.These CONS of course are personal CONS, and probably do not settle the same way with most other players as they do with me.That being said, despite my biases, I do love Crysis 2, because I am open-minded and won't hate a game just because it isn't quite what I prefer.That and the game still maintains a lot of traditional Crysis feel to it.The game feels great, and the multiplayer was a blast.I definitely recommend this game, but I INSIST that anyone who considers Crysis should purchase the first Crysis game first.TL;DR Buy Crysis 1 (If you already have played it then GREAT!) THEN play Crysis 2.

Posted: January 19, 2016
												I was once again about 5 years late in getting to this game. I enjoyed the gameplay of Crysis, and the powers and tactics afforded by the Nanosuit are fun. As far as the Nanosuit goes, it all seems the same from Crysis. At the cost of limited (but regenerative) Energy, you can have Super Speed, Super Strength, Super Armor, or a Stealth Cloak. Fun stuff. What's really obviously changed is an attempt at a slightly more linear experience in the vein of the Call of Duty's and Battlefield's and so on. The first Crysis took place on a massive, open tropical island where you had objective locations but you had a lot of freedom in how to approach them.The areas in Crysis 2 are much more traditional, though they're by no means over restricted. Each major encounter area gives you the option of full frontal assaults, stealth, or some kind of special item/flank (a sniper rifle, turret, rocket, sniper nest, vehicle, etc). Back when I bought it, I paid $20 for it, and it took me around 10 hours to beat the Campaign. So while the value could have been a little better for me, I have to admit I enjoyed those 10 hours. Even at 5 years old, Crysis 2 is a graphical powerhouse, and I didn't get any grief for using modern resolutions (2560x1440). There's nothing here that really sets Crysis 2 apart from a multitude of other first person shooters out there, but if you want to feel like a powerful super soldier and you've exhausted your Halo games, I recommend picking this game up on the next sale. I'm sure it would only be $5 or less.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												While it may not offer the same breath of freedom in approaching situations as it's predecessor but this is a solid game and the toned-down nanosuit still offers plenty of fun options.I don't want to dwell on what was lost from the first game. Instead I want to talk about what was improved. First of all a lot of the environments are more three dimensional that those in Crysis 1. While the first game had the super jump it mostly allowed you to just scale cliffs and get onto the roofs of the mostly flat buildings the game had. In Crysis 2 the urban setting allows levels to be more layered and verticality is much more important. For this it adds a ledge climbing mechanic that gives a much nicer feel to vertical navigation than in Crysis 1. The added slide move is also really fun to use in combination with a shotgun.To say the combat against aliens has been improved from the first game would be a colossal understatement. The alien designs from Crysis have been pretty much entirely thrown out and replaced with enemies that are actually fun to fight. The Ceph, as they are called now, fight in humanoid exosuits that make them seem familiarly human but while giving them a broad range of movement. They can climb, run along walls, squeeze through small spaces and are just generally very mobile. Their weapons are actually very inaccurate compared to human ones and they often resort to melee attacks.This allows you to fight them in a very different way to the human forces, who you must mostly engage from a distance and from cover like most modern shooters. With the Ceph you can dance. Use a shotgun or SMG or just your hands and attack them up close. Get in their face and move with them, after them and away from them. Explore the arenas you are in horizontally and vertically as you hunt after them. It's a style of play so different to how you face the human forces and the game's light RPG elements (alien forces drop pickups that give you XP) incentivise this up close and personal approach.The game offers a variety of environments and set pieces to engage in and many different guns, with the customization system from the first game still in place and unlike Crysis 1 the game remains fun up to and including the final level.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												Crysis 2 exceeds in graphics, gameplay, optimization, audio design, music, etc. Even the story is pretty good, written by Richard K. Morgan, who wrote one of my favorites, Altered Carbon.Set five years after the first game where you first witness the Ceph in all their terror on Langshan, the Ceph have made their way to NYC, an urban jungle (as described by Crytek devs). I think the most remarkable thing about Crysis 2 might be the attention to detail with the recognizable buildings and showing their true height, just looking up at them in a video game shows how massive NYC can really feel from a virtual perspective. Obviously, it helps that the CryEngine is perhaps the best engine out there in terms of graphical prowess.I really liked the story, mainly because I'm a sucker for sci-fi games. So the various twists and military factions you encounter while trying to survive from the Ceph was nice. Granted, it's rather easy to survive from the Ceph is you use cover appropriately and kind of strategize your plan of attack. Or you can stealth your way around them, I did that a few times just to see what would happen; can't do that the whole game though as really, most of the Ceph you'll have to kill just to move forward.I didn't check out the multiplayer, but I bet it's pretty cool. And the way the game ended definitely set it up for Crysis 3, gonna play that soon.9.3/10

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Cautions: A bit buggy with some graphics cards (however their are usually some workarounds such as underclocking your gpu, etc.).  Multiplayer master servers have been taken down so nobody plays online anymore.  Not a lot to it, you can beat it in less than 15 hours if you're good at fps, or don't feel the need to slaughter everything that walks across your path.Pluses:This game is pretty.  It's Cryengine's showcase game so that's to be expected.  Still pretty by today's standards.This game has a lot of variety.  You have objectives, and obstacles that get in the way off those objectives.  Fortunately there's a lot of ways around those obstacles.  You can snipe them, cloak and then come up behind them and knife them, charge head on with an assault rifle, throw grenades, ignore them completely and run past them, find a tank and run them over, etc.  So that's fun.  Note: It is really hard to kill the armored brute aliens by punching them to death, I advice Jaw rockets from a safe distance.Modding available and encouraged by devs.The AI is fairly clever and is fun to play against, though sometimes it feels like they're cheating when they aim at you when you're cloaked.  The story is...well really cliche'd, but mostly engaging.  You nearly die a lot, it kind of gets a bit old.  I got this game as a gift, so I'm not sure if I would pay full price for it or not - but if it's on sale go for it!Having never played Crysis before, I had no idea what was going on with the story or why there are aliens in downtown New York, but that's not really important I suppose.  I'm a nano-suit wearing badass, I'm there to shoot them in the head not ask questions.  Also I couldn't flirt with the cute girl which was disappointing (couldn't shoot her either, also disappointing), but at least she doesn't die.  That would be very disappointing.I kind of like the soundtrack.  Also Lockheart hates me.  :(  What did I ever do to him!?

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Sneak, or Blast, or Ambush, or Gun down muscle head soldiers or alien invaders...Notice that word: "Or", more on that later. Enjoy my reivew of Crysis 2 Story ~Prophet did what he could, after contracting the virus he entrusts the survival of mankind with you, by giving you the Nano Suit... just before he takes his own life. Sounds simple right? Well it pretty much is, and even though the game throws a few twists at you, it never feels like it is hard to grasp.You are entrusted with saving New York from an alien threat, and it becomes apparent how important you really are when you come face to face with the Ceph, who pose a pretty large threat if you try taking them down with normal means. They put up quite a fight, even for a fully suited super tech equipted Marine. Through video instructions you are able to see just how quickly the Ceph are taking over and pose a threat to the entire country if you do not act quickly. Gameplay ~Remember all of those Ors at the top of the review? Those options are what make Crysis 2 such a wonderful game to play. The game loads sections of the map at a time, unlike the first game, and tasks you with taking-out enemies (Or sneaking past them if you can) to complete objectives. When given these options and the ability to scan the area for weapons and threats, you have all the options in the world to beat each section however you see fit!The Nano Suit boasts 3 main powers that can activated or deactivated at will:-Sleath Mode          (Sneaky)-Armor Mode           (Tanky)-Power Mode          (Stabalize/Jump/Sprint)-and Tactical Mode  (...Tactical)Pick one, or pick them all, and enjoy ripping enemies to shreds by means you chose! Presentation The game is beautiful.Look at screen shots.I dont even need to write anything here. Final Thoughts Crysis does so much right, I am a huge sucker for choice in games, and an even BIGGER sucker for stealth in games done right.Each mode you can activate feels balanced and you have to adapt yourself to each one. Stealth is of course my favorite, and I would always do my best to get assassination kills with silenced weapons because when you expose yourself, some enemies will call for backup.+Great Musical Score that hit all the right notes when it needed to+Wonderful Pacing: You always felt like you were accomplishing something+Superb Gameplay complimented by unique weapons and gadgets+Tactics encouraged!+/- Graphical glitches on Ceph were farely common when executing.-Character dialogue was cheesy...very very cheesy9/10 Loved it

Posted: November 25, 2013
												While it may not offer the same breath of freedom in approaching situations as it's predecessor but this is a solid game and the toned-down nanosuit still offers plenty of fun options.I don't want to dwell on what was lost from the first game. Instead I want to talk about what was improved. First of all a lot of the environments are more three dimensional that those in Crysis 1. While the first game had the super jump it mostly allowed you to just scale cliffs and get onto the roofs of the mostly flat buildings the game had. In Crysis 2 the urban setting allows levels to be more layered and verticality is much more important. For this it adds a ledge climbing mechanic that gives a much nicer feel to vertical navigation than in Crysis 1. The added slide move is also really fun to use in combination with a shotgun.To say the combat against aliens has been improved from the first game would be a colossal understatement. The alien designs from Crysis have been pretty much entirely thrown out and replaced with enemies that are actually fun to fight. The Ceph, as they are called now, fight in humanoid exosuits that make them seem familiarly human but while giving them a broad range of movement. They can climb, run along walls, squeeze through small spaces and are just generally very mobile. Their weapons are actually very inaccurate compared to human ones and they often resort to melee attacks.This allows you to fight them in a very different way to the human forces, who you must mostly engage from a distance and from cover like most modern shooters. With the Ceph you can dance. Use a shotgun or SMG or just your hands and attack them up close. Get in their face and move with them, after them and away from them. Explore the arenas you are in horizontally and vertically as you hunt after them. It's a style of play so different to how you face the human forces and the game's light RPG elements (alien forces drop pickups that give you XP) incentivise this up close and personal approach.The game offers a variety of environments and set pieces to engage in and many different guns, with the customization system from the first game still in place and unlike Crysis 1 the game remains fun up to and including the final level.

Posted: September 24, 2012
												Crysis 2 is epic. It is easy to get lost amongst the sheer scale of the seph-torn cityscapes of Manhattan, a city breathing with life due to the technically impressive CryEngine 2. That's right, the graphics are spectacular, with a great attention to detail, and cater to a range of builds. Other than the jaw-dropping, mouth-watering visuals, the combat in this game is excellently paced, challenging and genuinely fun. There is a large variety to weapons and suit upgrades, accommodating for a great many number of playstyles. The soundtrack does very well to harmonise with the constant action, in particular the main theme, composed with grandeur by Hans Zimmer. The story is fairly straightforward, with a foreseeable arc, although it does have its fair share of surprises.Tl;dr Crysis 2 (Maximum Edition) is an excellent first-person action game, with beautiful visuals, varied gameplay and a really enjoyable campaign.9/10

Posted: August 28, 2013
												One word to describe it: Beautiful. It is absolutely beautiful. Even on mid end laptops like mine, it looks incredible. The color and lighting makes this game look so realistic, and the intro video to the game is the most epic intro I have ever seen in a game. The graphic quality is on par with the best games TODAY (Despite being almost 2 years old), and easily wins over most FPS. The score is by Hans Zimmer (who also composed the Dark Knight), and is very well done. The gameplay is special - it kind of reminds me of a combo of Battlefield, Blacklight: Retribution, and Halo. Elements from each game polishes this one, and the campaign is a lot of fun. Got it from the Humble Bundle, and very happy that I donated and got this game:) Overall: Graphics: 10 out of 10. This game challenges big ones like Planetside 2 and Battlefield 3 in terms of graphics. CryEngine 3 for the win!Gameplay: 9.5 out of 10. In this game, you are more than just a character... you are a WEAPON. Stealth and strength are your main tools; you can either choose to use stealth elements and make the combat feel like an FPS Metal Gear Solid game, or use "Maximum" elements and go bananas on the enemies using brute force. Campaign: 9.5 out of 10. Has good replay value, and long story line. Multiplayer: 8.5 out of 10. The multiplayer is awesome, but you may need to be very patient. My first few matches online were miserable... I was confused on how to set up my classes, and the people online are very competitive. There are lobbies dedicated for "Recruits", but those are always filled up, so good luck on "Standard" or  "Pro" lobbies. Doesn't take long to adapt, however.Overall score: 9.5 out of 10. All I could say is... I regret not buying this game any sooner. I will buy the entire series (Crysis Maximum Edition and then Crysis 3) very soon. A MUST play.

												Crysis 2 is wonderful sequel to the original Crysis storyline, but the game does not crush modern systems as its predecessors. While dissapoining to some, Crysis 2 still remains to be one of the most beautiful games out there. Although, it doesn't provide the same "sandboxed" feeling as the first two, the maps do still offer a variety of approaches from full head-on assaults to stealth kills. Crysis 2 does excel in a more streamlined approach to using the nano suit so the gameplay remains fast, intense and versatile. The multiplayer component, however, can be summed up as a Call of Duty-styled system with the only differential being the nano suit and its level-induced upgrades.

												I coudn't make a new online account, and based on other reviews assumed its broken as well as multiplayer. So this review is only of the singleplayer campaign.In my opinion, this game is not worth the full price. Story took about 7 hours at a normal pace, and really wasn't all too engaging. As far as gameplay, I am 99% certain it is locked at 30 fps which was a downer, but I suppose you don't notice it too much in the middle of a fight. There is a good mix of environments and enemies, although towards the end it does get somewhat repetitive. Luckily you have a few different options for going about combat with your suit ablities (invisibility, armor ect.). There are a few bigger alien "bosses" that will be thrown in here and there, and really aren't too hard to get past. Visually the game looks awesome, and there is a good pace of changing environments.So with the rather short campaign, somewhat cliche story and locked fps, I woudn't reccomend getting this game at full price. But if you can pick it up at a good discount, it is a very entertaing game for what it is and a very nice challenge. Watch some gameplay and see if the mechanics appeal to you, they really can get quite fun.

												Crysis 2 starts the same as Crysis 1 finished; muddled, confused and frustrating. It very often leaves you fighting for your life, without any clear idea as to what you are actually supposed to be doing. This is a fault that plagues the game at a number of different points. The game doesn't give that sense of freedom that was in 1, feeling much more constrained and scripted; much most like a console game, which of course it is. One thing I really dislike is the inability to save whenever you like. All you get is checkpoint saves. This means that a particularly tough section you may have to play and listen to all the commentary again and again and again...! Having said all that, it's still a very enjoyable game. It gathers pace as you play it, so stick at it for a while. It's a definite "must have" even though I still prefer Crysis 1.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												True to the CryEngine legacy Crysis 2 is visually a triumph but as a deep and immersive game it falls a little short. Not to say there isn't any enjoyment or fun to be had, it's just doesn't do anything that you could say was better than just good. For me this was due mostly to two main issues. A sparse/generic/confusing plot and mechanics that are at odds with each other.As far as the plot goes some of my qualms could come from not playing the original game. It's possible that the plethora of characters, that are used without much introduction, featured in the first installment. Most of your time is spent going to places to meet people who have to move for various reasons, forcing you to go to a different place to meet them in the next level. It just felt a little padded at times and a limited weapon set (or little incentive to use most of them) and not a lot of enemy variation fail to add any spice. Speaking in generalizations the plot is pretty typical alien invasion fare, with the biggest twist being your super suit which brings up my next issue.The main mechanical difference between the Crysis series and other FPS's is the super suit your character wears. The suit allows you to either cloak (invisibility) or armor (huge damage reduction) among other things like jumping higher, kicking large objects, and throwing most objects. The issue is that the two main suit modes are at odds which is really hard to design and balance as a dev. If you've played stealth games and military shooters then you'll know that level designs between the two are completely different. Things like enemy placement, difficulty and, numbers need to be different to deliver a great experience for either style. If you rush the suits stealth upgrade it almost completely breaks the game. With the fairly open levels, great for running and gunning in armor mode, you can essentially sneak past the rest of the game with ease which is pretty boring. Before the stealth upgrade I did have some tense stealth moments, an unaware enemy closing in on me in the open with just enough power to get to my next hiding spot but for the most part a silenced sniper rifle + cloaking = cake walk.After all that it may seem like you should avoid Crysis 2 at all costs but that really isn't the case. At full price it's a little hard to swallow but on sale it probably provides enough enjoyment and it certainly is good to look at. I have only played a little multiplayer but, with the exception of playing against over-leveled opponents, it was enjoyable and had variety.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												Solid first person shooter. It is very much a linear game which I have nothing against. On the second hardest difficulty the enemies are tough and do hurt you if you are not careful. Humans are laughably easy later on the game and offer no challenge at all. For me sneaking was the way to go. Sometimes I got bored and didn't kill enemies at all and just sneaked trough the levels. The shooting mechanics are basic, nothing wrong in them.Game had multiple assault rifles available. I think the first one you get was the best one. You get silencer, red dot sight and singleshot firing mode later on. That was my main weapon of choise. Second slot I filled with sniper-rifle, LMG or shotgun as I saw fit for the map. There were some special weapons also but I usually found no use for them. Gauss-rifle would have been nice to carry around but you get it so late in the game that there is little use for it.I didn't care about the plot that much. I found it stupid, a bit silly, full of cliches and offered no surprices for me.Visually the game looks very good. Especially when you think it is already five years old when I write this.I did not run into any serious bugs. I think it crashed on alt-tab couple of times, but that was partly my fault. I would not recommend anyone to pay 20€ for it, but if you get it on a sale certainly. If you like FPS-games, go for it.

content:
Posted: April 20
												The Original Crysis was an excellent adventure, full of tactical options, interesting (although simple) plot, and unique mechanics, all brought together by an amazing engine. Sadly, Crysis 2 seems to drop EVERY ball it was handed.The plot is almost non-existant, as if they wrote five minutes of story and dragged it out over eight hours. Half the game they don't even tell you what's going on. They put you in this super suit and just expect you to walk from point A to B for four hours, killing people who try to kill you.The tactical options are all there, but they shove them down your throat, telling you that there are new tactical options available every checkpoint, literally marking where you should stealth or snipe from effectively. It takes the decision making process out completely, and the whole game plays like a tutorial.Even the engine seems less impressive than the original game, with poor AI and meager graphics.I loved the first game, but this entry turned me off of the series entirely. Do yourself a favor, just enjoy the Original game, and steer clear of this mess.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's not a bad game but not at all stellar. Not as good as the first. The action is pretty good but it's far less open than the original, the UI is dumbed down with "go here" and "take this ammo" prompts doing all the hard work for you, and worst of all it's absolutely saturated with long, boring, dreadful, horribly written, unskippable cutscenes. Every few minutes without fail. You'll be begging to just play, slamming your ESC key and clicking madly, to no avail. You must endure every idiotic word of every utterly uninteresting cutscene every single time you play, and they are very frequent. Often you can't even control your camera - just take your hands off the controls and accept that you're watching a 3D rendered movie. It's for this reason that I decided not to buy any sequels and I advise you not to buy this one.Checkpoints with no quicksave, very low FOV, stupid collectibles like Statue of Liberty souveniers that you put in your pocket while saving the world - this is a console game in all the worst ways.Just replay Crysis 1. It's far more satisfying than this lame sequel.

												CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is a first-person shooter video game developed by Crytek, published by Electronic Arts and released in 2011 as CRYSIS 2 REGULAR EDITION before being later released as CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION in 2012. It is the sequel to CRYSIS aka CRYSIS 1.Set during the Great Depression of 2023, CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION focuses on Prophet, a nanosuit-wearing mute soldier from a poor family of tenant farmers driven from their Oklahoma home by drought, economic hardship, agricultural industry changes, and bank foreclosures forcing tenant farmers out of work. Due to his nearly hopeless situation, and in part because he was trapped in the alien invasion apocalypse, Prophet sets out for New York. Along with thousands of other generic gun-fodder soldiers, he sought jobs, land, dignity, big guns that can murder ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, and a future.CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is infrequently played in American high school and college literature classes due to its lack of historical context and nonexistent legacy, plus the fact it is a video game, not a book. A sequel, CRYSIS 3 MAXIMUMEST EDITION was released in 2013 to general lack of interest, but it's only on Origin, and who would want to use Origin? Nobody, that's who.Anyway, CRYSIS 2 MAXIMUM EDITION is not very good.

												While I wish my Crysis and Warhead games were on Steam instead of DVD so i could review those more publically, all we get is Crysis 2.Since I have not finished C3 I can only work any comparisons to C1 and WH. I know the tech is older, but guess what, C1 and WH are better than C2 in some ways.Now, while C2 starts out pretty awesome, because were I ever dying, that would be the only cool way to be saved, and it continues to build into the story and unknown environment with some nice suspense, as you proceed you will start to be dragged around a bit. This means you start by working your way into yourself, building prowess and skills, and get to making some friends. But then, your new pals start to tell you what to do, how to do it, when to do it, etc. Which is fine for a bit, "Sure I'll help you out, grab that latte, make a copy of that document...", but drags on in such a manor for a length of time that starts to get agggrevating. Am I not practically a superhuman? Can I not kick a car into your face from 20 yards? If you give the marine grunt spec-ops mentality a leeway, you can at least cover your lack of independence there. No worries though. Towards the end, you will still be told some things you need to do, but you will have more of a freelance, superhero feel gathered with your actions. And the only issue is the realization that someone has been able to know the dirty things you were thinking about that CIA vixen.*Notes:The custom 1912x1076 resolution some players needed for C1 and WH does not seem to be necessary for C2. If you have experience with C1 and WH, you likely had performance issues. This is the old poorly optimised engines. Crysis 2, even though a heavier engine, with better graphics, ran much better on my system. Which is exactly the same as it was when I completed C1 and WH.*Pros.Nice environments/Better graphics than C1 and WHGreat audio/SoundtrackLots of pointless collectiblesExcept for a point at the beginning in the city, ran much better than C1 and some better than WHMore viable/easy to work with Nanosuit, let's hope they didn't fubar NS 3.0 eh?Decent arsenal and modifications/easier to work with and accessDecent storylineCompletely different alien enemiesCons.More linear gameplay than C1 and WHSome suit upgrades are pointless, others ar used for less than 1 minuteWeapons dont seem quite as moddable as in C1 and WHPretty much no vehicle utility or availablility, a staple for C1 and WHMuch of the game you play a mindless drone, I mean a marine....Lots of pointless collectiblesNew suit setup requires more attention so you don't get ROFLStompedAt first the human enemies make sense, but as time passes, you begin to wonder why they are such ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to you, and you never really find out why. So you are required to assume its Epeen envyLess fun and challenging aliens, literally a pushover, if you get my meaning....Overall.A graphically enhanced, tighter gameplay, non-story-bridging game that provided me 21 hours of what I feel is time decently spent. Posted: February 22, 2015
												While I wish my Crysis and Warhead games were on Steam instead of DVD so i could review those more publically, all we get is Crysis 2.Since I have not finished C3 I can only work any comparisons to C1 and WH. I know the tech is older, but guess what, C1 and WH are better than C2 in some ways.Now, while C2 starts out pretty awesome, because were I ever dying, that would be the only cool way to be saved, and it continues to build into the story and unknown environment with some nice suspense, as you proceed you will start to be dragged around a bit. This means you start by working your way into yourself, building prowess and skills, and get to making some friends. But then, your new pals start to tell you what to do, how to do it, when to do it, etc. Which is fine for a bit, "Sure I'll help you out, grab that latte, make a copy of that document...", but drags on in such a manor for a length of time that starts to get agggrevating. Am I not practically a superhuman? Can I not kick a car into your face from 20 yards? If you give the marine grunt spec-ops mentality a leeway, you can at least cover your lack of independence there. No worries though. Towards the end, you will still be told some things you need to do, but you will have more of a freelance, superhero feel gathered with your actions. And the only issue is the realization that someone has been able to know the dirty things you were thinking about that CIA vixen.*Notes:The custom 1912x1076 resolution some players needed for C1 and WH does not seem to be necessary for C2. If you have experience with C1 and WH, you likely had performance issues. This is the old poorly optimised engines. Crysis 2, even though a heavier engine, with better graphics, ran much better on my system. Which is exactly the same as it was when I completed C1 and WH.*Pros.Nice environments/Better graphics than C1 and WHGreat audio/SoundtrackLots of pointless collectiblesExcept for a point at the beginning in the city, ran much better than C1 and some better than WHMore viable/easy to work with Nanosuit, let's hope they didn't fubar NS 3.0 eh?Decent arsenal and modifications/easier to work with and accessDecent storylineCompletely different alien enemiesCons.More linear gameplay than C1 and WHSome suit upgrades are pointless, others ar used for less than 1 minuteWeapons dont seem quite as moddable as in C1 and WHPretty much no vehicle utility or availablility, a staple for C1 and WHMuch of the game you play a mindless drone, I mean a marine....Lots of pointless collectiblesNew suit setup requires more attention so you don't get ROFLStompedAt first the human enemies make sense, but as time passes, you begin to wonder why they are such ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to you, and you never really find out why. So you are required to assume its Epeen envyLess fun and challenging aliens, literally a pushover, if you get my meaning....Overall.A graphically enhanced, tighter gameplay, non-story-bridging game that provided me 21 hours of what I feel is time decently spent. ConsolizationCrytek decides to address the consoles for its next chapter of Crysis, enriching its history but with the consequences of being designed to run on limited hardware.PROS:- Excellent artistic direction (although it was designed thinking on consoles, Crysis 2 boasts a spectacular design of the city of New York, enemies and characters).- Wonderful attention to detail (from the photos on posters of missing people in the disaster to the inside of a newsstand, Crytek's hand into this title is pretty evident).- Solid and immersive history (a new step forward in the narrative structure of the series, answering questions from the previous installments and paving the way towards the close of the trilogy).- Weapons arsenal quite varied and original.- Long Campaign (beyond collectibles scattered in the most remote corners of the maps and the relentless search for accessories for your equipment that may already increase your playtime).- Improved IA over previous titles (although there is the possibility that enemies can "stuck" in specific places of the maps).CONS:- Consolized (From the ridiculous FOV of the render of the weapon you hold, passing through the reduced level design and ending with the simplification of controls and gameplay elements).- Multiplayer support is discontinued (with the shutdown of GameSpy servers there is no active multiplayer... but, there are ways...)A solid game all around, especially in the artistic and narrative department. However, fans of the two previous installments probably be disappointed when they see how much the saga has been reduced, technologically speaking.My Score: 8/10Note: Played it on Microsoft Windows 7 Ultimate - 64 bits

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Crysis 2 Maximum Edition skip to Results and read from there.Crytek Studios Continues the series optimizing the interface and mixing up the story with its third extension to the Crysis experience. Crysis 2 Maximum Edition is a great example of a first person shooter that mixes up traditional style FPS with amazing dynamics. Story:Crysis 2 Maximum Edition starts off with a group of marines in flight to New York City in order to support military operations against alien invaders. The mission goes horribly wrong as submarine is blaster out of the water almost immediately leaving the entire crew marooned without communications; yet, it’s shortly lived because as soon as the crew emerges all but one are destroyed by an alien aircraft. It is up to you Alcatraz (a name they chose for obvious reasons) to continue on with a mission handed down to you as a legacy. You must push through the bowels of New York City fighting against humans and aliens alike in order to succeed! With the Nano Suit there is nothing that can truly stand in your way.Campaign:Crysis 2 is a relatively long campaign depending on your gameplay style and difficulty preferences. The game has a mediocre difficulty curve at best making the hardest game mode relatively easy for a seasoned gamer. Regardless if you decide for a slower paced game knock the difficulty up to Post-Human Warrior otherwise take a lower difficulty and just enjoy the ride. The campaign has an amazing depth in the level varieties and methods of completion. There are about eighteen levels which vary in how you can play them as well as the various opponents, options, and surprises within; although, there are actually only a few different enemies the way they are mixed and how they are placed make them seem like new posing challenges every step of the way. The game is played with a combination of sequences where you are either alone in the dark or surrounded by marine allies. Overall the campaign is relatively fun and definitely has high replay value due to the dynamics of the gameplay. Gameplay:The controls are relatively simple which makes this game easy and entertaining to play. There were no points during the game where I was annoyed with gameplay elements, such as camera angles or controls. Hiding behind cover is very useful as you can pop over without having to stand up simply by using your sights. Unlike in the first Crysis there are really only two suit modes: Armor and Stealth. Power takes up both strength and speed and activates automatically when you hold space to jump or shift to run. This makes those abilities a lot more useful as I noticed in the first Crysis I never used super strength or speed just because of how inconvenient it was to switch mid battle then switch back. Just like the original there are loads of customizations for each weapon, but they’ve pushed it even further offering way more weapon choices and tons of different gameplay strategies; although I didn’t grab them all I believe there are about 20 weapons ranging from pistols, assault rifles, light machine guns, rockets, sniper rifles, explosives, and more. So depending on your gameplay you can either sneak with stealth and use silenced weapons or run and gun with light machine guns and armor. One of the major additions to Crysis 2 is the Nano Suit upgrades which allow you to optimize the suit and enhance your gameplay strengths. There are four different brackets which each contain three upgrades, but you can only have one active in each slot meaning if you buy all three for Armor you can only use one of the upgrades at a time. Hints:>Save up for the highest level upgrades, they are the only ones you’ll really need and they make a huge difference in your strength. The maximum armor upgrade costs 12,000 and the maximum stealth costs 10,000.>Make sure you run over enemy aliens after defeating them in order to collect the nano points needed for suit upgrades. Heavy Ceph Devastators give 500 nano points, but if you don’t run over them shortly after killing them the spores disappear and you get nothing.  >The most expensive upgrade 16,000 is only used in the campaign at the very end where you fight four cloaked enemies. Be smart if you tag them with your binoculars you can track them anyway.>Any time you find a machine gun post you can rip off the heavy machine gun [HMG] and use it. It has 150 bullets and is incredibly powerful. I found myself using HMGs more than my regular weapons. >Unlike the first Crysis the Stealth in to kill and enemy and stealth out tactic doesn’t work as well. The enemies can see you if they are close while you are stealth. Results:Crysis 2 Maximum Edition was a fantastic game with loads of dynamics offering high replay value. If you are a fan of FPS this is a great game to buy and play. I honestly buy all my games at 75% off, but this would have been worth spending the whole $29.99 on, which is rare for me to say the least. One of the great things about Crysis is you can choose your play style, you can go in quietly and assassinate your enemies like Sam Fisher or you can run in like Space Marine and gun down your foes like hordes of orcs. The campaign has a large number of levels which provide a great experience.   Pros:+Loads of weapons to choose from with dynamic customizations: Grenade launchers, shotgun attachments, silencers, semi/full fire, red dot, reflex, sniper, laser attachment, and more. +Awesome levels which are semi-destructible; use an HMG to blast up a wall near an opponent in order to flank them out (does not apply to all walls).+Cool vehicles, although you don’t use them much the tank missions and the Humvees are a fun aspect of the game. +Awesome suit customization, take your suit and make it for your gameplay strategy by purchasing armor enhancement augmentations or optimizing your stealth. +Suit strength and speed are auto activated rather than require a special mode to use. +Loads of different levels which take you all over New York City taking you through buildings, underground, through streets, under water, or into parks. +Good enemy AI, unlike the first one where the enemies would let you stealth shoot one and then stealth and walk two steps to the left and repeat these ones are a bit smarter. They will detect you and even flank you if they are high enough in numbers. +Good story although I have a con about this as well the story is great and is highly intriguing. Cons:-Although I did enjoy the story my major con is how it doesn’t continue with the elements from Crysis, and Crysis Warhead. In fact it kind of transforms into something else, not necessarily worse but just different. In the original the enemies were robotic and manufacturing themselves through a facility on an uncharted island. Yet in Crysis 2 the enemies were organic and creating themselves from the living tissue of infected humans. This completely changes how the story even seems logical, in the first Crysis they were in hibernation deep underground while in this one it seems to be the same yet they are organic and sentient?-Checkpoints were few and far between at some points. This was more a nuisance than anything, there were points where you’d fight for about 20-30 minutes and then die on the last enemy before a checkpoint. Resetting you back thirty minutes earlier and making you go “ugh”.-Some checkpoints were triggered before cinematics, this meant if you died you were launched back prior to a cinematic and had to watch it again without being able to skip.-Apparently multiplayer does not work for this game – I personally don’t play multiplayer but if you do then this may be a deal breaker for you.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Despite recommending this game, my feedback is qualified: I cannot really put in words the disappointment I felt when, with the game's settings universally set to Ultra, the first reveal of the game (when you emerge from the warhouse that Prohphet shot himself in the head in) showed that I was playing a sequel that looked quite some distance worse than the groundbreaking original.I say this not because I'm a shallow graphics-♥♥♥♥♥, though of course I am to a certain extent, but because the immersion breaking consequences of a massive dropoff in technical achievement thoroughly robbed this experience of anything approaching the uber-ambitious gameplay - and the CURCIAL sense of wonder - of the original. Frankly, the buildings of NYC in this game look like they've been transplanted from a rushed-out-the-door licensed Spiderman game from the mid-00s, and how am I supposed to feel like a badass when the - let's admit it - utterly cheesball design of my character is the best looking part of a game that was spawned from a ground breakingly, heart achingly beautiful game?It goes beyond the graphical achievements of the game, though. I understand that all of this downscaling was done as a result of the move to consoles, and I understand that by now I'm looking at a game that was scaled for the xbox 360 - there's no way it'll look anything like Metro 2033 Redux, for example - but I just cannot deny that the game is just less fun than the original was. In this game you basically move down linear coridoors - albiet city-street-sized coridoors - with the megerest of alternate routes threaded around them, whereas in the original (If you haven't guessed it now then I am indeed saying that Crysis should be bought immediately without delay if you haven't played it yet, certainly in preference to this game) one had what truly felt like a wide open island environment to cloak, drive, or blast your way around.Okay, so the game is uglier and more constricted than the game it was supposed to be a sequel to. So why have I recommended that you get it? Because it's a good shooter on it's own, and when sales time comes around it is going to be worth picking up. Put it on your wishlist and bide your time, you will get a good looking, tight shooter with tactical combat and a lot of fun additional gameplay tweaks, with a bit more character building (not story development, character building) than the original thrown in. Get it. If it's on sale.If you haven't played Crysis, do so immediately.
