content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I quite enjoyed my time with You Gotta Get Outta Here Simulator 2011, known in PAL territories as We're Outta Time Buy Me More Time 2.Here's the thing about this game,I didn't like it much when I first played it, on all but the highest setting, yeah you can do things how you like, but that means you hardly have to think at all, just gunning everyone down is a reasonable option as long as you stand in a corner.My second playthrough, however, I bumped up the difficulty to the highest, and that's when it became apparent to me how refined the gameplay really is.  You're forced to learn little tricks and make certain tradeoffs, you're made to choose precisely from which angle you want to initiate an attack.  It's really very well done, and much more refined than the original Crysis, which I believe to be overhyped on account of its eye candy.There are certainly cons though, so I'll list everything out here in bullets:PROS----------Beautiful graphics (if a little “smoky” at times)Adjustable FOV (thank god for that cause it's awful)Really smart, approachable, tactical gameplay (love)Optimised suit controls over the first gameReally optimised performance-wise over the first gameSmarter weapon customisation systemSuit upgrade system adds much-needed depthNewGame+  (more or less)CONS---------*Really* generic, boring, military characters*Really* generic, boring, military dialogue*Really* generic, boring, military soundtrack*Really* generic, boring, military cutscenesLots of weapons but still only two at a time (hate)16 suit upgrades but only 4 at a time (haaate)No useful unlocks of any kind from any difficulty completionCONCLUSION-----------------If you're into standard military shooters, you'll find something extra here, and doubtless have a good time.If not, you'll have to take time to understand the game's mechanics fully before you can really appreciate it, and have to sit through a *lot* of dumb, tough-guy talk, but it's still very possible to have a great time if you focus on the fantastic stealth gameplay.Crysis 1 - 8/10Crysis 2 - 8/10Crysis 3 - 7/10

Posted: October 20, 2014
												Crysis 2 is not a bad game, but falls short of its predecessors by a fairly large margin. It follows Crysis Warhead's level design - fairly wide but straightforward route to objectives intersected by large combat spaces plus some tighter sections thrown in - but fails to replicate it as effectively. The levels just aren't as well-designed or interesting as the previous games. Gameplay has also changed for the worse; The new nanosuit has a buffed armour mode and pemits stealth kills to better utilize stealth, but speed and strength are nerfed. This limits your options to mainly armour or cloak, and makes combat more dull, especially with the less noticeable physics, mostly absent ragdolling and more limited vehicle combat. I also preferred Crysis Warhead's interpretation of the alien enemies than the ones here. Nevertheless, the singleplayer campaign is still solid and enjoyable. Just don't expect something like the previous games.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Crysis 2 Maximum Edition skip to Results and read from there.Crytek Studios Continues the series optimizing the interface and mixing up the story with its third extension to the Crysis experience. Crysis 2 Maximum Edition is a great example of a first person shooter that mixes up traditional style FPS with amazing dynamics. Story:Crysis 2 Maximum Edition starts off with a group of marines in flight to New York City in order to support military operations against alien invaders. The mission goes horribly wrong as submarine is blaster out of the water almost immediately leaving the entire crew marooned without communications; yet, it’s shortly lived because as soon as the crew emerges all but one are destroyed by an alien aircraft. It is up to you Alcatraz (a name they chose for obvious reasons) to continue on with a mission handed down to you as a legacy. You must push through the bowels of New York City fighting against humans and aliens alike in order to succeed! With the Nano Suit there is nothing that can truly stand in your way.Campaign:Crysis 2 is a relatively long campaign depending on your gameplay style and difficulty preferences. The game has a mediocre difficulty curve at best making the hardest game mode relatively easy for a seasoned gamer. Regardless if you decide for a slower paced game knock the difficulty up to Post-Human Warrior otherwise take a lower difficulty and just enjoy the ride. The campaign has an amazing depth in the level varieties and methods of completion. There are about eighteen levels which vary in how you can play them as well as the various opponents, options, and surprises within; although, there are actually only a few different enemies the way they are mixed and how they are placed make them seem like new posing challenges every step of the way. The game is played with a combination of sequences where you are either alone in the dark or surrounded by marine allies. Overall the campaign is relatively fun and definitely has high replay value due to the dynamics of the gameplay. Gameplay:The controls are relatively simple which makes this game easy and entertaining to play. There were no points during the game where I was annoyed with gameplay elements, such as camera angles or controls. Hiding behind cover is very useful as you can pop over without having to stand up simply by using your sights. Unlike in the first Crysis there are really only two suit modes: Armor and Stealth. Power takes up both strength and speed and activates automatically when you hold space to jump or shift to run. This makes those abilities a lot more useful as I noticed in the first Crysis I never used super strength or speed just because of how inconvenient it was to switch mid battle then switch back. Just like the original there are loads of customizations for each weapon, but they’ve pushed it even further offering way more weapon choices and tons of different gameplay strategies; although I didn’t grab them all I believe there are about 20 weapons ranging from pistols, assault rifles, light machine guns, rockets, sniper rifles, explosives, and more. So depending on your gameplay you can either sneak with stealth and use silenced weapons or run and gun with light machine guns and armor. One of the major additions to Crysis 2 is the Nano Suit upgrades which allow you to optimize the suit and enhance your gameplay strengths. There are four different brackets which each contain three upgrades, but you can only have one active in each slot meaning if you buy all three for Armor you can only use one of the upgrades at a time. Hints:>Save up for the highest level upgrades, they are the only ones you’ll really need and they make a huge difference in your strength. The maximum armor upgrade costs 12,000 and the maximum stealth costs 10,000.>Make sure you run over enemy aliens after defeating them in order to collect the nano points needed for suit upgrades. Heavy Ceph Devastators give 500 nano points, but if you don’t run over them shortly after killing them the spores disappear and you get nothing.  >The most expensive upgrade 16,000 is only used in the campaign at the very end where you fight four cloaked enemies. Be smart if you tag them with your binoculars you can track them anyway.>Any time you find a machine gun post you can rip off the heavy machine gun [HMG] and use it. It has 150 bullets and is incredibly powerful. I found myself using HMGs more than my regular weapons. >Unlike the first Crysis the Stealth in to kill and enemy and stealth out tactic doesn’t work as well. The enemies can see you if they are close while you are stealth. Results:Crysis 2 Maximum Edition was a fantastic game with loads of dynamics offering high replay value. If you are a fan of FPS this is a great game to buy and play. I honestly buy all my games at 75% off, but this would have been worth spending the whole $29.99 on, which is rare for me to say the least. One of the great things about Crysis is you can choose your play style, you can go in quietly and assassinate your enemies like Sam Fisher or you can run in like Space Marine and gun down your foes like hordes of orcs. The campaign has a large number of levels which provide a great experience.   Pros:+Loads of weapons to choose from with dynamic customizations: Grenade launchers, shotgun attachments, silencers, semi/full fire, red dot, reflex, sniper, laser attachment, and more. +Awesome levels which are semi-destructible; use an HMG to blast up a wall near an opponent in order to flank them out (does not apply to all walls).+Cool vehicles, although you don’t use them much the tank missions and the Humvees are a fun aspect of the game. +Awesome suit customization, take your suit and make it for your gameplay strategy by purchasing armor enhancement augmentations or optimizing your stealth. +Suit strength and speed are auto activated rather than require a special mode to use. +Loads of different levels which take you all over New York City taking you through buildings, underground, through streets, under water, or into parks. +Good enemy AI, unlike the first one where the enemies would let you stealth shoot one and then stealth and walk two steps to the left and repeat these ones are a bit smarter. They will detect you and even flank you if they are high enough in numbers. +Good story although I have a con about this as well the story is great and is highly intriguing. Cons:-Although I did enjoy the story my major con is how it doesn’t continue with the elements from Crysis, and Crysis Warhead. In fact it kind of transforms into something else, not necessarily worse but just different. In the original the enemies were robotic and manufacturing themselves through a facility on an uncharted island. Yet in Crysis 2 the enemies were organic and creating themselves from the living tissue of infected humans. This completely changes how the story even seems logical, in the first Crysis they were in hibernation deep underground while in this one it seems to be the same yet they are organic and sentient?-Checkpoints were few and far between at some points. This was more a nuisance than anything, there were points where you’d fight for about 20-30 minutes and then die on the last enemy before a checkpoint. Resetting you back thirty minutes earlier and making you go “ugh”.-Some checkpoints were triggered before cinematics, this meant if you died you were launched back prior to a cinematic and had to watch it again without being able to skip.-Apparently multiplayer does not work for this game – I personally don’t play multiplayer but if you do then this may be a deal breaker for you.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Despite recommending this game, my feedback is qualified: I cannot really put in words the disappointment I felt when, with the game's settings universally set to Ultra, the first reveal of the game (when you emerge from the warhouse that Prohphet shot himself in the head in) showed that I was playing a sequel that looked quite some distance worse than the groundbreaking original.I say this not because I'm a shallow graphics-♥♥♥♥♥, though of course I am to a certain extent, but because the immersion breaking consequences of a massive dropoff in technical achievement thoroughly robbed this experience of anything approaching the uber-ambitious gameplay - and the CURCIAL sense of wonder - of the original. Frankly, the buildings of NYC in this game look like they've been transplanted from a rushed-out-the-door licensed Spiderman game from the mid-00s, and how am I supposed to feel like a badass when the - let's admit it - utterly cheesball design of my character is the best looking part of a game that was spawned from a ground breakingly, heart achingly beautiful game?It goes beyond the graphical achievements of the game, though. I understand that all of this downscaling was done as a result of the move to consoles, and I understand that by now I'm looking at a game that was scaled for the xbox 360 - there's no way it'll look anything like Metro 2033 Redux, for example - but I just cannot deny that the game is just less fun than the original was. In this game you basically move down linear coridoors - albiet city-street-sized coridoors - with the megerest of alternate routes threaded around them, whereas in the original (If you haven't guessed it now then I am indeed saying that Crysis should be bought immediately without delay if you haven't played it yet, certainly in preference to this game) one had what truly felt like a wide open island environment to cloak, drive, or blast your way around.Okay, so the game is uglier and more constricted than the game it was supposed to be a sequel to. So why have I recommended that you get it? Because it's a good shooter on it's own, and when sales time comes around it is going to be worth picking up. Put it on your wishlist and bide your time, you will get a good looking, tight shooter with tactical combat and a lot of fun additional gameplay tweaks, with a bit more character building (not story development, character building) than the original thrown in. Get it. If it's on sale.If you haven't played Crysis, do so immediately.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Oh dear... this is a bit of a mess...It looks stunning... of course it does... it's Crysis.The story is a confusing mess with some genius geek nerd guy mansplaining gobbledygook to you over the radio... after about 20 mins you won't care about the story.Gameplay is much the same as the first game and very satisfying when the game gives you the freedom to be inventive. New features and abilities are all well designed and make for a fun playing experience.The main problem with this game is the level design and it's desperate need to try and be cinematic.Level design wise, even with objective markers and all the help the HUD gave me I still ended up in dead end after dead end, trying to figure out where to go. At times the comms from the professor dude were just misleading and led to a lot of frustration. The battle in the lab against the chopper is a good example with the doc screaming at you to get out but actually there is no way out of the lab at that point.The games need to be cinematic is also really frustrating. The first half of the first game did a great job of giving you a really large play area to explore and be inventive with. Here you're just been led by the nose from one set piece to the next. It controls like the first Crysis, however, your nano suit has been casualized only to carry OP mode, stealth, binoculars which are only used as a waypoint system to find ammo, and nightvision, which is only viable to use in like freaking 3 parts of the whole game. Gotta have something to support that console controller! The checkpoint system WILL drive you nuts. It rarely logs down your progress on your map and just seem to live breathe its own life. If you get a CTD during a map, enjoy being thrown all the way back to the beginning of the map.Avoid this, even if you liked the first game. It's not a PC game, it's a quick money grab to make up for all the cash they didn't earn with their first game. I hope you got this through the cheap EA bundle like me. I feel bad for anyone actually getting this for full price.

												Crysis 2 is the linear sequel to an 'open world' Crysis, that became a more straightforward title. It was a promising title that fell short compared to its predecessor, ultimately failing to deliver an above-average experience beyond its next-gen appeal for its time.It's only recommendable buying when on discount, when all you want is an 8hr experience of cinematic action.Pros:+Great graphics.++Superb sound effects.++Well detailed environments.++Engaging gunplay.+Slightly interesting although predictable story.Cons:-Short Single Player.-Very much linear single player mode, go to point A to point B in a nutshell.--Poorly optimized engine, framerate drops.--Very glitchy and buggy. (Some alien stealth kills pop artifacts out of nowhere)--No multiplayer (it wasn't too bright anyway -- very little people played it after its first year of release).--Poorly implemented mechanics, ie. The Stealth detector upgrade (which is expensive) can be bought early enough in the game if you save enough to get it, however it is only useful in the near end of the campaign. -Very few enemy types and weapons.Overall it's not a bad game. Just lacking.

content:
Posted: February 7
Some opening scene spoilers, probably. I needed a rant following this experience.It's not all bad, but I'd look elsewhere first.I bought this game in a £3 humble bundle with Battlefield 3 a number of years ago. I bought the bundle to buy BF3 cheap. This and the other games I received just sat in my library until now.Even though I had installed it prior to 2017, I had never played it beyond the introductory cutscene. This time, January/February 2017, I decided I would complete it from start to finish. This was also the first Crysis game I had ever played. I had no idea what to expect, aside from the catchphrase reverberating in my head: 'But will it run Crysis?'My first problem with the game: cutscenes. Of the first 35 minutes of playing the game, from the moment I started a new campaign, only 3 minutes had been dedicated to moving around and exploring to any meaningful extent. The player is met with a rollercoaster ride of pixellated then gorgeous cutscenes, the ugly ones obviously down to the game's console past.It's not that that the game isn't beautiful enough. I mean, my favourite games are Delta Force: Black Hawk Down (2003) and Final Fantasy 8 (1999) and both look like Meatloaf's butt when compared to Crysis 2. The problem is that the player has to sit through the opening cutscene, then they get to press W and move the mouse a bit to swim through and navigate the virtual underwater equivalent of a disappointing chutes and ladders children's playground. After that, the player sits through another cutscene, before they are finally allowed to navigate the world.And even then, the player isn't trusted to make his own way and discover how his tools work. Instead of making the player watch the tutorial, the tutorial could at least have been skippable and made obviously so with a 'Press Esc to Skip' message.My second problem was related to performance. This game was released in 2011. I built my PC in 2015. It has an i7, a GTX 980 and 16gb DDR4 RAM. Aside from Early Access ARK and ARMA 3, where I struggled to play the game at 50-60fps (yes, yes, 144Hz monitor), I have never struggled with any game thrown at this computer. Those first three minutes of actual gameplay as the super soldier with the nanosuit felt as though I was a turtle marching through a field of peanut butter. The framerate was stuck at 100 indoors, and outdoors it hovered around the 70 mark. Even for the acceptable framerate of 100, the movement wasn't fluid and it took a while to get used to the sub-par performance.After the first 35 minutes, the game starts to get better. Yes, the player does have to sit through more lengthy cutscenes and yes, the player does have to endure occasional idiotic AI and scripted events in the form of friendly NPCs explaining life-and-death-level important things in elevators while the player is bouncing up and down, desperate to get out and shoot things. And yes, there's the storyline. It exists. It's alright but very idiotic at times.After about an hour and a half of gameplay, I grew tired of the framerate and adjusted the settings, lowering everything to 'HIGH', keeping the resolution at 1080p and finally playing around with the settings in the Nvidia Control Panel. The game looked marginally worse, but the smooth 250fps plus framerate was worth it.With the smooth framerate, the gameplay was much more enjoyable. If you've played any first person shooter, well, ever, you'll feel at home here. You get to shoot things, you get to jump high and you get to hear a big man with a deep voice breathe the words "cloak engaged" down your neck every time you don't fancy fighting a bunch of enemies.Final mention: The music was very promising to begin with. The main menu and opening theme are evocative and very powerful, but from then on, unless you catch a bit of the pause menu music every now and again, the rest is rather forgettable.---I can't imagine anyone would buy Crysis 2 Maximum Edition on steam for £20 or so. Especially when you consider the fate of the Multiplayer.Is Crysis 2 worth £20? Probably not.Is Crysis 2 worth £3 on a sale? Considering you could buy the likes of Deus Ex: Human Revolution for the same amount... Probably not.Is Crysis 2 worth £3 if you've played all other Triple A titles under the sun? Try an indie game, or go outside in the fresh air and buy an ice cream.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Well another story untold...That's the way it is game after game.  Game developers assume everyone plays for the blood and gore and not for anything else.I play for the story and the idea, that stuff they make all the cut scenes for, and I know I am not alone, but people know you can't get a game company to do anything but what's cheapest for them to do.  Stories require more work, more expense and are seen to be less profitable -- a short term view.  But, alas, I digress, for why should any gaming company be different than any other, right?  They should all be the same, have the same policy toward players, swap out PR people from one company to another, all use the same group of elitist beta and alpha testers, and, usually end up with them running the very forums they direct us to for support (Kinda explains why so many games are so identical in so many ways, and boring right?).  Yeah, game after game putting down "corporate interests" and "greed" done by company after company.... or more accurately "corporation after corporation," whose entire interest IS greed.  Game companies are one of, if not generally, the highest profit margin available, 20% or more due to most of what they're selling being automated integrations, and those figures have only gone up since the company doesn't have to even produce a box, disc, or pay for shipping to some box store and is now a downloaded, entirely electronic product.So, yeah, recruit mode in Crysis 2 is too difficult for me.  I want to see the game world, to enjoy, and not be frustrated by, getting there.  I find little enjoyment in not being able to save the game when I want to save it, instead of relying on checkpoints that assure when I die to have to go through again what I was already sweating to go through the first time with 3 meleeing aliens on me at once, only to die to another one later due to their extended melee range compared to mine (to keep that blood and gore challenge assumption thing going).So I dedicate this review to all the silent gamers who spend money on games they uninstall a couple days later (as I am going to do with Crysis 2) and have resigned themselves to not being able to change the gaming industry and its assumptions about players that defines "fun" as one type of game play to the exclusion of all others.The solution for me with Crysis 2 is to be able to have a slider to adjust the aliens, both in hp and damage. from 150, or even 200% down to 20%, that are available to me through the options menu and irrespective of each category of player level I picked from recruit to veteran (sure I can set it at the beginning of the campaign and these are locked values for everything above recruit).  This way I can play the game with the level of challenge that keeps it fun for me, the player, the person who paid for the game, the person the game is supposed to be designed for, instead of resenting every penny I spent on this due to the frustration of trying to reach the next area and failling over and over.  If this happened by my own error, that's fine, but instead it's by a legitimized form of bullying, where game designers cater to that aspect of the game and its players but no other.As I am sure Crysis 2, nor any iteration above it, will ever have what I've suggested so we who want to pay to buy a story (like buying a book) can enjoy the game, I urge anyone else who loves the graphics, loves the stories of games, and wants to give those who went to the trouble to design them, to code them, to produce them, their due, not to buy Crysis 2.I'm hoping to get Crysis 1 working and that maybe its balance is different, however, I can see that in Crysis 2 I won't be getting passed the part where I have to escort the Marines.  Too many enemy aliens that take 5 shots each to take down (and often more than one head shot with a sniper rifle).  Too much shaking ground when using a sniper rifle.  Too much "they know when you put the crosshairs on em" when my suit doesn't have that innate feature and the aliens didn't have to kill me to earn being able to do that.  Though it is good to see that if I kill a boatload of them, and get to their bodies while fresh kills, I can enable that feature on my suit.  Yet my suit with its entirely inferior armor barely gets me through the first volley of 3 meleeing aliens.  Again, I am playing for the story, not harassment and to become intimately familiar with what it is like to be the scrawny new guy in the prison shower who dropped the soap.I've played computer games a long time (since the first mainfame text based Star Trek game that was coded in Fortran on punch cards), and have since picked games for the story not the elitism of epeenhood that appears to be the only thing game developers care about today (and mostly because it's cheap).To be sure Crysis 2 has great graphics, human AI could be better, story isn't too bad as far along as I am in it, but I'll never get to know the rest of the story due to being unable to go any further in the game.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												I really enjoyed this game, it was done very well. The graphics are superb, and it overall a very lifelike experience. As far as gameplay goes, the game changes as you move forward. The more dynamic style keeps things interesting for you. At first when you have no upgrades and such, it's more of a cover-based shooter. However, as the game moves on, mele combat becomes more of the way forward. A few missions later when you have more upgrades, you become more of a tank, and can just mow over a lot of the people (of course they are kind enough to give you a gigantic boss at that point). Moving to the end it turns in to a more stealth shooter. All of this keeps you interested, and it's really enjoyable all the way through. There isn't much of a story, everything that can go wrong, goes wrong; and every time something goes wrong, you have to battle more people. That's pretty standard, but the story isn't really the focus of the game, so it doesn't matter that much.TL;DR: It's awesome.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2013
												Let me start off by saying this is an epic first person shooter game, possibly one of the best I ever played.Weapons are very well balanced and each have their own uses depending on your style. It also, like the original, has a great variety in the ways you can fight, either by stealth with cloak or by tanking through enemies with armor mode, the campaign is also a decent length, so you won't be beating it inside a couple of hours, though I could hardly see spending a total of 24 hours trying to beat the campaign. Regardless, the game excells in both gameplay and visuals, so even if you're one of those people who absolutely has to have that detail, this has it.Now for the question, "does this game continue directly off of the first?". No, it does not, at least not at first. Near the end the events that occurred between 1 and 2 are explained pretty well, so while you'll be left in the dark at first, you will get much more information later in the game. Which may feel like a drawback to some players, but I saw little issue with it, it did, if nothing else, make it feel more interesting to find out what happened.As for the story. While the game has a pretty thought-out story, it doesn't really have the kind of story that makes you wish it were a movie or novel out in the store for you to read or watch, nor does it really pull you in too much, it's interesting, and definitely action-packed, but if the game's strongest point were it's story, this game would very easily be near the bottom of the charts.For graphics. The visuals of the game are incredibly well done, you'll definitely need some good hardware to run this, but nonetheless it's quite nice looking. Maybe not to the level of games such as Bioshock Infinite, or the latest addition to the series, Crysis 3, but thats understandable as both of those games are newer, while this is a couple of years old. Now, back to the weapons, throughout the game you will find an Assault Rifle, Pistol, Submachine Gun, Sniper Rifle, Shotgun, Rocket Launcher, and multiple other, more powerful weapons that I won't spoil for anyone reading my little review/recommendation. None of them overpowers the other, unlike the original where the assault rifle was vastly more powerful and useful than any of the other guns.As for the multiplayer, this game has an incredibly fun multiplayer that is definitely worth playing. Sadly, and surprisingly in my opinion, there are very few players online, so finding a room will be tough, finding a room that doesn't have latency is also difficult. Not worth buying if you're only in it for the multiplayer, but only due to a lack of players.Now, finally, a last question; "is the game better than the original?". Yes, this game, in my opinion, is by FAR superior to the original, despite the lack of being able to roam through a massive island, everything else is vastly improved upon, with many new things to enjoy.Overall, I would give this game a 9/10, on gameplay, a 10/10, on story, a 6/10, on multiplayer, a 3/10, on graphics, a 9/10, and finally, on entertainment and replay value, definitely a 10/10.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Pros:+ Stunning visual design that runs smooth and beautiful even on mid-range hardware (Crytek knows how to make a pretty engine)+ Combat is fast-paced, exciting, and fun+ Variety of weapons and suit-based powers only add to the range of combat experiences and play-styles+ AI is solidCons:- Story-line is mediocre- Slight difficulty spikes- "Open-world" is more smoke and mirrors than actually sincere- Managing suit-powers, energy levels, and engaging in combat can feel a little hectic for the control schemeThe Bottom LineFor me Crysis is a lot like Halo. While I'm not all that heavily invested in the franchise I still somewhow find myself buying and playing the games and continuing to do so despite coming away from each one with an overwhelming "meh" experience.Crysis 2 is a lot of fun, I'll give it that, but its story-line and universe is one that feels more tired and generic rather than unique. Much like the Call of Duty series post-Modern Warfare, "epic" setpieces and scripted events just can't breathe any kind of actual life into the game or its story and so at the end of the day Crysis 2 is simply a great looking alien-killing frag-fest. A great looking time waster that will probably be a once-and-done experience.7 nanosuits out of 10

												The plus side of this game, is that it's awesome. Graphics, sounds, action, and story are superb. I wish there was a little less action in places. It does get rather intense with full on action all the time. Not really a fully fledged grumble though coz I took breaks, and if you want to press on it's OK.There isn't much I can say that reviews haven't covered about the game, like it's in the city. I can add that it doesn't suffer for not being set in a lush tropical paradise. The graphics are handled superbly. I pondered about lots looking around and taking in scenery, often crouching to look at even the ground. I loved all the different coloured rocks and pebbles they put in streams, that exist in real life. It's still a real vacation experience. I have seen the odd complaint that it's possible to get through with little combat, and using stealth. Really though, why buy a shooter if you not going to fire your guns. The shooting action is epic too. You can go toe to toe with one standard enemy ground troop as you have better armour and better firepower. I read criticism of the new nano-suit, and I think this is unfounded. It's much smoother to access. Maximum armour actually does something. With upgrades you add on during the game, it gets better.All in all, a blockbuster from start to finish. Just maybe it could do with a little rest of easier gameplay once in a while.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is overall, a very fun experience. The storymode/campaign is absolutely AMAZING. For a extremely linear and restricted story, the options available for any simple combat task are always entertining. You can snipe off enemies, you can sneak around them, or you can put on your armor and blast your way through them. The combat system is a bit simple minded,  but it is beautifully balanced and you never feel "OP". The story is basic, but it is still pretty freakin cool. The only bad thing I can say about the campaign is its limited feel. Its short and restricted, but still one of the most fun 3 to 8 hours you can spend. 												The release of Crysis 2 was a mess on the PC. It was an obvious console port and the options had been maximum limited. This game was obviously meant to make console gamers crap their pants with Cryteks graphical technology. They had already made PC players crap their pants from Crysis 1 so now it was the console gamers turn. In this case the cryengine 3 got way more limited than cryengine 2. Which means worse graphics, less dynamic stuff and less destructible environments. Put Cryengine 2 on a console and it would blow up, so crytek had to tweak the engine to be less productive but still look great. This is a huge disappointment for PC players. Lets just face the fact, Crysis only got famous for its incredible graphics! Thats the main reason people bought it.The game itself is so linear and scripted its like youre playing a theater. You stand there on the stage looking like a fool while everybody around you (on the same stage) jump around and do their stuff from their manuscript and push you aside everytime you stand in their way. Thats how the whole game felt for me. You do your shooting in the most linear corridors and areas until you come to the next scripted event. You cant shoot, you cant talk, the game waits for you until you stand in the exact spot it want you to stand so it can continue. And the story is so abysmal i didnt even know the purpose of the whole thing. It felt like i was playing a cod campaign. Its just there for a reason so you can shoot stuff. And yeah it felt like a cod game with nanosuits. I played through the entire game just to see if at least the ending was any good but no i was wrong. No huge bossbattle just another scripted event with "push that button or you die". Man these developers have to realise that not everything cod does is good. Make something of your own for fick sake!I cant recommend this game to anyone except people who like to shoot alot.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Impressions & Score: Story: 9.5 out of 10The story in part II of Crysis has improved by a lot, although you do have a feeling that's copying Half-Life 2 on some aspects. There is a lot of work put into this new story, videos before every mission, information about characters and enemies, in-game cutscenes etc., most of the work is of good quality and there are some surprises throught the story, but not many. I liked how the aliens have been changed but at the same time I would have prefered to see a mix of old aliens and new ones, so that there's a logic why they changed aspect (they upgraded some of their units, etc.) otherwise you'll have the impression that there aren't the same as those from Crysis I, even though the story tries to tell you that they are. There are many captivating moments throught the story and I like the fact that it isn't too predictable, meaning that you won't know what will happen exactly. The end leaves room for many sequels to come, so be ready to continue buying Crysis.Graphics: 10 out of 10Crysis 2 continues it's legacy of excellent graphics that it started in 2007, improving on every aspect. The lights, weapon effects, character design, environments are all top notch, the only thing I'm dissapointed is the fact that they removed vehicule interiors, which were not only great in the first Crysis but gave more realism to the game. There are some bad graphics on certain objects, but you'll ignore them easily  when you evaluate the whole game. Crysis 2 graphics still manage to impress me and I'm playing this game in 2015, so that's why I gave it the maximum score.Gameplay: 8 out of 10Gameplay is great, many features added (ledge grab, power kick, combined nano powers etc.) but other were removed (vehicule interiors - which would have been great on the streets of New York, no flight vehicules, no boats, no tanks, no freezing effect etc.). Some removed features, I can understand, others not, since they would have made the gameplay better. Also, I've mentioned earlier the bug with some spawn locations, which can remove some realism from the game.  The good thing is that some of the features added work very well, in the ruined New York environment. Many players complained for the fact that the game became too linear, you don't have the freedom to roam around on huge map like in Crysis 1, but I understand the producers for making the game more linear, since many of the cool effects (buildings, bridges falling etc.) wouldn't have been possible on a  free-roam map, also the level of details wouldn't have been the same. Overall the gameplay is quite cool when combined with the great story.Audio: 10 out of 10The music in Crysis 2 is just awesome, especially the music in the menu, the other sound effects are also of high quality. How can I give it less than 10 when sometimes I was starting the game just to listen the music, I wasn't even playing. AI Behavior: 8.5 out of 10The AI is quite good, not awesome, but it handles itself pretty well. I've played the game on the max difficulty (Post-Human Warrior) and I didn't find the game too hard, the AI shoots very well but if you use corectly the nanosuit powers, you'll manage to finish each mission after just a few tries (you'll need a few, since the enemies are unpredictable).  The Human AI soldiers will try to flank you and use grenades, while the Aliens AI will jump on you, deactivate your suit and even cloak (at end of the game). The bad part is that sometimes the AI acts stupid, for example you kill an enemy AI on cloak right in front of his friends and they don't react at all, like nothing happened. Also sometimes the AI gets stucked behind certain boxes or in certain areas. Over 75 % of my kills were stealth kills (mostly with the knife), actually if you play on the max difficulty, most of your kills will be stealth also, since the enemy can kill you easily even with armor mode on. Still even after those bugs, the AI is quite good and dynamic, for which it deserves a good score.Multiplayer: not testedI've played this game during a month that I had no internet at all, so I couldn't actually test anything that involved multiplayer. But I've red that the suits powers are diminished considerably, in order to be able to kill other players faster, and not wander around in a stalemate. I'm not a multiplayer gamer, so I mostly prefer single-player campaigns, but I think that Crysis 2 would have deserved at least an 8 or a 9 for the multiplayer (mostly because of many removed features).Overall: 9.2 out 10The new Crysis 2, really improves on everything that the last one did except gameplay. I didn't gave the maximum score because I didn't liked the fact that they removed a lot of cool stuff from the previous Crysis, like a lot of vehicules and boats and other things. But even after this Crysis 2 definitely is worth the money, the story is very well done for a shooter, you'll spend many hours of good gameplay, the environments are awesome, the aliens are great, the audio is cool, what more can I say. I bought the game on a sale for less than 4 EUR, but if you don't want to wait for a sale, go and buy it right away cause it deserves full price.PS: Enemies in Crysis do have the same amount of health and deal the same amount of damage regardless of difficulty. Difficulty only affects their A.I.; i.e. reaction time, awareness, accuracy, and duration of burst fire.On the highest difficulty setting(Post-Human Warrior there's no split-second invincibility after you're hit, allowing you to be damaged by each consecutive bullet in a spray of automatic fire. As a result, you die a LOT faster against automatic fire when not in Armor Mode. In Armor Mode, however, your durability seems pretty much the same. Source: gamefaqs.com/Crysis 2 Weapons-Enemies GuideImportant: After finishing the game I only got 12 out 13 weapons attachments, which gave me a 99.76 % completion. I was a bit disappointed that I couldn't get 100 % completion and started to look online for tips. I found out that you actually cannot get the 13 weapons attachments because of a bug (they decided that ironsights isn't an attachment, but then they forget to update the list to contain 12 not 13) that the producers forgot to remove, so at least try to get at least 12 if you want to have the game completed 100 %.  	Obs: The only thing I dislike about the new Crysis 2 is the enemy predefined spawn locations, which are really annoying at first and predictable after that. Example: I have to destroy a fuel supply, after the fuel supply explodes, enemies start to spawn in predefined locations (some spawns are good, those when the enemy comes from outside the map, others are just awfull, like when the enemy spawn right in front of you, this removes some part of realism from the game). By the way, the AI is great, not very smart but dynamic, which makes every encounter different.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Basically a Call of Duty type game.  Blasting your way from inconsequential mission to another.  Not sure what the whole story is about as it didn't seem to matter.  I give it a "Yes" mostly because of the graphics, they were great.  I have good PC system so I like games that are made with really good graphics. I know lot of gamers say it’s the gameplay not the graphics that count, but I would disagree.  Its the same reason we go to see action movies like Avatar, Batman, Ironman, Spiderman, Captain America etc.  Those are all cartoon stories, with silly plots and even sillier characters if you think about it.  You go to these movies for only one reason; the mind blowing special effects. When you hear that an action movie cost around 150-200 million to make you know that you are in for a visual treat.Back to the game; another thing I liked about this fairly liner shooter is that you could fight the battles coming at it from different angles.  When you got killed, the approach to enter the battle was always the same, but you could try different tactics, i.e., gun your way through, hit and run, or hide and wait till they came to you.  I found that in most other linear shooters that if you didn't follow the strict "run and shoot" Call of Duty style that there was little other options.  Generally in other game I've played, you have to hit a certain point for the enemy to fight you and if you hide or try stealth, nothing happens till you come of hiding face them full on.  Often the game forces you into the open by one method or another such as lobbing grenades thrown by invisible enemies just to keep you in the open.  In this game I did a lot of hiding forcing them to look for me which actually worked very well and broke up the monotony of the constant skirmishes.  Actually I did a lot of hiding because I was always busy admiring the incredible rendering of buildings and the cityscape.  The detail was phenomenal.  I couldn't get enough of it.As for the Nano suit gimmick, half the time I forgot to turn it on.  It was nice to have those abilities of armour and stealth, when I remembered to use them.  There were lots of different weapons to choose from, although I generally like to choose a set of weapons and stick with them if I can throughout the game.  As for the shooting mechanics, I find that all FPS suffer from the same limitation; a sometimes inconsistency in weapon damage.   The same weapon can kill an enemy with a few shots or next time you use it need to empty the clip to do the same damage.   Fortunately this incosistancy was no different from any other game.The plot was confusing and to me didn't really matter.  The only game I ever played a game that had a decent plot was Metro 2033 and that's because it was based on the Russian novel of the same name.   That game followed that novel’s plot reasonably close so the story and game were much closer intertwined.  As for Crysis 2 you are being directed by one character or another and didn't really matter because regardless of the mission by the time you got close there was always one of those "by the way, I forgot to tell you this" scenario that stretched the game out.  For all I cared about the missions they could have been asking me to pick up a quart of milk at the 7-11 while I was on my way to whatever destination I was heading for.  As matter of fact it was kind of like that, sort of like "Hey Alcatraz, before you get here can you picked a quart of milk from 7-11".   Then when you got close it was like "Oh, sorry I forgot to tell there are some bullies hanging around the 7-11 that are going to try and take your money so you're gonna have to fight your way through them to get to the 7-11."In conclusion, even though the plot was meandering and gun play was getting very repetitious, it still allowed you explore different ways to attack and still get your objective done.  Of course as mentioned the graphics are amazing.  If you really take the time to look at all graphics you'll see that they spent a lot of money and time on this aspect of the game.  I wouldn't have been satisfied if I paid full price for this game but I got it on a Steam sale for around $10.00 and it was well worth the $10.00.

Posted: May 15, 2014
												First of all this is kind of a pointless to review such a game which is critically acclaimed by everyone (literally) and secondly, I have completed the game pretty late - considering the time of release of the game.But these being said, I feel that I should put my thoughts for this awe-inspiring game at least once.So, I have broken down my thought or review(so to speak) in sections -Story: The plot is very thick - though it may not have the emotional content that we can find in the popular CoD series of games. But still the plot compels  the player to stick to the game and hear out the different chatters between the NPCs. The link up with the 1st installment of this series is very smooth and "now it all make sense". Still I would have loved to have at-least a couple of side missions / sub-plots in the game (specially when these days when FPS leverage some of the RPG elements).Gameplay: Very smooth indeed; the keyboard configuration is very nice and also be dragged to the multiplayer games without changing much -  in fact I played the multiplayer with default keyboard and mouse config. The movements are very nice and the transitions between nano suit modes are seamless. You could just put on some strength just before shooting your sniper rifle and then just after the shot switch to cloak without any difficulty. Cut Scenes are very nicely played and well placedGraphics : well when you are talking about a game that uses Cry Engine 3 "Graphics" is the most spectacular feature that you wish to review. in words - STUNNING!! I have made a few in game snaps that I wish to keep forever. the horizon and the urban landscapes are too good and the NY city is realistically portrayed here. Since I used a bit older GTX 570 to play the game- I had to reduce a bit of the quality in order to get an optimum performance. Still, boy oh boy , you will feel that a new world is coming alive in front of your eyes.Multiplay - well the MP is really really good (once you get used to the pace and skills) and I earned a few badges there. Unfortunately I had to stop the MP cause it was interfering with my CS 1.6 skills (whatever I have left of it) cause their game mechanics are completely different..So in shorter words - I really liked that game - so much, that I played the campaign in 2 different difficulty modes. If you are looking for some FPS with gripping story and stunning graphics with smooth gameplay then be sure that you have this game in your library.And thanks to steam that I got it in much cheaper rate.- Maximum Game -

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Better than its predecessor and certainly more compatible with Windows 8 and 64 bit systems, Crysis 2 is proof that a game can never be too finished. The new functions of the HUD, namely the ability to tag objects, use thermal vision and navigate the environment in more inventive ways than before, all add a great new dimension to the Crysis universe. The setting of New York is very well recreated. The crisis of the aliens invasion is masterfully plotted and the introduction in which you and your squad members have to swim to saftey, only to be rendered unconscious by an unknown enemy, sets the stage for a compelling adventure. The  weapons are as modern, diverse and advanced as ever. They make you think that all soldiers of the future should adopt them. The AI is no pushover and will give you a run for your money. The physics of the various impacts are well researched, impressive and fun to see. You will find at least a handful of ways to take the enemy on and have a good laugh.Crytek  created a great followup in the form of Crysis 2. The extras also add extra replayability, so, if you have the means and love Crytek games, get this one. You won't be disappointed.

												Even though an untimely computer crash caused me not to be able to continue finishing the story mode, I have compiled a few thoughts about Crysis 2.This game is pretty. Crytek went to the pretty store, bought everything in it, sprinkled extra pretty on top, then put it on sale. The best word in the arsenal of the english language to discribe the graphics isstunning.Even with my admitedly aging PC rig, I managed to have a very consistent, and enjoyable single player experience at 1080p resolution.  If I had a kidney to spare, I'd sell it for a PC that can run this game in all of its visual splendor, yet with my also admitedly meager funds and some careful configuring, found the PC version more satisfying than the xbox 360's.The story and the in-game dialogue are a vast improvement over the first one, and the game itself sticks to tried and true FPS gameplay mechanics, without becoming tiresome. I was thoughly entertained from start to finish, and for the price of admission, hard to beat.I reccomend this game with a 3/5,and 3.5/5 on sale.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I've put this game aside for now only because of saves. Any game, particularly on PC should allow you to save at any moment in your progress. Crysis 2, however, takes you back to your last check point. This increasing trend is extremely frustrating at times, and in Crysis 2 - where you can spend a significant amount of time getting past enemies - it is even moreso. Perhaps when I'm done clearing my massive backlog, I'll come back to it. But at this point in my life I'm more interested in quality time and a good story, than a game that intends on penalizing me with time loss thanks to the lack of a simple save function. The story, is however, solid, and the graphics are beautiful. I'm somewhat disappointed by the lack of open world features, at least in comparison to the first Crysis, but it's understandable. Before it came out, I pictured being able to go into any building, or at least most buildings around you and exploring every location I could get into. That was a little unrealistic, I'll admit. Particularly when it was also a game designed with consoles in mind. I recommend it, if you're looking for a good time waster.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												When I started playing this game, I was enthralled. The first several levels are on par with games like Half-Life 2 and Bioshock, evoking a real sense of wonder and exploration. As you begin to explore, you slowly learn about what's going on. The game does a really good job keeping the tension at the start--the pacing is great. The basic premise is very generic, but it seems like a pretty interesting version at first. The experience of wandering the beseiged NYC alone looking for answers as an unlikely hero forced into an inhuman monster was great. I had to keep playing just to see what would happen next.Unfortunately, the plot quickly falls apart. After a few hours, all the mystery is lost, and it devolves into yet another "Heroic U.S. Military vs. Fictional Bad Guys" kind of game. You get shackled to some idiotic squadmates, and it's no longer about exploration and discovery, it's about following the orders that get shouted at you. Not a satisfying experience for me.Also, as I got further into the game, it started crashing more and more. I think I'm about 3/4 of the way through it, but every time I play, it crashes within an hour. And when i say "crash," I mean it freezes, messes up my video card drivers, quits big picture, and I have to♥♥♥♥♥♥around with ctrl-alt-delete for several minutes just to get back to normal. At this point, it's not worth the effort. Other Pros and Cons:+Controls are perfect+Graphics are quite impressive (mostly I was impressed that my computer could handle it)+Immersive (at first)+Good gun feel+It's fun watching New York get more and more ♥♥♥♥ed up over the course of the game+Gun customization is good+Nanosuit powers are cool+"Tactical options" are a nice addition+You can see your own legs+Some voice acting is pretty good-Most voice acting is pretty bad-Why even bother carrying bullets when you can kill anything with a couple of punches?-AI sucks-Stealth sucks (the enemies always know exactly where you are, and will start shooting immediately when you decloak)-Long loading times-Glitches

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												This is a console port.  I loved Crysis and Crysis Warhead, but this was like biting into a piece of poop.Crysis and Crysis Warhead put you into deceptively open environments.  It was linear, but allowed you freedom.  This was done fantastically.  You could run and jump around, and come at tasks from different angles and accomplish them in different ways.  You were changing armor modes and doing fun stuff the entire game.  Sneaking in, sneaking out.  Running in, grabbing a guy, running out, then throwing him off a cliff.  Sneaking in, taking over a machine gun, then switching to armor mode and using the gun.  There was flanking, stealth, open environments, vehicles, etc etc etc.  It was a truely great FPS.Crysis 2 is Crysis 1 with dumbed down graphics, dumbed down armor (you just use armor mode the entire game), infinite ammunition, no free roam environments, never an enemy 50 yards away, full body hitboxes (no headshots), stupid-as-♥♥♥♥ story line, and was clearly just a money grab.  It's like they took Crysis and said "Hey, how can we make the sequel the same as Call of Duty, but with the hitboxes of an RPG?"There are no decisions to be made.  You just trudge forward, blazing your gun the entire time in armor mode.  Enemies spawn like a Gauntlet game.  You kill one, and another identical one just pops out from the same location.  Each area has 5-20 guys that you kill like this.  The enemies aren't human, they're robots.  Because they explain that the aliens are all wearing suits like yours now.  So every fight is blasting into the enemy 50 or so times until it dies and is immediately replaced by its clone.Also, the AI got worse.  The enemy never works as a team.  I find it strange that they did this.  Maybe XBOX's processor couldn't handle the old AI?  I don't know.

												This game could've been so good. It could've gave the player a feeling of being a predator in the city jungle. Hunting it's prey down with the help of an awesome power suit that allows the wearer to move around unseen or even go into open combat to prove who can outlast the other with the help of the suits maximum armour. But no of course not. You feel more like a little ♥♥♥♥♥ who can't take much even in maximum armour. Or feeling like the invisible predator that hunts it's prey down? No. Your stealth is so short (even with the stealth and power upgrades) you'll stealth to kill one enemy then go behind a ♥♥♥♥ing wall to wait for your suit to recharge and then do that over and over. But wait the stealth system is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sometimes you could be standing in front of the enemy pop in and out of cloak and they seem to ♥♥♥♥ing stare at you like don't exist. What else is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about the stealth? The silencers for the guns. Here's how the silencer works for this game. If you shoot an enemy in the head with a silenced weapon and they die? Good job the enemy will not notice that. But if you attempt to shoot but miss with a silenced weapon? SUDDENLY THE ENTIRE ENEMY FORCE KNOWS YOUR EXACT LOCATION AND FLOCK TO YOUR♥♥♥♥♥AS IF A NEON SIGN WAS PLANTED ON TOP OF YOUR ♥♥♥♥ING HEAD. Small note about the AI for this game. I think they recycled similar coding from Crysis 1 for this game as well. Another thing that is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about this game is that the aliens a bunch of bullet/rocket/grenade/c4-sponge♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that soak up all your ammo. It ends up feeling like military in Crysis 2 give their soldiers ♥♥♥♥ing BB guns to fight the alien invasion. I had to use at least 5 ♥♥♥♥ing rockets to bring down the walker-type alien. Don't have rockets? Why don't you try walking up to it using your other explosives? Yeah you'll be ripped to shreds because your suit energy gets depleted by one of it's moves, basically rendering you dead.Also talking about the suit. Can someone tell me why a futuristic suit designed to for any situation. Doesn't have simple functions like I don't know A FLASH LIGHT or SIMPLE NIGHT VISION. Yeah that vision used to see in the dark in the game? IT'S CALLED HEAT VISION. Why the ♥♥♥♥ am I using it to see in the dark? Also when you run it uses up the suits energy. Sure that would've been alright if my running speed wasn't so ♥♥♥♥ing slow. I'm pretty sure the speed mode in Crysis 1 was at least 3 times faster than this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Speaking of energy usage. Did you know if you throw a flat pc monitor with "full force" using ALL the suits energy. It is thrown literally 2 metres away. WHAT KIND OF SUIT IS THIS? It allows me to tote a mounted machine gun around using ZERO energy but if I am to throw a small monitor 2 metres away I use ALL of the suits energy. A lot of things in this game can completely 100 to 0 your suit energy really easily. Things such as taking 1 rocket to the face but here's the catch that 1 rocket basically cuts through all your suit energy AND 99% of your health too so if an enemy just farts in my general direction I die. What else? If you want to break down a metal door = 100% energy. Even though you can clearly just break metal door bar with ease in a cutscene in right at the beginning of the game. Why can't he just ♥♥♥♥ing do that to all the doors? Break door handle, open door simple♥♥♥♥♥♥ Falling literally 8 metres with armour mode on = 100% energy. So you could imagine how long armour mode lasts in an actual fight.When I bought the game and looked at reviews online I really had high hopes for this game. I really didn't think it had so many horrible design decisions. That really disappointed me. I really wanted to look past these points but they just broke my immersion and my mind. Like seriously I think I can throw a flat screen monitor further without the suit and the door thing? I think can get through those doors with less effort without the suit.TL;DR Broke my immersion and expectations.

												*Sigh* What a disappointment. Let's keep this to the points. Crysis 2 is a bad game. Crysis 1 and Warhead are better and worth spending on. Why is Crysis 1 / Warhead better? Well, because it has the following:A semi-large open sandbox environment.Being able to go Prone (snake belly on the floor shuffle).Better control over Nanosuit abilities (able to activate strength mode, speed mode at will rather having it on by default)More ability to be stealthy and favour a silent approach.A whooole newww worllllld... a fantaaastic poiiiint of viiiiewwww. It was a new experience.Crysis 2 shoves you down a corridoor shooter under the pretense of being an open world sandbox environment. You are tricked into thinking it is, but it's not. It's a lie. The game features stupid setpieces, fixed cutscenes that no one cares about, a storyline as farfetched and uninteresting as it can be and a linear progression which renders you bored and tired.Yes, the visuals are amazing but the whole game experience is such a farce that I don't think it's worth you sitting through the whole title. Go play Crysis 1 and Warhead (expansion). Those are brilliant games. Very enjoyable. VERY. Avoid Crysis 2. Please. Crysis 3 is even worse than Crysis 2. Crytek don't know how to make games. Just expensive tech demos and benchmark tools which take up 20GB of your HDD / SDD and give you nothing in return but railroad boredom.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												A wonderful masterpiece that is well worth your time. Crysis 2 is a game that is a worthy successor to the massively acclaimed Crysis. With masterful graphics, and revamped gameplay, Crysis 2 is a work of art all on its own. With the included threat of the Ceph, the pesky Koreans from the last Crysis seem like baby toys, with high tech weaponry and deadly technology, you feel like you are a god among men when you are mowing these aliens down. But one of the largest changes that impressed me is how the nanosuit interface has changed. Crysis 2 has made the usage of the nanosuit a lot more user friendly, so instead of having to use your mouse wheel to select certain armor abilities in Crysis, you press key binds to use them, and in some cases they are used on their own without having to activate it. Like instead of selecting sprint to run super-fast, now regular sprint does that automatically for you, and to use your enhanced jumping, you just hold space instead of switching to strength then jumping. It makes the suit a lot more functional and easier to use. With an excellent story to continue the originally Crysis. I don’t feel it is worth the $30 price tag, but if you can find it on sale, this game is a wonderful game. Just make sure to play the original Crysis first, because a lot of the background story in the first in necessary to understand the story in Crysis 2.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Everything feels like it should be right with this game. You have stealth capabilities, armor, you can quickly change weapon mods on the fly, you can scan your surroundings and look for helpful things. You're a badass black ops nano super soldier dude, and it should be great. But it isn't. Nothing comes together right. I've played a lot of stealth games, and the stealth encounters in this game rarely work out right. People notice you from far away and then all hell breaks loose and all you really have to do is activate your armor, shoot at the bad guys for a few seconds and then hide to recharge your armor. You can go stealth again but it's all going to go back to chaos in the next minute anyway.And that's what the gun fights are like: chaos. It doesn't feel tactical or fun, enemies just seem to spawn out of nowhere, and you mow them down until the game decides to not spawn enemies for a while. Your choice of weapons are limited and there really isn't that big of a difference between them for the most part. You've got shooty rifle, fast shooty rifle, and far away shooty rifle. Also there's a shotgun and maybe a couple handguns. Who cares? They all feel equally unsatisfying to use.Then there's the tiny frustrations. The game showing an objective on the roof, and so you walk to the stairwell door and you press F to open. It doesn't. OK I'll melee it open. Doesn't budge. Maybe it's locked I'll power kick it because I'm in a ♥♥♥♥ing super suit. Nope, the door's content to just stay closed. Apparently in this game you don't use doors. Doors just really aren't a thing. Turns out I was actually supposed to jump out the window. Which is fitting because that's what I felt like doing anyway.Then at the very beginning after a ten minute intro you finally get to play. So I'm walking around and I see it let's me activate a laptop, so I do and a recording starts playing. It's a discussion that reveals some backstory, so I go on my way and walk up the steps, but the sound of the recording fades. What? In the first minute of gameplay you're going to tether me to a single room where I can do nothing but listen to a recording that I don't know how long it is? And if I leave, I miss the backstory. Stupid stupid stupid stupid.And then there's was a, not a cutscene because it didn't cut, but a live scene I guess? Where you can walk around while another character is talking? One of those, and during this scene the other character is like "here look on this screen at all this exposition about the story" but I couldn't walk past his couch to look at the screen directly. There was just an arbitrary invisible wall keeping me from going over there. And then the bad guys attack the apartment and my gun pops up like I should be able to use it, and there's a objective telling me to kill the bad guys, but it won't let me shoot out the window at the like five snipers across the way! I'm mashing the fire button but nothing's happening! No, the game doesn't want me to fight there. It wants me to go out into the hallway and fight through the building. Nothing about this is good.I'm sick and tired of games sticking me in a room where all I can do is listen to a guy who's showing me♥♥♥♥♥♥on another screen telling me the story. This is the opposite of the one of the fundamentals of storytelling which is "show don't tell."If you buy this game, you're in for disappointment, because it looks like it's going to be so fun, but it just fails at every turn. Don't waste your time.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												With Crysis 2, the series finally arrived where it was always meant to be. Crysis 2 is the equivalent of the loud, obnoxious blockbuster movie dazzling the audience with its fancy effects. Hell, they even got Hans Zimmer to do the soundtrack.That being said, despite cutting down a lot on the open world aspect, Crysis 2 is probably a better game than the original. At least this one has something resembling proper pacing. The game does a far better job alternating between quiet moments, full-on shootouts and everything in-between. It also throws the player into a couple of memorable scenarios instead of making him infiltrate the same military base over and over again. The gunplay is also improved as it finally has some weight to it and the recoil doesn't seem that random anymore.However, not all areas have been improved upon. The enemy design, for instance, is actually a step back since you're mostly fighting aliens who look like oversized (human) grunts with squishy heads - the predecessor's design definitely looked and felt more 'alien'. The story is still completely irrelevant and only serves as an excuse to drag the player through different setpieces. And yet, the game feels the need pester you with radio chatter and cutscenes regularly even though it neither cares about the characters it introduces nor the story it was supposed to tell. Despite some improvements, Crysis 2 is still lackluster. Although I did enjoy some parts of the game and the scenery of a war-torn New York does have a certain draw to it, a first person shooter that features subpar gunplay is simply not that enjoyable. It doesn't help that the opportunities to use various suit powers have been drastically reduced.Even if it fails at everything else, the game is a competent benchmark to torture your GPU with.

												Great game, wonderful graphics, my i3, 4gb mem and gtx750ti card, ran everything at max with no problems. The story is good. the action intense and fun. One is that you have to complete each sometimes quite longish sections before the game saves, which in my case means playing them many times, which is annoying, also if I must stop for any reason, I lose all that hard earned progress, even a limited number of free saves would be more PC freindly. Based on these cheats being available, I purchased Crysis 2 and found to my dismay and unlike the first crysis, the cheats have been blocked on the single player? On multiplayer, sure that makes sense, but blocking single player games will lose them sales and unless this is fixed for the next one, I won't be buying it. Posted: December 20, 2016
												The original Crysis blew minds in 2007 with incredible graphics and freedom of gameplay. Unfortunately, Crysis 2 can't say the same. From the very onset, this sadly feels like a generic shooter with a convoluted plot and predictable enemies. The nanosuit adds some (arguably unnecessary) upgrade and customization opportunities, but it doesn't make you feel as superhuman as the version in Crysis 1. If you can pick up Crysis 2 for a couple of bucks on sale, it'll give you about 8 hours of mindless shooter fun. However, given the short length of the campaign and no more multiplayer support I can't recommend it otherwise.

content:

												Pros:It's prettyInteresting mechanicsNeat upgrade systemCons:Boring story and gameplayTerrible enemy design and AITerrible ally design and dialogueThis game was basically created to demo the Cryengine. Not many games even run Cryengine. But that's not really the point. "Can it run Crysis" was a thing for a while, but no one should bother in the first place. If a game looks awful but runs, and is enjoyable, then it's a game you should play. Crysis 2 is pretty, runs on my machine, but is a chore to play.The game is dry and overcomplicated, and the enemies have too much health. You can sit in front of an enemy dumping bullets into them for 20 seconds while in armored mode and they might die. I tried to finish this game, I really did. But between being unenthused by the story and just outright hating the weirdly difficult* gameplay, I had to stop.* The gameplay isn't mentally difficult, but the enemies can take hundreds of shots without dying, and you having an extremely limited supply of ammo and energy.Also the graphics settings start at "High". There are 4 levels. That's just ridiculous. You're not cool, Crytek.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												A real piece-of-stinking-crap-game that should be offensive to anyone of average or above intelligence. It starts with an absurdly long cutscene that doesn't bring any useful information to the player except that the developers believe that big explosions and shiny graphics will make you interested in this turd of a game. It's broken up by masked cutscenes in the actual engine where you are able to look around, as if they think you're stupid enough that this miniscule form of interactivity would make you feel less like you're watching a dumb action movie about big explosions. And it just keeps dragging on to the point where I started feeling like the purpose was to bore you to death.What follows is probably the worst case of constricting hand-holding I've ever seen. They constantly take the control away from the player in order to ensure you don't miss their "super cool and awesome scripted events". As with the interactive cutscenes they make you unable to move, you cannot continue playing until you do what the game prompts you to. By the time I was about to start in on the actual gameplay I was so frustrated at the game that I could not bare to continue. It took some 20 minutes to get that far, 20 minutes which were so poor on actual useful information that it could easily have been cut down to about two minutes, with some time left for filler explosions to make you realise how cool of a game the developers think they've created. Poor game design all over. Absolute garbage. The end.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												No,  I can tell you why you should NOT play this game.  1. Crap map design. Namely, inconsistency, and no small amount of confusing layout.  This game constantly breaks accepted conventions of FPS.   Doors or ramps that look like they're the way in, but they're not - hah, Trolled!   Some items you can climb over, or into, yet others, which look indentical, you cannot, for no good apparent reason.  This even applies to the weapons: A missile launcher that looks like it's laser guided (ala Half Life) , but guess what?  It's not.  Oops, too bad, you thought you could guide it, now you're dead. Time to start over from where you were 20 minutes ago.At the end of one level, you enter the alien spire, the goal says to destroy it but if you enter the little tunnel with spores your health plummets to near nothing.. afraid to die and be forced to play the level all over again, I felt stuck, I threw in all my grenades.. finally I just charged in, and apparently I was supposed to lose health and do that all along.  No clue was given. Like I said, the game is confusing and inconsistent.Oh, and game companies, when are you going to learn that no one wants the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ useless pistol to start with?  Screw the wimpy weapons, they're not fun.  Just stop already.  That's the ONE freaking convention they decided to stick with?? WHy does everyone do this?? What's the point of a near useless item that packs no punch?3. Constantly moving the goalposts and objectives.   "Prophet, I need you here".. you get there,  "Oh, I need you over there now, nevermind". Early on in the game, this happens far too much, Gould is a idiot.4. Checkpoints too far between.  I battled for 25 minutes, killed a dozen Ceph, finally bought the suit mod I was saving up for.. got into an ARMORED vehicle (turret), took out the main heavy with it.. then got killed with a single missile that came from freaking nowhere. Was I supposed to get out of the turret at that point? Who knows? Confusion. Yeah, that's fun, having everything you just accomplished erased and  having to do that all over again, no warning.5.  Buggy as HELL.  The first time you drive a tank,  through an underpass, there are two red enemy tanks to meet you.  They couldn't be killed. Even after one exploded, it apparently respawned in place because suddenly it fired more missiles while I was working on the other thank, and killed me.  This happened a number of times..   After the 20th attempt, my tank got stuck in the ground and I couldn't even move.  Quitting the game and reloading fixed it, then I killed them on the first try. 6. Why the hell does the sniper rifle drain the suit of energy ??  How is that even related? Seriously. 7. Speaking of weapons, the selection system is shiite.  Why couldn't they just stick with the normal 1,2,3,4 convention, and MORE IMPORTANTLY allow you to add secondary custom key bindings?  The graphics are very nice, the story interesting, but somebody got SO much wrong with this game. You want a good game?  Play Dishonored, they got it right.
