content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Oh my god, I just finished it.It was absolutely hilarious. Cheezy voice acting, hopeless enemy AI, writing that wouldn't happen outside of this and children cartoons, funny prerendered cutscenes, suit talking to you to get yo'♥♥♥♥♥up. The only thing that was not funny is that I wasted my SSD's write cycles for this POS.You see, you play the first Crysis, then Warhead, masterpieces of PC gaming. Beautiful and a pretty good game too. They were called gameplay-less benchmarks back in the day by some people, but I think it's only because they couldn't run it back then, wanted to justify that they couldn't play it. But you got a huge area to explore and think your plan through. And different playstyles were readily available under your middle mouse button. The atmosphere was pretty neat and all that. I mean, whoever played it, will know what I'm talking about - and I will stop here, as this review is not about the first Crysis, but the second one.What do we get, when we first start up? OK, we're a soldier, then the guy in a suit gives us the suit and then shoots himself. Fine, I guess. Something about viri and aliens. Then we run around killing some soldiers because we can't speak, hear some scientist-type guy to get to him and then get to his exgf's apartment (WAIT A MINUTE YOU'RE NOT PROPHET - well no♥♥♥♥♥♥I'm no prophet, ♥♥♥♥♥), then we meet some other guy, then we get betrayed, then our betrayers get betrayed, and we of course almost-die-but-something! lots of times here - this deus ex machina guy must've been busy. Also your suit. Your suit is the answer. You get some♥♥♥♥♥♥from the aliens and there are some funny cutscenes showing some octopi-like alien viri and you kinda hope that when you get that enabler or maybe when you get to another alien structure thingy you'll get some super powers, but let me spoil that for you - no. It sounds convoluted, and I wrote it like that just to give the feeling that this♥♥♥♥♥♥is complex. But it's not Metal Gear type of complex, but needlessly complex. EA was trying way too hard to give you motivation to run around linear corridors and get teleported on each prerendered cutscene with a guy talking in the background. The effect was exactly opposite. I couldn't care less about your laughable plot I just wanted to go through that painful experience, hoping that it would retribute itself later, in the end - just like first Crysis changed its pace a little when you met aliens and gave us the pretty neat zero-g level. No. I mean, first Crysis' writing was pretty bad (lol north koreans lol aliens), but this hit a new record. I'm not sure if I can find a triple-A game with similar level of writing.Enemies are bullet sponges, and I played on normal. That's all I have to say. The CELL guys take way too many shots before finally laying down. The aliens are killed much quicker when you run to them, press V four times, and get their♥♥♥♥♥♥But you know what's more interesting? That you don't really have to fight. There are very few objectives that say to hold your ground and kill every alien we spawned, but besides that, you can run through the map easily. Sometimes they spawn too many aliens and you kinda have to kill them, but then you just shoot until you get health critical, enable armor, regenerate health, disable armor, run again. Or stealth. You can disappear in front of them and they won't try looking for you, just shoot where you were last seen. And then proceed to the objective. Even if you didn't cloak, just ran past them, they still won't run after you, or try to make an ambush or anything. It's a perfect game for pacifists - there's only one human person you have to kill.No interaction with the world. You can't kill that scientist nerd, they were too lazy to add a game-over from that. No physics puzzles. Just running. Pretty close to a Mirror's Edge 2, but that one was released already officially.I'm glad I got this in a humble bundle a long time ago. I even had more fun with FEAR 3, which I kinda regret paying three dollars for. That's saying something. Stay the hell away. Get the first Crysis, that was a really good game, but this? Just don't even think about it.

But you got a huge area to explore and think your plan through. And different playstyles were readily available under your middle mouse button. The atmosphere was pretty neat and all that. I mean, whoever played it, will know what I'm talking about - and I will stop here, as this review is not about the first Crysis, but the second one.What do we get, when we first start up? OK, we're a soldier, then the guy in a suit gives us the suit and then shoots himself. Fine, I guess. Something about viri and aliens. Then we run around killing some soldiers because we can't speak, hear some scientist-type guy to get to him and then get to his exgf's apartment (WAIT A MINUTE YOU'RE NOT PROPHET - well no♥♥♥♥♥♥I'm no prophet, ♥♥♥♥♥), then we meet some other guy, then we get betrayed, then our betrayers get betrayed, and we of course almost-die-but-something! lots of times here - this deus ex machina guy must've been busy. Also your suit. Your suit is the answer. You get some♥♥♥♥♥♥from the aliens and there are some funny cutscenes showing some octopi-like alien viri and you kinda hope that when you get that enabler or maybe when you get to another alien structure thingy you'll get some super powers, but let me spoil that for you - no. It sounds convoluted, and I wrote it like that just to give the feeling that this♥♥♥♥♥♥is complex. But it's not Metal Gear type of complex, but needlessly complex. EA was trying way too hard to give you motivation to run around linear corridors and get teleported on each prerendered cutscene with a guy talking in the background. The effect was exactly opposite. I couldn't care less about your laughable plot I just wanted to go through that painful experience, hoping that it would retribute itself later, in the end - just like first Crysis changed its pace a little when you met aliens and gave us the pretty neat zero-g level. No. I mean, first Crysis' writing was pretty bad (lol north koreans lol aliens), but this hit a new record. I'm not sure if I can find a triple-A game with similar level of writing.Enemies are bullet sponges, and I played on normal. That's all I have to say. The CELL guys take way too many shots before finally laying down. The aliens are killed much quicker when you run to them, press V four times, and get their♥♥♥♥♥♥But you know what's more interesting? That you don't really have to fight. There are very few objectives that say to hold your ground and kill every alien we spawned, but besides that, you can run through the map easily. Sometimes they spawn too many aliens and you kinda have to kill them, but then you just shoot until you get health critical, enable armor, regenerate health, disable armor, run again. Or stealth. You can disappear in front of them and they won't try looking for you, just shoot where you were last seen. And then proceed to the objective. Even if you didn't cloak, just ran past them, they still won't run after you, or try to make an ambush or anything. It's a perfect game for pacifists - there's only one human person you have to kill.No interaction with the world. You can't kill that scientist nerd, they were too lazy to add a game-over from that. No physics puzzles. Just running. Pretty close to a Mirror's Edge 2, but that one was released already officially.I'm glad I got this in a humble bundle a long time ago. I even had more fun with FEAR 3, which I kinda regret paying three dollars for. That's saying something. Stay the hell away. Get the first Crysis, that was a really good game, but this? Just don't even think about it.

												I'll keep this short and sweet.Buy this game if you want to know if your computer is up to snuff. Yes it's released in 2011, but still can melt computers if everything is set to "ultra".The story is actually pathetic at best, the only reason why people love this game is because it's used as the best benchmark out there(well, crysis 3 at this point). The crysis game is a more or less a tech demo for the "cryengine", so yes, the story is really weak..You will play the game through once(about 8-9 hours worth). Then likely never touch it again, so buy this game when it's on sale.It's a multi-platformer, so don't excpect amazingly amazing graphics, but expect a very nice picture. But the likes of "watch dogs" and "far cry " will easily put this and crysis 3 to shame. So if you're looking for something serious to bench mark your system, look elsewhere.The game play is okay, clunky at best. You can use steal and not shoot a single bullet, but sometimes the game is so clunky that by being quiet, the game will some how manage to have you run into someone that will cause them to shoot you, in which case, just run for cover, let your stuff regenerate, hit god mode...err...stealth and then walk out a free man.It really isn't a great game..Honestly, it's entertaining, but that's it..Gets boring quick.If you're looking for a "smart" FPS, get this. Posted: May 12, 2014
												The basic gameplay of Crysis 2 take very few risks. You can carry two weapons, two explosives, and a rocket launcher. The weapon variety is very limited - most of the guns function and feel the same, and some of them are such direct upgrades that the prior versions all but vanish from later levels. The only non-humanoid enemies are the boss-types, which only show up a few times. Aliens have both gained and suffered from this - they are less of a chore to fight than they were before, but this is as a direct result of them being more similar to the regular human enemies.A number of cues seem to have been taken from Call of Duty, Gears of War, etc. when it comes to other areas. Health is no longer shown as a bar on the HUD, but is instead represented by red splotches showing up on the sides of the screen. This is less precise and guaranteed to get in the way during critical moments by cutting off peripheral vision and blurring colors. The player can now lean out of cover by holding the right mouse button when near the edge of a barrier or wall, but the only way to find the sweet spot is by edging up against the corner until the prompt appears and risking a bullet in the arm.The Nanosuit's operation has been streamlined, and now feels less like a vehicle and more like a passive system. Only the Stealth and Armor modes can be manually selected; Speed and Strength have been merged into a new category, Power is now activated automatically when the player uses a corresponding action. With direct access to only two modes, the Nanosuit's operation is more intuitive, but also feels less rewarding to successfully use. Minor upgrades may be unlocked, but only a few have visible effects.Stealth mode hasn't changed much. Sneaking past enemies is still just as easy, and the majority of enemy AI is still lazy enough to simply shoot at the point at which you disappeared from sight. However, a few enemies are located at the other extreme, and have inexplicably impeccable aim no matter how visible you are.Armor mode also performs the same, transferring damage from health to energy. However, it has suffered from the changes to other systems. When active, hexagons appear on the corners of your screen. This meansit becomes nearly impossible to tell whether you have Armor mode active when you are close to death, because the screen's contrast drops and the red splotches cover most of the screen. Worse, this is usually when it is most critical to know if you have Armor mode active.Power mode is hard for me to get behind entirely. On the one hand, streamlining all of the extraneous suit functions into automatic actions makes for faster action and less micromanaging during combat. On the other hand, you can't sprint without suit battery left, and you throw items about as far as most regular people could. Furthermore, melee attacks are almost useless - it's far more effective to simply shoot the foe with whatever you have in your weapon.The binoculars have gotten an upgrade this time around, and now highlight many objects of interest through walls and floors. A small number of enemies may be tagged through the visor, which will let you see their locations even when not using them. It also has a new function called "Nanovision," which provides a thermal-esque color overlay pointing out enemies and objects of interest. However, it suffers from a short range, and drains the suit's batteries while in use.Level design has suffered. The developers have ditched the spacious, free-roaming environments of Crysis 1 in favor of much smaller areas. Although initially confusing, this decision actually meshes better with Crysis 2's gameplay than more open environments. Sprinting is slower, and vehicles are rarely placed in locations where they could be effectively used by you. Gone as well are the large turret and vehicle sections, which is only an improvement as far as I'm concerned. Additionally, most objectives are simply to reach a point behind a number of enemies, although this greatly incentivizes turning on cloak and walking past them all instead of dealing with them.Although not a masterpiece, the story does an effective job of both moving the plot forward and maintaining player interest. Unfortunately, most of the major players have only the bare minimum of characterization, and there are several gaping plot holes. That said, I rather enjoyed it, and the story and gameplay combined to keep me interested enough to continue playing without it feeling like a slog. Unfortunately, there were several scenes where player interaction suffered to make way for the story, which left me feeling like a non-participant in the game I'd paid money to play. A few well-done scenes, however, managed to hit the sweet spot between player interaction and storytelling where I felt involved in the character's situation, instead of left out of it.Crysis 2 suffers from a number of basic design problems. Doors are largely unopenable, except for some specific plot-necessary ones, which are usually similar to every other door in the room, and the player must check each one for a prompt. Hints given after death are almost never helpful, and after a while start feeling a little mocking. A quicktime event later on has nearly the exact same thing happen regardless of if you succeed or fail, except that if you fail it kills you. Some weapons take up one of your two slots, but can't be refilled from ammo crates, making them dead weight when they run out of ammo. Autosaves are located very far apart most of the time, meaning that dying could set you back a lot more than you might have expected.Despite being a AAA title, this game has a remarkable number of glitches, crashes, and sloppy mistakes. I've seen every type of enemy try to shoot me through walls, over and over. Possibly my favorite example of the sheer sloppiness of the AI in this game is the number of times I have seen a humanoid yell "FRAG OUT!" and then throw a grenade at the wall he's taking cover behind, only to ignore it as it bounces back, ticks down, and explodes, killing him.To summarize: is Crysis 2 a game you should play? Sure, if you already own it, or if a friend owns it and offers to let you play it. It is entertaining, despite its flaws. However, that isn't the real question I'm answering here: is Crysis 2 a game you should BUY? No. Crysis 2 brings very little to the table that cannot be found, and done better, in other games, for either the same price or cheaper. The game's primary mechanic, the Nanosuit, is interesting, but in the end, it doesn't stand out very much from the crowd, especially with the lengths it took to stand closer to titles like Call of Duty and Gears of War. The story is passable and gets the job done, but certainly nothing to write home about, especially with its large plot holes and how little characterization most of the characters get. Most of the weapons differ only superficially from each other, and the enemies differ even less. Crysis 2 is not the worst purchase you could make, but you could certainly do better.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Buy?Maybe=TL;DR=Crysis 2 - Maximum Edition is a solid, though largely unremarkable shooter that does it's fanbase a disservice by dropping the free roam and multi-optional gameplay from the original for a linear, Call of Duty like experience that obviously tries to hard to copy CoD, but never took much steam from the series and harmed the reputation of Crysis in the process. The game is fine for folks that like CoD campaigns and the Crysis theme. =Overview=Note: I completed this game in 10 hours within Origin. Steam probably shows no time for me. Crysis 2 - Maximum Edition is futuristic, modern military shooter set in the Crysis universe: which means it mostly involves gunplay, combat options, well detailed environments and use of the Nanosuit, which grants Supersoldier like ehancements to the average Marine. Unlike it's Crysis 1, Crysis 2 is even more linear due to a level design that shoves players down corridors and streets with little options for exploration and a game design that provides no incentive to customize your gameplay. It's essentially a Call of Duty campaign with a Crysis theme.=Presentation=It looks as good or better than most games of its time. The nanosuit is beautifully detailed as usual, and character models seem to look better when you can see them close. The Ceph look great up close and would make for some excellent real world figures. World textures are generally good, but not perfect - screens and signs look great, but wall textures look console quality. Physics act as expected and rarely I've had moments where an enemy body would hilariously fly off the screen without good reason or get stuck in geometry "Bethesda game style". I played this in Origin (don't remember why), sI couldn't get screenshots. Not that it mattered, as there were only a few times I wanted one, versus the 100+ times in Crysis 1.Sound design is as it should be. Combat sounds like guns, explosions, and melee have the expected punch that a AAA game should, though I don't specifically remember stuff like loud echoes in tight spaces or super loud bangs from sniper rifles and shotguns (which still sound good, but not so loud that you would need earmuffs or head gear in real life). The soundtrack is of great quality which should be considering much of it is composed by Hanz Zimmer, but beyond the main menu music, is good, but unmemorable. I do however really like the menu music, which really has that dramatic, epic, and dreadful feeling as seen from Modern Warfare 2.Voice acting is good, though you probably won't remember any voices beyond Prophet and the nanosuit. =Gameplay=The open world gameplay has been stripped down to a bog standard corridor shooter with occasional open spots with few options. While Crysis 1 was still a very linear game. it gave you options on how to approach "objective areas" well before you got to it, unless there was only one way into it. Now, you're following a path and then you reach the objective area in which you do have a few options, by taking a slightly alternate path to flank, creeping around to perform stealth kills (or not kill at all), finding a turret, vehicle, or explosive barrel to use against packs of enemies....Honestly, the combat options are actually equal to that of Crysis 1, but it generally feels that the best option is to take care of the biggest or nearby threats, and then hustle it to the objective, as it will eventually take you to the next area for you to skip the enemies. Stealth is effective, but it's much easier to use cloak to occasionally hide from enemies after combat or get the first shot on them.Considering that your upgrades all come from Nano Catalysts which drop from the Ceph enemies (which stupidly enough, disappear after a certain time. This aint the NES era!), there's no bonus or detriment to killing enemies a certain way - you may as well run and gun since the heavier enemies require explosives or heavy weaponry to take down. The upgrade system provides handy upgrades that slightly customizes your play, but nothing to dramatically change your playstyle - you could probably play the game successfully without even bothering with upgrades.The gunplay is solid, though nothing new. Guns feel good to use, especially the Feline Revolver, Heavy Machine Gun (which are pretty neat to dismount), and some of the later "Power weapons" like the L-Tag grenade launcher or the XFire. The use of abilities are more streamlined than the first game, so instead of switching modes to enable every action, the suit enhances you where it makes sense. Your speed mode is enabled the moment you run, super jump (holding the Jump key to jump higher than normal), and climb (your climbing speed can be upgraded). Strength mode engages when you melee, detach HMGs, or steady yourself with Shift to shoot more accurately - however, it can be enabled manually to reduce fall damage as well as the enchancements listed earlier. Armor mode and cloak however, are much like the previous game where they need to be activated and deactivated manually unless energy is depleted. However, Armor now does drain energy over time. While I miss the RPG-esque styling of the original, this does work better, but you have to be careful when sprinting around and armoring/cloaking behind cover - you will be looking at the energy bar alot. The function that allows you to toggle different suit modes is seriously less responsive and clunky. Before in Crysis 1, I could easily roll the mouse while holding the assigned mouse key to select a mode. Now in Crysis 2, that function is still partially there, but sometimes, the game doesn't recognize where your mouse is and doesn't register a selection, requring me to move my mouse alot to get to where I need. I believe this has to due with the fact of having the game ported to console systems, so the circle could probably recognize which "zone" the player pushed the stick. While I can just as easily use assigned keyboard keys, I preferred the radial mouse key menu.My biggest gripe about the game is it's clear "I want to be Call of Duty too!" Syndrome. Extremely linear game design, regularly scripted setpiece/cutscene moments, "slow walking can't use your gun while listening sequences", hunts for mostly pointless and tallied collectibles (there are keys for civilian vehicles, but you won't be driving much in this game. I entered a car maybe 6 times?), and on rails tank rides. Don't forget typical military jargon. I'm sure EA coerced the developers to make the game much like Call of Duty to compete with them. This means this game does pratically nothing unique for the genre or industry and made itself another CoD clone to get lost in the shuffle. You even have those typical satellite, wireframe debriefing overviews like every other modern military shooter does, but at least I personally like those. Multiplayer community is nearly dead with about 3-6 active servers. The little I played was a decent CoD clone, but I got kicked out of every server because the game couldn't verify DLC purchases, even though, i just put in the key to unlock the Maximum Edition  "DLC". Don't buy this for multiplayer. Like all games of this type these days, you can't use custom weapons and classes until after gaining XP.=Summary=Crysis 2 is a decent linear shooter, but you're not missing out on much. If you're a core shooter gamer, chances are that you're playing something or could be playing something else better anyways. If you were wanting more of Crysis 1, checkout it's modding community, or maybe even Crysis Warhead and Crysis 3 (I haven't played them yet). I can't recommend this to somebody who really values their time and doesn't want to waste it on anything but the best games - it mostly a standard modern military shooter.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												I've sunk a decent amount of time into both Crysis and Crysis 2, and I have to say I like them both equally, but for very different reasons.  Crysis was an amazing shooter, pure and simple, with it's huge open world and multiple, distinct combat modes.  Coming into Crysis 2, I expected more of the same.  Instead, I got something different, but not necessarily in a bad way.  The combat's been streamlined in this game, and what I mean by that is, the nanosuit's different modes are more integrated.  The only dedicated modes are Armor and Stealth, while Strength and Speed only activate while spriting, jumping, and using melee attacks.  The result is a much different feel that Crysis.  Rather than switching between specific combat modes, it feels more . . . more like a traditional shooter, I guess, with some special tricks thrown in.  Basically, your only two options when confronted with an enemy are A) use armor and try to tough out his attacks or B) use stealth and ambush him.  The level design is also more linear than Crysis, usually confined to a street, block, or square in NYC.  But while I didn't like combat as much as Crysis, I immensly enjoyed the story.  Can't say quite what intrigued me so much about it, but I'm a longtime fan of sci-fi and this really scratched that itch for me.  So, long story short, if you only play games for the combat experience you may not like this game as much as Crysis, but if you're like me and you enjoy a good story as much as the game itself you'll probably find Crysis 2 worth your while.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												I'm recommending this because it works. It's a functionable shooter, nicely optimized, looks very good(even in 2014) with some very obvious AAA features.That being said it's a really dumbed down game. Way back when in the confusing times of 2009-1012, a lot of games jumped ship to adopt a Call of Duty style gameplay, development and whatnot because of the cash cow Activision had turned that into. This is a perfect example of such a crime. Levels are heavily linear, "go here" objective markers, suit powers are streamlined into 2 seperate catagories with a "3rd" that's just there to have an excuse for sprint and higher jumping, a very superficial sci-fi story with memorable characters but no substance. Again, this isn't bad against the game, none of these features are actually detrimental to the game in any form and they all work as they should. But the creativity is long gone. Your approach to levels comes down to if you want to stealth or not. What comes out is a corridor shooter set in the streets of New York, with 2 sections that open up and make you wish the whole game was set in levels of the like.So in short, it works. The game is fine in that sense. As a sequel to Crysis? No, it's pretty inferior. But if you can get it cheap, get it.P.S. There have been some funky resolution issues with AMD users. For some reason this game tries to cap out at 24hz. It won't go into actual fullscreen. You can either force it borderless windowed mode, change your settings on your monitor to 50hz, or download some 3rd party fixes like RadeonPro.

Posted: August 18, 2014
												this wont be my longest review as to put it bluntly there inst really much in the game itself to review but okay here goes ...  so i was a big fan of the first Crysis game, was a ridiculously stunning piece of design with a solid frame work of story, mechanics and gameplay .. a model shooter for its time despite being generations ahead of other shooters of the day. saying this i was always going to be skeptical of a sequel as sequels are usually a bit rubbish. and to a degree this game both exceeded my expectations and at the same time failed to meet them. weird i know but it managed it.the game is  set years after the Lingshan island incident that saw the deaths of all but two members of Raptor team (Prophet and Psycho) new york is in the grip of a deadly virus infecting its citizens and the CELL corporation has stepped in to take control of the mess that has ensued. you take a step away from raptor squad in this game and play as a strong but silent (and i mean literally silent) marine named Alcatraz. you are sent on a recon mission to rescue a scientist when your submarine is hit by the CEPH aliens and all of your team is wiped out and you are left floating in the river until you are saved by prophet. prophet then places you into the suit to save your life and (SPOILERS) .. in short you must then progress the game as Alcatraz trying to save New York from the grips of the CEPH and CELL alike. now i like the story for this game i think its well written and well paced for a shooter .. its not the most imaginative story in the world but it appeals to me.the game itself is your standard shooter so don't expect much in terms of adventurous mechanics or gameplay. mechanics are to be expected as pretty solid .. you run jump, sprint,slide and ledge grab same as the last game with solid steel shooting mechanics (you shoot the guys and they die nothing overly adventurous really) some new toys in terms of suit upgrades allowing you to swap out nodes to allow for different approaches in combat which i quite like. you can swap out weapons with various attachments to suit stealth and various other aspects and play styles and with a wide variety of weapons available you can get quite adventurous in how you want to play out the situation. the mechanics for the powers hold nothing new in this game so i wouldn't get  your hopes up about that part. the little bits of tat you can collect throughout the game as well can be a bit annoying to find as Crytek were very imaginative in the hiding places. the energy bar can seem a bit stupid in terms of longevity to start with but you get used to being a bit more tactical with it after the first attempt to Rambo a group of enemies winds up with Alcatraz having more holes in him that a block of Swiss cheese. the graphics really are the main selling point of this game and they sell it very well. i played on the PC with a reasonably powerful machine and i like to think im quite demanding from my games but this game blew me away. the detail of the environment is not flawless but it is close to being so, the level of detail that Crytek have given this game takes it to a whole new level for the PC gamer especially on ultra settings. the Crytek engine allows for stunning visuals that make the world the player is experiencing all that more immersive. but excellent graphics do not make up for the shortfalls the game has in terms of the average story and the generic shooter gameplaythis is a game where i wish steam would have another recommendation button for i think its decent but not amazing, the story is good the gameplay is solid despite being a tad generic but the graphics do make up for this sin some way .. in the end i would recommend the game to fans of the series and FPS fans but if you are looking for a great sci-fi game with some depth then this inst the game for you.. this game is great ... but flawed ...

												Not that great of a successor to the original Crysis. The game shipped out with only dx9 capabilities, missing a dx11 patch, high res textures, and came with a badly optimized way of rendering water underneath the level thus requiring further resources than necessary for the level. The game is much more closed in level design than Crysis 1, so as to appeal to a more broad basic FPS market, and also ops for a mute, personality-less main character that you play as. While Cryengine 3 does look impressive, you can tell this was rushed in order to be released soon and to consoles. While some suit functions are nicely streamlined like running, and power punching, the drain rate on the suit and amount of enemies you encounter bring a rather pretty but somewhat boring FPS experience. Still, the soundtrack, modding support, graphics, gun recoil and level design is worth at least playing to see how you feel.Multiplayer is nothing to write home about and the running makes the game crawl to an incredible low pace.

GameplayFor most of the singleplayer you go around shooting faceless grunts who realistically fall and bleed all over the place, but the twist here is that you get a few superpowers to help you out. For some reason in the future the nanosuit recieves a downgrade from it's original 5 powers (now chaged to 3) but in return battery usage and visible UI have a few minor upgrades that keep it worth your time to use. The suit also has a new power where you get to play ghost hunter and use your thermal camera, and now the second you grab someone in the neck they die from shock or something (idk why grabbing people makes them die.) I would also like to say that gone are the free roaming jungles of Crysis because the devs thought making the areas as small and clausterfobic as possible would really please fans of the original (not add MSAA options is enough to displease the fanbase) but if you can get pass crysis 2 was marketed to CallofHaloFutureSoldiers it can be dismissed as EA's marketing flaws, BUT that does not stop crysis 2 from being freaking awesome and a blast to play and replay. I should probably also mention the collectable items throughout the level, but due to the linearity of the gameplay you'll either miss them right under your nose (erm facemask) or they'll be staring you right in the face with blinking lights around it saying PICK ME UP I'M USELESS! I would also like to mention that they broke the physics too. I'm serious they took something perfect and said naaaaaaa console players can't handle that, now, it's very rare to be able to throw enimies into each other.StoryThis is where I feel the game excels and also ruins my expectations. You play as a marine corps guy who isn't much for words who gets a suit from Eli Vanc- I mean Prophet, and you have to save the world because Prophet just wasn't good enough? Idk it's never really explained why he gives you the suit... and doesn't tell any of his friends about it... and you start killing people because they fired first. Oh, and a nerd named Gould keeps bothering you to hurry the hell up and get to him... because... I still don't know for sure why he called, but everything is pretty so I shouldn't care should I, and after that you murder more helpless victims until you start taking orders from some other guy, and he betrays you and you learn that anything with a human face is good while you should just pump as much lead into everyone else. That is, until you get to the leader of the blue clad suicide unit, and this is where I got a little mad. Spoiler: you kill him. Don't ask for answers or try to change him just let him swear at you until your magical touch of death kicks in and you get to throw him out a window. Yay... anyway aliens happen and all the pollution and bad fire effects in New York turn their color from blue to red for no reason and what else would you do but give a little on the fly dissection. You know the more I think about it the more I feel like the games major enemies stem from when a sibling says: "well he started it!" after your younger brother is hospitolized because you touched his neck or something.OpinionYeah, this is some good game if you completely forget the first one ever existed, and the ability to walk 5 feet without blowing off some alien's head. It's actually really fun so yeah on a steam sale get this one it's pretty freakin awesome

												A real disappointment to play.  The first two installments never failed to make you feel like you were ahead of the curve during gameplay. I felt like I was trying to get the game to work properly - all the way to the epilogue.It really shows that this was developed for game-boys.  The port to PC just didn't feel right. It really destroyed any chance for immersion.I found myself spending way too much time with the visor - checking out other weapon mods.  It seemed like playing the game was secondary to "collecting award trinkets".  The cut-scenes lacked detail of the overall story, and were confusing. Weird.I feel badly for all of the people who worked hard on the artwork and other piece elements of the game.  The whole package - when put together - was just bad.I wish I hadn't played this game.  Like so many sequels, this one did nothing to enhance the original.  But, fortunately, the original is *still* replayable.  Whereas this game was a struggle to complete the first time through.  I won't be replaying this - and I won't even try the multi-player.  I'm going to uninstall immediately and forget about it.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												I've played this game several times super soldier difficulty, first on console then on PC.  This is one of my favourite shooters.  There are many aspects that I love about the game (there are smasll drawbacks aswell but nothing serious).What I like so much about the Crysis series is their sandbox and unrestricted worlds (for the most part).  Crysis 2 however is a little less so.  You are confined to a set path through the city with closed-in walls instead of running through jungles like in Crysis 1 and or Warhead. It makes up for some of this during each individual battle which occurs in a pretty open area, so you don't end up ffeeling completely penned in.The suit's powers are can now be accessed with keyboard shortcuts. 'Q' for armour and 'E' for stealth mode. There is no sprinting or power jumps. Those activate automatically when performing certain actions. The suit's abilities can be upgraded.  Upgradability is neat, but not very integral.  You become able to upgrade it by collecting nano particles from aliens you kill.Although there is no longer any multiplayer, the campain will keep you entertained. An average playthough I've found can last from 6 -9 hours if you know what you're doing.  The guns and combat are as crisp and satisfying as they were in the first two Crysis games. When getting near the end of the game it is easier to stealth (and fast) than to kill everyone on the map. Dying can set you back annoyingly far so don't die.Overall, it is a solid game worth investing your time into with a great storyline and combat, you can't go wrong.

												3/5 Uh. What can I say about Crysis 2? I definitely didn't enjoy my time with this game. I didn't HATE it, but I struggled to finish this game. The plot got to be a bit too much for me, but I guess with super soldiers fighting aliens, how can you do anything but go too far? The environment is beautiful but now the game is a lot more linear, and certainly no longer as open-world as the previous game. There is also a lot more handholding, and the game tries to give you options to do things but there's usually an "obvious way" to go that is clearly the Occam's razor (am I using that phrase correctly?) and most simple and effect method of completing the current mission. With the exception of becoming a bit of a hallway shooter, the gameplay is about the same. Also there is a "leveling system" in the game where you gain levels by absorbing the DNA out of killed aliens. I found this to be a terrible addition because now instead of trying to save the world, I was constantly focusing on trying to remember where certain dead bodies were so I could go back and level up once I finished killing all the aliens in a certain area. One noticeable change is that you are no longer a secretive super soldier skulking around a tropical island uncovering a hidden mystery, but now you're in the middle of a chaotic war zone trying to stop an entire alien invasion. But the plot isn't what concerned me--it was just the gameplay was so repetitive and felt endless and exhausting. I kept checking my play time and I even looked up online the average time it took others to beat the game. I hated "leveling up" because it distracted me and I hated the linear paths to the ends of the levels (at least after experiencing the more semi-open world environments of the first game). No more sneaking around the entire map to flank the enemy from behind--now you just walk down a New York street and try to sneak behind cars right in front of the bad guys. That being said, the game wasn't terrible--it was just a lot of negative changes from the first game. The ability to upgrade the suit was a nice addition but poorly executed. Also making the game into a hallway shooter was also a bad decision. If you enjoyed the first Crysis, then this isn't the game for you.

												Maximum metropolitan mayhemLet’s get the obvious out of the way first: CRYSIS 2 looks great. You would expect stunning visuals from Crytek and they deliver here in spades. Alien-devastated New York feels very realistic as you work your way through the dust and trash that blows in the air. Much has been said about the fact that you have to work our way through the streets rather than roam freely, as was possible in the first Crysis game, and it’s true that C2 is less open-world than the original. But it never feels as though you’re being herded and there is some room for exploration within the confines of the streets. But even though this aspect is a little disappointing C2 is an improvement on the original in most aspects. The suit controls have been made far more intuitive and it’s now possible to upgrade it as you gather points through despatching alien invaders. The story is less nebulous than in the first and the action is far more intense, with barely a moment to take a breath at times. The set-pieces are more epic in scope and there’s a real sense of urgency throughout. Sadly it’s not a long game. I took my time but still completed it in a little under 20 hours. But if you like the Crysis franchise this game is a worthy follow up to the original, even though it doesn’t quite have the same overall impact. Now onto Crysis 3 … 4/5

Posted: February 4, 2016
												So I think the general gaming community admits that the original Crysis was not exactly earth shattering in anything but visuals- though the story was a lot of fun, the combat/mechanics acceptably challenging/enjoyable, and of course the visuals jaw-dropping, the original Crysis was not a /spectacular/ game.  But, it had coherency- you could follow the story pretty well, the characters though simple were likable, and the AI wasn't totally bonkers.  Enter Crysis 2.  Crysis 2 certainly lives up to its predecessor in terms of visuals; if you want to see post-apocalyptic New York City at its finest, look no further. But the storyline is, at best, confusing and at worst rubbish. I played through the game and then had to look up the Wiki to understand what on Earth I had just accomplished/done. You have a silent protagonist that everyone addresses by name, sort of like Half Life 2's Gordon Freeman but without the self-awareness. It's like they couldn't afford the voice actor they wanted and the studio said "screw it, we'll make him silent."  I recall in the original Crysis getting to use all of the powers of the Nanosuit with fair regularity; speed was great for escaping, armor allowed me to tackle a slew of guys at once, and invisibility was great for getting the drop on folks. Something happened with 2, however, as Invisibility and armor are basically all that you use, generally flip-flopping between them in an attempt to bewilder the already chilish AI.  The AI, I think, is perhaps the most disappointing part. There were times where I misjudged my energy levels and decloaked not six feet from an enemy... who simply shrugs and walks away. Characters running up and down stairs endlessly is a frequent occurrence, and in general I found myself bewildered at what my enemies would do next. Summary:  Crysis 2 basically only has its visuals going for it. A sloppy, incoherent storyline, unlikable characters, poor mechanics, and laughable AI serve to make the sequel to Crysis simply a crisis.

Posted: November 16, 2013
												If you like FPS games, you'll like this, because it's every other FPS, all at once.* You're the only survivor of your team, which is killed off before you're actually briefed on your mission.* You're special, because you've got this super armor.* There are soldiers, working for an evil corporation. In a shocking twist, you use their weapons against them.* Also, aliens.* Also, there's a horrible disease and the city is quarantined, using extremely brutal yet totally ineffective methods.* US flags fscking everywhere* You have to rescue some guy, who keeps giving you orders, and who somehow knows in general everything that's going on within a few miles of his location, but can't explain anything in detail.* Also, guy who needs rescuing keeps getting angry at you because you're taking so long, despite your near-death with the rest of your team, your having to travel miles on foot through all sorts of absurd side-paths, and your having to single-handedly defeat several hundred soldiers.* Hey, ammo cache! I wonder if there's a big fight coming up?* Hey, laser-guided RPG! I wonder if I'm just about to fight a helicopter gunship?* Occasionally, the game pauses for a bit of tutorial, pointing out that you have tactical options -- which are extremely difficult to actually pull off, and don't offer any advantage over the standard tactic I've used in every computer game I've played in thirty years, which is to work around the edges and pick off enemies in detail, because sneaking through the middle always means you just fight everyone at once.Uniquely, and perhaps a first for any FPS, CRPG, and for the entire meta-genre of speculative narrative, the horrible disease does NOT turn people into zombie. At least not so far -- I'm only a few hours into this game.The graphics are quite good. The designers are of the school of thought where there's incredible detail and extent, but you don't feel you can actually explore much. It's almost the opposite approach of Bethesda-style games, in which there's far less fine detail, but lots of time and space to explore.The game has several glitches. For instance, I often find I'm unable to switch between semi-automatic and full-automatic on my weapons. At least once, I had a scripted event fail to trigger. Both these problems were solved by exiting, and going back to a save-point.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												Get ready to strap that Nanosuit on again, because it's time to go to the jungle of New York.Crysis 2 brings the beloved Nanosuit back into action, and improved in some ways. The suit's new look is fantastic, and the upgrades that are available gives the player more flexibility on how to use their suit. Whether it is for more stealth-like gameplay or more straight up shooting with a lot of armor, the suit gives the player a lot of fun customizable options that were not available in the first game.As for the story and setting, Crysis 2 takes place three years after the first game's horrific first contact with the alien race known as Ceph. Rumor has it that the Ceph built an underground hatch millions of years ago, and it is up to you how to save New York. The story is fun, although could be confusing since many of the pieces between the 1st and 2nd game are never explained. Rather, they are implied through dialogue. The setting is fun and interesting, and New York looks astonishing in Crytek's game engine.The gameplay is more linear, which is a big drawback since the first game prided itself on the open maps that gave players flexibility. In Crysis 2, you always move in a linear path and that's a shame really, since it doesn't allow the player to explore other interesting looking locations in New York. Yet, you still have some choices in certain areas, and the vast array of weapons at your disposal makes the gameplay quite fun. The AI is somewhat improved over the first game, but don't expect Einstein here, they will still make laughable mistakes. The game also becomes a bit challenging towards the end, which is a nice change from most FPS games these days. Last, some of the nanosuits functions such as sprint and strength from the first game are now automatic. Rather than improving those abilities from the first game, Crytek opted for a lazy removal of those abilities and made them automatic.The graphics are, just as the first game, fantastic. Yet I cannot help but notice that they did hold the engine back because it was marketed towards consoles. This sadly put the game behind its potential. Make no mistake, the game still looks great.The soundtrack is perhaps the best part of the game. Hanz Zimmer made the soundtrack and this automatically makes it awesome. But no, seriously, it's a fantastic and emotional soundtrack that makes you feel the desperation people feel in New York. Overall sounds are also great.There is a multiplayer mode in the game, but hardly anyone plays it today. In fact, almost no one played it when the game came out. The multiplayer is bad in most respects, and tried too much to mimic Call of Duty. They should have focused entirely on the single-player aspect of the game, not the multi-player aspect.Overall, if you want an FPS shooter with a crazy good soundtrack, fantastic graphics, and enjoyable story, then I see no reason for why you should not try Crysis 2.Score: 7/10

Posted: October 8, 2014
												I have mixed feelings about Crysis 2, the graphics are undeniable awesome and the story is just as good imo.However the changes made to the gameplay compared to the original Crysis have it's ups and downs. The speed and strength mode from the original Crysis has been removed and integrated as a passive ability, there is only armor and stealth mode as an active ability.This makes for a more seamless experience but at the same time simplifies the game. Not many will agree with me, but if we take away the suit powers it's an - somewhat above - average shooter.The suit upgrades make up for this with 4x3 unique mods unlocked by killing enemies, but you can only choose 1 power per slot. Maybe the developers thought enabling all of them would make the player overpowered, but it's a real shame not to have the option to choose all of them at once. The devs could always disable this in multiplayer, at least give us something unique in single player.Given these restrictions on the suit ugrade and the limited choices in power use, there isn't much in the way of upgrading the suit. I found myself rushing through the levels in stealth, because killing enemies was getting less rewarding as the game progressed on.I still recommend the game for the experience it can give you, but I feel like the combat suit upgrades could have been made better and the game doesn't live up to it's full potential.7/10

Posted: December 14, 2014
												I know this game was praised as a graphical masterpiece when it was released and it still holds up extremely well as a benchmark for your rig.  It's vibrant with tons of effects and well textured throughout even if certain assets are reused over and over again (some of it can be immersion breaking but I thought think you're here for the roleplaying aspect anyway).It's a solid FPS experience with hours of content unlike the modern day shooters you see with a few hours, the campaign definitely felt lengthy and the storyline present.  The plot isn't something to write to your mother about but it's passable for the genre and even had a few memorable characters (though lots of blank ones too).The gameplay itself offers lots of variance in tackling objectives while spoonfeeding you certain ones using the "Objective scanner" by pushing B.  While helpful at times so it's clear what you have to do, some of this definitely took a lot of the challenge away and feelings of accomplishment on completing any objective or entire mission.Some of Prophet's abilities are a bit too strong as well such as Stealthing (which seems to be a common complaint among players) that it takes too much of the challenge away from the game but with the Ceph enemies using EMP pulses and the like - I found just enough variance and challenge to enjoy the experience.  It 'will' get repetitive to an extent but it overall was a pleasant experience with a large enough variance in weapons and secondaries.The A.I. is one of the few complaitns I have with the game - sometimes the enemies were buggy and multiple times during the playthrough - I found them clipped or stuck on terrain (especially the Heavy Ceph).  While this meant they were exploitable in a game that already felt a bit too easy.  Other times the enemies (especially Ceph) would just randomly patrol/pace back and forth while you were shooting at them - as if they were trying to decide if they should fight back or run away.Overall I wouldn't say it's a must-play game release but it didn't have enough shortcomings for me to warn people away from the experience if they are a fan of futuristic-tech FPS campaigns.

Posted: April 14, 2015
												Overall crysis 2 makes up for most of the crysis 1 & warhead short comings. Controls are smoothed out making the annoying radial menu obsolete. We're no longer killing north koreans which feels a lot better. And gameplay can really allow you to play how you like. There are chavets though. Although I can't blame this game directly, Krytek simply dropped the ball on picking up where Crysis 1 left off. That massive cliffhanger at the end of Crysis 1 was never even addressed. Moreover, only one of the characters from Crysis 1 even returns at all and he isn't one you got to play as. Its like they decided to scrap almost all the story progression and start over. You never hear about the marines you played as in either crysis 1 or warhead, and the giant battle they are about to embark on at the end of that game (but is subsequently cut) is never even mentioned. You know that Prophet survives it, because he is in this game. But really thats all there is. At the very least we could have had an epic cutscene that wraps up that hanging storyline. But instead we start this game with nothing properly resolved. I found that to be extremely annoying as the best part of Crysis 1 was actually this (late to bloom) antogonist of an mysterious alien race. In this title almost all the rules are changed as to what these aleins are or what they do. The only thing left in common is the ice shard bullets they use. However, they are minimized and the whole frost/ice thing is replaced with a locus spore/disease cloud. This felt a lot like trying to pander to the zombie fanboys just to get them to buy the game. There are still the big questions hanging out there on why these aliens are now squids but maybe that will get resolved in the next installment. Given the history of the franchise, i'm not holding my breath. They are squids just because. Crysis 2 did a few things right as far as the story goes, this time around. There was a point where you see the final alien hive thing and you're in a helicopter flying towards it. This was the exact moment Crysis 1 abruptly ended, so I was expecting the credits to roll here... but to my surprise we actually got to land and have this last level. Even better you have the option to playing this last area as you see fit. I decided to do a stealth approach and only killed the 4 aleins you absolutely have to to trigger the final cutscene. If i went in guns blazing the whole area was crawling to the teeth with huge guns and huge aliens. The option to play it either way was pretty great. The ending was a bit odd but felt fairly well rounded. They wrapped up the NYC storyline and opened up the game to sequels with other "infected" areas around the globe. What was important is that at the end you felt like the whole game you were battling to save NYC and you accomplished that goal. That was a feel-good ending. I did find the changes to the aliens acceptable, but annoying. To expand... The aliens in the first game were very interesting, very dramatic and really quite unique. Although some aleins resembled things from matrix and other popular culture, these designs were tried and true. I found this fact charming, not bothersome in the first game. In this game it seems like there was an executive decision to make Crysis a sci-fi story that stood on its own feet. Although the end result was pretty good in the end, it didn't improve anything from the original. The whole "squid" theme really seemed forced. I felt like the fact that everything had tenticles from the aliens themselves to their guns and buildings...felt too much like the designers were like "SEE THIS IS UNIQUE! WE ARE UNIQUE" and I wasn't feeling it. To understand what this actually is... imagine if humans didn't drive cars but instead moved around in these crawling contraptions that looked like hands. Buildings weren't cubes, but instead all looked like human heads. This is what we get from these aleins here. Its too much. I feel like this game was over all leaps and bounds better than Crysis 1, even if it wasn't as awe-inspiring. Controls were great, upgrades felt meaningful and weapons ramped up in great ways. The story feels self contained and ends with the feeling that you've accomplished something, even if it is very obvious that it was trying really really hard to be a unique franchise. Over all: its a great game. Who knows about the next one, but its better than the first two.

												Crysis 2 is a game which puts you into a futuristic universe from the viewpoint of a soldier relying on technology to survive. As true with all Crysis games, the visuals are phenominal. 												I have mixed feelings about Crysis 2, the graphics are undeniable awesome and the story is just as good imo.However the changes made to the gameplay compared to the original Crysis have it's ups and downs. The speed and strength mode from the original Crysis has been removed and integrated as a passive ability, there is only armor and stealth mode as an active ability.This makes for a more seamless experience but at the same time simplifies the game. Not many will agree with me, but if we take away the suit powers it's an - somewhat above - average shooter.The suit upgrades make up for this with 4x3 unique mods unlocked by killing enemies, but you can only choose 1 power per slot. Maybe the developers thought enabling all of them would make the player overpowered, but it's a real shame not to have the option to choose all of them at once. The devs could always disable this in multiplayer, at least give us something unique in single player.Given these restrictions on the suit ugrade and the limited choices in power use, there isn't much in the way of upgrading the suit. I found myself rushing through the levels in stealth, because killing enemies was getting less rewarding as the game progressed on.I still recommend the game for the experience it can give you, but I feel like the combat suit upgrades could have been made better and the game doesn't live up to it's full potential.7/10

												The poor-man's Halo is back, though this time he might be considered middle-class.  This is a marked upgrade from Crysis 1.  It's still not quite as polished as it should be, considering the production value in other areas here.  The backstory is still mostly left unexplained.  If you were hoping for answers for the first game's questions, you will be disappointed.  It doesn't stop the game from delivering on present events, but the past is just as shrouded as ever.  Unfortunately Nomad is gone.  You're not told where he went or what happened to him.  In fact, only one character from the previous game is in this one, and it's the one who was mostly missing the whole time.  Go figure.  The suit's interface is much more polished this time around, with hotkeys available for the suit modes should you require them.  It's still an unfair advantage for anyone remotely good at stealth gameplay, but even with run-and-gun the game probably cannot be considered difficult on "Normal".  The game practically throws enemies and weapons at you, but you can actually skip most of the game since the suit is more efficient now, if you're so inclined.  The game threatens to break the very necessary bonds of its own ideas and concepts.  It feels as though at any moment you could break the game, if you so choose, so you almost feel bad and might alter the way you play because of it.  Pacing is erratic, but you are always given the tools to compensate.  Gone are the annoying godda** helicopters from the first game.  I experienced some weapon-mode switching and audio bugs towards the end of the game, but it isn't the mess that Crysis was.   Still pretty epic.

Crysis 2 however is a little less so.  You are confined to a set path through the city with closed-in walls instead of running through jungles like in Crysis 1 and or Warhead. It makes up for some of this during each individual battle which occurs in a pretty open area, so you don't end up ffeeling completely penned in.The suit's powers are can now be accessed with keyboard shortcuts. 'Q' for armour and 'E' for stealth mode. There is no sprinting or power jumps. Those activate automatically when performing certain actions. The suit's abilities can be upgraded.  Upgradability is neat, but not very integral.  You become able to upgrade it by collecting nano particles from aliens you kill.Although there is no longer any multiplayer, the campain will keep you entertained. An average playthough I've found can last from 6 -9 hours if you know what you're doing.  The guns and combat are as crisp and satisfying as they were in the first two Crysis games. When getting near the end of the game it is easier to stealth (and fast) than to kill everyone on the map. 												WILL IT RUN CRYSIS? That famous catchphrase known in PC gaming. As for Crysis 2, I'll do a two-shot review as I did played the game at release and now, two years later.1) So, at release, I would say I was totally disappointed with this game. Gameplay speaking, sure it's not as fun as C1 but I got past my disappointment and did enjoyed the game lately!Current rating: 8 / 10PROS:-Nanosuit makes you feel truly powerful (a walking TANK with the .50 cal)-Gorgeous visuals with DX11 (post-release)-Cat & mouse play with enemies-Suit UpgradesCONS:-At release, no DX11-Noticeable bugs-Poor story-No recap of the story so far... wiki recap's it better!-No mention of Nomad and Psycho from previous Crysis & Warhead-Streamlined controlsCurrently, I do recommend this game for anyone seeking a decent action game.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												Get ready to strap that Nanosuit on again, because it's time to go to the jungle of New York.Crysis 2 brings the beloved Nanosuit back into action, and improved in some ways. The suit's new look is fantastic, and the upgrades that are available gives the player more flexibility on how to use their suit. Whether it is for more stealth-like gameplay or more straight up shooting with a lot of armor, the suit gives the player a lot of fun customizable options that were not available in the first game.As for the story and setting, Crysis 2 takes place three years after the first game's horrific first contact with the alien race known as Ceph. Rumor has it that the Ceph built an underground hatch millions of years ago, and it is up to you how to save New York. The story is fun, although could be confusing since many of the pieces between the 1st and 2nd game are never explained. Rather, they are implied through dialogue. The setting is fun and interesting, and New York looks astonishing in Crytek's game engine.The gameplay is more linear, which is a big drawback since the first game prided itself on the open maps that gave players flexibility. In Crysis 2, you always move in a linear path and that's a shame really, since it doesn't allow the player to explore other interesting looking locations in New York. Yet, you still have some choices in certain areas, and the vast array of weapons at your disposal makes the gameplay quite fun. The AI is somewhat improved over the first game, but don't expect Einstein here, they will still make laughable mistakes. The game also becomes a bit challenging towards the end, which is a nice change from most FPS games these days. Last, some of the nanosuits functions such as sprint and strength from the first game are now automatic. Rather than improving those abilities from the first game, Crytek opted for a lazy removal of those abilities and made them automatic.The graphics are, just as the first game, fantastic. Yet I cannot help but notice that they did hold the engine back because it was marketed towards consoles. This sadly put the game behind its potential. Make no mistake, the game still looks great.The soundtrack is perhaps the best part of the game. Hanz Zimmer made the soundtrack and this automatically makes it awesome. But no, seriously, it's a fantastic and emotional soundtrack that makes you feel the desperation people feel in New York. Overall sounds are also great.There is a multiplayer mode in the game, but hardly anyone plays it today. In fact, almost no one played it when the game came out. The multiplayer is bad in most respects, and tried too much to mimic Call of Duty. They should have focused entirely on the single-player aspect of the game, not the multi-player aspect.Overall, if you want an FPS shooter with a crazy good soundtrack, fantastic graphics, and enjoyable story, then I see no reason for why you should not try Crysis 2.Score: 7/10

Posted: April 1, 2015
												"Crysis 2," where Master Chief travels to New Vegas and encounters The Flood.I swear, that's what this game felt like."Crysis 2" borrows a number of tropes from sci-fi and sci-fi gaming, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. It feels like Crytek was pretty appreciative and respectful about how they borrowed from other stories, and that's something I can appreciate.In terms of visual design, this offering is really quite impressive. The environments are huge and detailed, even though your traversal of those environments can be a bit limited at times. (Much like "Crysis" and "Crysis Warhead," where there was a sprawling island in front of you...and lots of mountains or cliffs which prevented you from going too far afield.) What's even more jaw-dropping is the impression that all of the hugeness probably had to be built (largely) by hand. A natural environment lends itself to certain kinds of procedural generation, whereas a ruined city is something that demands much more manual crafting.Where the game does not truly impress is in how it all knits together as a whole.The story is actually a pretty good "yarn," but the telling of it is a little clumsy and not quite paced in the right way. The acting tends to be wooden, and what really ought to come out "in game" tends to be rendered instead as exposition over "cheap" cutscenes. I call them cheap because most of them are just "tactical overview" videos or "nanosuit rebooting as it struggles with alien strangeness" sequences. In a certain way, the presentation ends up giving a person the impression that it serves mostly to cover up the bulk of loading the next level. It all ends up being a little disjointed, and there's no emotional core. Even when you do meet up with the actual characters in the game, they quickly go back to being little more than voices with Internet connections.The basic gameplay is pretty good, with you having to balance your suit's limited power with what you're trying to achieve. The stealth energy management returns to good effect, with you having to think about where you can get to before your cloak drops and you become easy to spot. The ability to customize the suit's upgrades to your preferred playstyle is a nice touch.However, the gameplay is only "pretty good." It's not stellar. The weapons generally lack punch, especially against the aliens. While this does encourage you to think tactically, it also tends to punish you disproportionately for when you inevitably do get into a full-on fight. Further, the overall lack of hitting power combines with the long spaces between checkpoints in an unfun way. Combat tends to be a relatively slow-paced, repetitive, hit-n-hide grind...which, if you screw up, affords you the opportunity to do that grind ALL OVER AGAIN. AGAIN.It's not like the "Halo" series, where combat was dynamic and entertaining - and even dying had an element of fun, because it tended to be so over the top. In comparison to that experience, "Crysis 2" feel like a chore. To be brutally honest, I was tired of the game by the end.I also have to ding the "stealth kill" mechanic. Coming from "Far Cry 4" and "Blood Dragon" to the "Crysis" series, I definitely felt that not having a takedown system subverted the stealth aspects of the game. When I saw that "Crysis 2" had added its own brand of takedowns, I was initially elated. That elation quickly faded, though, as I experienced how finicky and unforgiving the stealth kill system is. The radius for it to work is miniscule, with a very sharp "falloff." That is, it's easy to find yourself in the transition range where a tiny bit of movement is all it takes to change "stealth kill" to "melee." It's far too simple to end up doing something you didn't expect to do, and even if you do end up initiating a stealth kill, your cloak drops for the duration of the animation. It turns out that stealth kills aren't all that stealthy at all. You are very likely to be seen and "lit up" by the unfortunate enemy's buddies, which is a pretty dangerous situation.I DO recommend the game because, for its flaws, it's still an interesting way to spend about 10 hours or so. It's not a bad game at all - it just isn't a genre defining title, because it sometimes gets in its own way. I say, give it a shot when it's on sale, and enjoy the enjoyable bits.

Posted: April 14, 2015
												Overall crysis 2 makes up for most of the crysis 1 & warhead short comings. Controls are smoothed out making the annoying radial menu obsolete. We're no longer killing north koreans which feels a lot better. And gameplay can really allow you to play how you like. There are chavets though. Although I can't blame this game directly, Krytek simply dropped the ball on picking up where Crysis 1 left off. That massive cliffhanger at the end of Crysis 1 was never even addressed. Moreover, only one of the characters from Crysis 1 even returns at all and he isn't one you got to play as. Its like they decided to scrap almost all the story progression and start over. You never hear about the marines you played as in either crysis 1 or warhead, and the giant battle they are about to embark on at the end of that game (but is subsequently cut) is never even mentioned. You know that Prophet survives it, because he is in this game. But really thats all there is. At the very least we could have had an epic cutscene that wraps up that hanging storyline. But instead we start this game with nothing properly resolved. I found that to be extremely annoying as the best part of Crysis 1 was actually this (late to bloom) antogonist of an mysterious alien race. In this title almost all the rules are changed as to what these aleins are or what they do. The only thing left in common is the ice shard bullets they use. However, they are minimized and the whole frost/ice thing is replaced with a locus spore/disease cloud. This felt a lot like trying to pander to the zombie fanboys just to get them to buy the game. There are still the big questions hanging out there on why these aliens are now squids but maybe that will get resolved in the next installment. Given the history of the franchise, i'm not holding my breath. They are squids just because. Crysis 2 did a few things right as far as the story goes, this time around. There was a point where you see the final alien hive thing and you're in a helicopter flying towards it. This was the exact moment Crysis 1 abruptly ended, so I was expecting the credits to roll here... but to my surprise we actually got to land and have this last level. Even better you have the option to playing this last area as you see fit. I decided to do a stealth approach and only killed the 4 aleins you absolutely have to to trigger the final cutscene. If i went in guns blazing the whole area was crawling to the teeth with huge guns and huge aliens. The option to play it either way was pretty great. The ending was a bit odd but felt fairly well rounded. They wrapped up the NYC storyline and opened up the game to sequels with other "infected" areas around the globe. What was important is that at the end you felt like the whole game you were battling to save NYC and you accomplished that goal. That was a feel-good ending. I did find the changes to the aliens acceptable, but annoying. To expand... The aliens in the first game were very interesting, very dramatic and really quite unique. Although some aleins resembled things from matrix and other popular culture, these designs were tried and true. I found this fact charming, not bothersome in the first game. In this game it seems like there was an executive decision to make Crysis a sci-fi story that stood on its own feet. Although the end result was pretty good in the end, it didn't improve anything from the original. The whole "squid" theme really seemed forced. I felt like the fact that everything had tenticles from the aliens themselves to their guns and buildings...felt too much like the designers were like "SEE THIS IS UNIQUE! WE ARE UNIQUE" and I wasn't feeling it. To understand what this actually is... imagine if humans didn't drive cars but instead moved around in these crawling contraptions that looked like hands. Buildings weren't cubes, but instead all looked like human heads. This is what we get from these aleins here. Its too much. I feel like this game was over all leaps and bounds better than Crysis 1, even if it wasn't as awe-inspiring. Controls were great, upgrades felt meaningful and weapons ramped up in great ways. The story feels self contained and ends with the feeling that you've accomplished something, even if it is very obvious that it was trying really really hard to be a unique franchise. Over all: its a great game. Who knows about the next one, but its better than the first two.

												I have mixed feelings about Crysis 2, the graphics are undeniable awesome and the story is just as good imo.However the changes made to the gameplay compared to the original Crysis have it's ups and downs. The speed and strength mode from the original Crysis has been removed and integrated as a passive ability, there is only armor and stealth mode as an active ability.This makes for a more seamless experience but at the same time simplifies the game. Not many will agree with me, but if we take away the suit powers it's an - somewhat above - average shooter.The suit upgrades make up for this with 4x3 unique mods unlocked by killing enemies, but you can only choose 1 power per slot. Maybe the developers thought enabling all of them would make the player overpowered, but it's a real shame not to have the option to choose all of them at once. The devs could always disable this in multiplayer, at least give us something unique in single player.Given these restrictions on the suit ugrade and the limited choices in power use, there isn't much in the way of upgrading the suit. I found myself rushing through the levels in stealth, because killing enemies was getting less rewarding as the game progressed on.I still recommend the game for the experience it can give you, but I feel like the combat suit upgrades could have been made better and the game doesn't live up to it's full potential.7/10

Posted: May 20, 2015
												Get ready to strap that Nanosuit on again, because it's time to go to the jungle of New York.Crysis 2 brings the beloved Nanosuit back into action, and improved in some ways. The suit's new look is fantastic, and the upgrades that are available gives the player more flexibility on how to use their suit. Whether it is for more stealth-like gameplay or more straight up shooting with a lot of armor, the suit gives the player a lot of fun customizable options that were not available in the first game.As for the story and setting, Crysis 2 takes place three years after the first game's horrific first contact with the alien race known as Ceph. Rumor has it that the Ceph built an underground hatch millions of years ago, and it is up to you how to save New York. The story is fun, although could be confusing since many of the pieces between the 1st and 2nd game are never explained. Rather, they are implied through dialogue. The setting is fun and interesting, and New York looks astonishing in Crytek's game engine.The gameplay is more linear, which is a big drawback since the first game prided itself on the open maps that gave players flexibility. In Crysis 2, you always move in a linear path and that's a shame really, since it doesn't allow the player to explore other interesting looking locations in New York. Yet, you still have some choices in certain areas, and the vast array of weapons at your disposal makes the gameplay quite fun. The AI is somewhat improved over the first game, but don't expect Einstein here, they will still make laughable mistakes. The game also becomes a bit challenging towards the end, which is a nice change from most FPS games these days. Last, some of the nanosuits functions such as sprint and strength from the first game are now automatic. Rather than improving those abilities from the first game, Crytek opted for a lazy removal of those abilities and made them automatic.The graphics are, just as the first game, fantastic. Yet I cannot help but notice that they did hold the engine back because it was marketed towards consoles. This sadly put the game behind its potential. Make no mistake, the game still looks great.The soundtrack is perhaps the best part of the game. Hanz Zimmer made the soundtrack and this automatically makes it awesome. But no, seriously, it's a fantastic and emotional soundtrack that makes you feel the desperation people feel in New York. Overall sounds are also great.There is a multiplayer mode in the game, but hardly anyone plays it today. In fact, almost no one played it when the game came out. The multiplayer is bad in most respects, and tried too much to mimic Call of Duty. They should have focused entirely on the single-player aspect of the game, not the multi-player aspect.Overall, if you want an FPS shooter with a crazy good soundtrack, fantastic graphics, and enjoyable story, then I see no reason for why you should not try Crysis 2.Score: 7/10
