Anyway no more super-faar throwing of grenades in power mode like in previous games :(.On the other side you can easily do double jumps or run fast and stay cloaked or armored, just your suit energy drains much faster.Pros:- even more epic story and storytelling (much more cutscenes and context-clicking scenes than before) about saving humanity from alien race's raid again, but in New York- smart AI- even with linear story you still have small sandboxes (levels) to solve goals only on your own- beautiful graphics, but Crysis 1 and Warhead are still better with their trees and foliage, here is everything limited (visibility, levels surrounded by buildings etc.)- tuning possibility of your nanosuit- scout every area for ammo crates, enemies and points to hide- Maximum Edition includes DX11 patch together with HD textures pack (over 2GB of data)Cons:- more bugged than previsou games which had none - very often stuck/repeating sound of NPC's (both human and alien) or i  saw a lot of AI stucked behing doorway on corner trying to go through- definitely smaller levels with less possibilities- worse graphics than in previous games (mostly noticeable on grass/trees/foliage)- four suit vanilla modes simplified into two (less freedom during gameplay)ConclusionBeside my unavoidable comparison with previous games in series - game is still very nice and good and fun to play. Overall very good game (yet typical scenario 'go save our world'). I had wait some years to play it in desired quality, but waiting was worthy :). If you like sci-fi and stealth possibilities with sandbox play i'd definitely recommend it to you.

												I know this game was praised as a graphical masterpiece when it was released and it still holds up extremely well as a benchmark for your rig.  It's vibrant with tons of effects and well textured throughout even if certain assets are reused over and over again (some of it can be immersion breaking but I thought think you're here for the roleplaying aspect anyway).It's a solid FPS experience with hours of content unlike the modern day shooters you see with a few hours, the campaign definitely felt lengthy and the storyline present.  The plot isn't something to write to your mother about but it's passable for the genre and even had a few memorable characters (though lots of blank ones too).The gameplay itself offers lots of variance in tackling objectives while spoonfeeding you certain ones using the "Objective scanner" by pushing B.  While helpful at times so it's clear what you have to do, some of this definitely took a lot of the challenge away and feelings of accomplishment on completing any objective or entire mission.Some of Prophet's abilities are a bit too strong as well such as Stealthing (which seems to be a common complaint among players) that it takes too much of the challenge away from the game but with the Ceph enemies using EMP pulses and the like - I found just enough variance and challenge to enjoy the experience.  It 'will' get repetitive to an extent but it overall was a pleasant experience with a large enough variance in weapons and secondaries.The A.I. is one of the few complaitns I have with the game - sometimes the enemies were buggy and multiple times during the playthrough - I found them clipped or stuck on terrain (especially the Heavy Ceph).  While this meant they were exploitable in a game that already felt a bit too easy.  Other times the enemies (especially Ceph) would just randomly patrol/pace back and forth while you were shooting at them - as if they were trying to decide if they should fight back or run away.Overall I wouldn't say it's a must-play game release but it didn't have enough shortcomings for me to warn people away from the experience if they are a fan of futuristic-tech FPS campaigns.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												Didn't like it, despite loving the first game. I found the smaller, more linear stages to be confining in comparison to the sprawling environments of its predecessor. What's the point of being stranded in an urban jungle if you can't explore it and are forced to go from point A to B with no way of approaching a threat from a different direction. They tried to address this by providing you with different objectives that allow you to sneak past enemies by going underground or by finding perch areas where you can snipe the opposition from but it still ended up being overly guided and constraining.I also found the story to be jarring and non-sensical, espeically since the game begins without a clear transition between the events at the end of the first game and the begining of this one as it begins with New York already half-destroyed with seemingly new types of aliens that weren't in the original game with no explanation as to what transpired in-between. We also don't find out why Prophet suddenly went rogue and was clashing with elements of the military, and the person you end up controlling and playing as has no voice and goes along with whatever he's told to do unlike the oppinionated and more believable characters of Crysis 1.I also found the sparsity of checkpoints (why remove quicksaves in this type of game) to be frustrating as you could go up against waves of enemies for a period of 10-15min only to be killed by a new, tougher enemy and have to replay the whole thing over again. I think the devs did this to try and 'cover-up' their linear environments and repetitive scenarios by artifically lengthening the game in this manner but it didn't work, I'M ON TO YOU SUCKAS!On the plus side controlling the updated suit is a blast: the new suit mode changes make more sense and it's fun to customize your suit (and weapons) as you progress through the game as you can do so seamlessly on the fly. However another gripe I had with the game becomes apparent here as you need dropped nano elements from killed alien enemies to upgrade your suit but these disappear if you don't grab them quickly enough. It therefore feels like you're being punished for setting up sniping perches and methodically killing every alien within the immediate vicinity as by the time you're done killing the last alien the nano catalysts drops would have disappeared from the corpses of your first kills. This makes even less sense as the game nudges you towards higher-vantage flanking positions to protect your human allies as they fight aliens but doing so prevents you from nabbing all the catalysts.6.5/10

   Another Crysis must play   Crysis is one of the best single player FPS ever released, if not the best, and expectations for Crysis 2 are pretty high. Having played the first game intensively I was excited about the second game and I was not left disappointed.GraphicsVery realisticVery detailed texturesGreat lightingSoundEpic soundtrackWeapons sound very goodVery good voice actingBalanceDifficulties all extremely well balancedPlay as fast as you want to - if you want to finish a level fast, you canGame helps you with tactics if you  needAtmosphereReal placesAmazing cut scenes in player view instead of loading a videoMost areas have no humans in them whatsoever, they're simply empty and yet you are told at one point that the city is full with people, really?UINano-suit extremely easy to use and get  used toNot able to save whenever you wantContentPretty long single-player for a FPSYou can replay the game since there are different ways of solving missionsCollectablesLevel designDetailed levelsThe levels are very diverse, sometimes you're underground, in sewers, in buildings or streetsSome levels are longAITake coverCall for assistanceNot many different types of enemies, soldiers or aliens and there's only 2-3 types of aliensWeaponsExtremely interesting nano suit conceptWeapons can be modifiedAble to upgrade nanosuitSome of the upgrades don't make sense in the single playerStoryGreat startAllies keep changingSadly no real final but rather a cliff-hanger for the next gameConclusionCrysis was an amazing game and so is Crysis 2. Unfortunately it is not as good as the first game and yet it still is a game that really anyone needs to play. If you can lower your expectations from the first game you will see that this is an epic game with great game play but also story and even addicting soundtrack. I would recommend this game to literally anyone even if they don't actually enjoy FPS games. Crysis 2 is very different and excels at so many things that it is difficult to even compare it to the average FPS. The  nano suit is an experience in itself while the story will make anyone curious. Posted: January 13, 2015
												The Good:As to be expected from this franchise the graphics are fantastic. The game allows you to take on any scenario however you see fit, and the unique mechanics of the suit lend themselves quite nicely to this. You can sneak through an area undetected using your cloak to move from hiding spot to hiding spot, or you turn on your MAXIMUM ARMOR, rip a machine gun off its mount and shoot everything that moves. Both are equally satisfying, but my personal preference is cloak with a silenced shotgun and sniper rifle combination because of the fear and confusion it instills in the ranks of the enemy.The Bad:Quite a few bugs, nothing particularly game breaking but at one point I transitioned from a cutscene to a firefight only to realize I had no weapons and was promptly killed, I respawned and everything was normal again. The game is rather short, I beat the campaign on normal in just under 9 hours; better players will probably run through this in about 6. The ending sequence leaves much to be desired: You have a final showdown against 4 Elite Cephs, which up until this point the game had been foreshadowing rather well, however I found that they were easily disposed of by repeatedly melee attacking them effectively stun locking them until I beat them to death. This was then followed by a mundane QTE finale of you crawling along the ground until you throw yourself down a hole. Also, the entire game takes place in New York City, which became repetitive after a while.Overall: great graphics, solid gameplay, average story, bit buggy, weak ending; 7.8/10

												A lot of people put the original Crysis game as a massive tech demo... that being said:  I really enjoyed the original Crysis.  Jump High, Punch Hard, Run super fast! No jumping, running, punching skills, and no open world-ish areas.   Just cloaking and armor in pre-designed combat areas.All that being said:  It is not a bad game.  I had a good time cloaking around and using melee (Melee is OP - I used it on 70% of all mobs or more.)  The city scape looked fantastic even if the close up graphics felt fuzzy.  The story wasn't half bad but it really made a leap from sci-fy to magical/spiritual in some areas.Some of the guns were fun to shoot and explosions were awesome.  However Melee was OP and I abused cloak/melee most of the time.  The AI was smart when you tried to engage in gun battles but they got pretty dumb when I was ballistic cloak/melee.Overall - a pretty good FPS game and sci-fy story; however I couldn't shake the feeling that the first one was better.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												The ruins of Manhattan here are how destroyed London should have felt in Mass Effect 3. Sadly, there are no hot alien chicks to flirt with. Or Biotics. Or Garrus. Or manual saving. God damned checkpoints; on hard difficulty I found stealth to be the least frustrating way to play this game. Otherwise you (read: I) die too fast too often and keep refighting the same battles, until it gets too tiring and you just use invisibility to avoid combat altogether and finish it. Strangely, there didn't seem to be the same amount of variety as the first Crysis. Fights became repetitive. Seeing New York in rabbles is cool, but overall it was a mediocre experience for me. Hard difficulty funnels your play style towards the quiet approach, lack of proper tutorial made me understand most of the mechanics and small touches only around halfway into the game - how to use which weapon and the advantages of your binoculars – and I felt no desire to explore the levels. There are collectibles, yes, but they weren't nearly interesting enough to encourage you to hunt them down. Nothing as engrossing as BioShock's audio logs, for example.If you want a shooter with a bit of a creative touch in the form of the Nanosuit and its abilities (cloak, speed, armor), it might be enjoyable. Even then, though, you get the gist of it very early on and the game doesn't evolve enough to keep battles exciting. If you're looking for a rich experience with captivating characters and an intriguing storyline, skip this one altogether.And if you imagine you're playing Shepard in London rather than Alcatraz in Manhattan, it both remedies a bit of the sour taste left in the end of Mass Effect 3 as well as makes Crysis 2's environment more exciting.

												I've had it on PS3 since release so I have put in probably 200+ hours that you won't see on my Steam, and well it's actually one of my all time favorite series. I understand a little bit of the crap this one gets for "dumbing down" it's sandbox nature, but in all honesty this is my favorite Crysis campaign yet (and yes, I own both Crysis 1 and 3 obviously.) Sure, it's a little more confined than the first, I still love that it feels like there are a good number ways to take on each mission, I mean I've beaten it probably 15 times with each time going differently. I just find it stupid that people have to say the game is terrible or nothing like the first when it clearly is the same dang thing, but with easier to switch powers (technically NO powers were taken away, just some combined.) I think the story of this triligy is super interesting, definitely way more so than other standard fps's out there ex. Call of Battlegears Halo Assault 29. Of course, the visuals are absolutely crazy, and on Crysis 3 especially, looking better than really any next-gen game I've seen yet. It runs very smoothly (if your computer doesn't suck) but really it's very well optimized for PS3 as well, so either or.It's definitely a great game, regardless of the people who want to shove their stingy negative opinions down others' throats. I say buy it for sure, if you want to wait for a Steam sale, that would be best since they took out multiplayer (just on PC) which is like half the game. If you like Crysis 1, and are not a close minded♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bag, and enjoy some casual alien blasting with sweet powers and an interesting story, this is for you. 												I know this game was praised as a graphical masterpiece when it was released and it still holds up extremely well as a benchmark for your rig.  It's vibrant with tons of effects and well textured throughout even if certain assets are reused over and over again (some of it can be immersion breaking but I thought think you're here for the roleplaying aspect anyway).It's a solid FPS experience with hours of content unlike the modern day shooters you see with a few hours, the campaign definitely felt lengthy and the storyline present.  The plot isn't something to write to your mother about but it's passable for the genre and even had a few memorable characters (though lots of blank ones too).The gameplay itself offers lots of variance in tackling objectives while spoonfeeding you certain ones using the "Objective scanner" by pushing B.  While helpful at times so it's clear what you have to do, some of this definitely took a lot of the challenge away and feelings of accomplishment on completing any objective or entire mission.Some of Prophet's abilities are a bit too strong as well such as Stealthing (which seems to be a common complaint among players) that it takes too much of the challenge away from the game but with the Ceph enemies using EMP pulses and the like - I found just enough variance and challenge to enjoy the experience.  It 'will' get repetitive to an extent but it overall was a pleasant experience with a large enough variance in weapons and secondaries.The A.I. is one of the few complaitns I have with the game - sometimes the enemies were buggy and multiple times during the playthrough - I found them clipped or stuck on terrain (especially the Heavy Ceph).  While this meant they were exploitable in a game that already felt a bit too easy.  Other times the enemies (especially Ceph) would just randomly patrol/pace back and forth while you were shooting at them - as if they were trying to decide if they should fight back or run away.Overall I wouldn't say it's a must-play game release but it didn't have enough shortcomings for me to warn people away from the experience if they are a fan of futuristic-tech FPS campaigns.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Crysis 2 is a convoluted Jerry Bruckheimer action movie poured into a video game, starring a dead-man-walking protagonist, who was almost literally poured into a power suit as he lay dying. It allows him to withstand a great amount of damage or to turn invisible, but not simultaneously, and only for a short amount of time. The suit needs to recharge regularly. Its abilities give the player multiple options to tackle obstacles and give a nice balance of strengths and weaknesses. Flipping the suit from one setting to the other is easy and fast, so you can stealth your way around in invisible mode and then switch to armor when the shooting starts. Just always keep an eye on your energy meter and retreat for a moment when the energy bar shows red.The original Crysis – which I didn’t play – was a sandbox game. It saw you freely running around an island in the distinctive powersuit, fighting aliens and humans. Crysis 2 moves the action to an overrun New York, in which people are dying from an infectuous alien disease, or from being blown up or shot, or from a combination of all of these things. The sequel is more linear, split into nineteen chapter that lead you through arenas filled with enemies. There are big action set-pieces, there is a rousing, synthy soundtrack and you get to be the one man able to stop the alien invasion. Just don’t ask me how you end up doing it exactly. I started to tune out a little as the well-produced cutscenes and voice-overs explained what I was doing and just focused on my next mission objective. The plot is a bit too dumb and a bit too dense.The Crysis franchise has often served as a graphical benchmark and even three years after Crysis 2 came out – which is a decade in game years – it still looks very pretty. However, graphics have a limited shelf-life given the always advancing technology, and the series is most likely to be remembered for the power suit. It does indeed make for entertaining gameplay. The pick-your-own-approach concept is still very much in vogue in game design, but Crysis 2 was a skillful early adapter. The game rarely forces you into one specific course of action, encourages you to switch things up and rewards you for it.As you enter each arena, your visor can give you a tactical overview, pointing out ammunition stashes, and showing where to head to ouflank, to ambush, to sneak by and so on. When I grew bored of shooting near the end – your arsenal is unfortunately fairly generic – I ghosted past the final levels mostly unseen, though the last one could easily have been a tough and epic battle if I had wanted to go that route.There was one final, tricky fight I wasn’t allowed to skip, but then you won’t want to avoid being lethal altogether. Because for both the rare occasions when you do have to go mano-a-alien and get up close and dirty, and also to make the stealth easier, you will want to upgrade the suit. This requires you to run up to aliens you killed, to collect the glittery cloud that hangs over them, before it dissapates. A bit morbid and a bit random, but it does require you to be tactical again, weighing the risk of running out across the arena against the glittery gain. But seriously, it glitters – how can you resist?Your enemies aren’t always especially smart. I remember being cornered, with two exits that ended up at different sides of the same group of soldiers. Rather than rush me, they stood staring at the exit they had seen me at last, meaning I could walk back and forth between the exits, picking them off one by one as they focused on the wrong exit. Some of the aliens are fast and hit hard, however, so even if reactions can get predictable and a bit dumb, you still face a challenge. Checkpointing isn’t always especially generous and you may end up replaying a lengthy battle or two. But if you start to get annoyed, you may be able to just go invisible and sneak to a new area. Even if you leave behind an alarmed army of enemies who see exactly where you are headed, they will not follow you to the next area. It makes no logical sense, but is an easy exploit if you just want bail. I also encountered a few amazingly resilient friendlies, just regular guys, who took on and took out strong enemies solo, as I stood by idly and invisible in my powersuit.Crysis 2 did leave me feeling satisfied, but not really wanting more for the moment. It’s not a case of overkill, but definitely a case of enough kill. I won’t be picking up Crysis 3 anytime soon. Considering that the reviews for this most recent outing were less enthusiastic than those for 2, new players may want to start with this by now cheaper predecessor. It is a spectacular and versatile blockbuster ride. (More of my reviews at: www.popcultjunk.com / Twitter: @PopCultJunk )

Summary ReviewYou're an unstoppable machine that makes all your enemies blow themselves up because you're too much of a badass.Detailed ReviewObviously this game no longer works for multiplayer, so the only thing this game has worth is its single campaign.Synopsis----------------You play as silent protagonist, Alcatraz, a marine soldier who is sent to extract Nathan Gould, a former employee who has vital information in defeating the aliens that gave everyone the spook in the first installment. However, the situations immediately escalates for the worst and  the aliens kill all of your men. As for you, you barely survive the attack and a man by the name of "Prophet" saves you, and then everything fades to black.When you come to, you find yourself in the very suit that "Prophet" was in, but "Prophet" is now dead. He says in a recording that he was already infected by a virus, and says that you have to continue where he left off. And now the game begins with you off to save the world.----------------If this is your first time playing Crysis, I would suggest watching youtube vids of Crysis 1. It gives you a lot of insight to the story and (personally) makes the game a lot more enjoyable to play.I went through the game for 2-4 hours completely detached from the storyline only because I didn't know who was "Prophet", what the nanosuit was for and why I should even care that there were a bunch of Squidwards fighting against us. However, when I got to Gould, I finally took time to look at a recap, and the story became more enjoyable because of it.Granted, the story's not groundbreaking. It doesn't do anything too unique to stand out from most other storytelling games, but it was enjoyable enough for me to care for the characters to a small extent, which was more than enough for me to allow myself to want to play from beginning to end.As for the gameplay, it has its moments of being entertaining, especially at the beginning.You're given the option to do things that no normal soldier can do, which is being able to go invisible, have super armor, kicking cars on their side like it was some kid's bike and punching people in the face harder than a heavyweight boxer.However, this is also the game's weakness.Due to these features, the game feels too easy regardless of difficulty, and more than half the time, the enemies will make it easy for you, even when you're doing nothing at times.The AI is...special. They will shoot at you, and if you go into cloaking mode right in front of their eyes, they will immediately forget that you were even there.Their attention span is equal to that of a hamster. They will see you, and forget that you actually exist until you show up right in front of your face.Also,  I guarantee you that unless it's a mission where you're forced to fight, you can honestly just cheese through the game in cloaking mode without having to throw a single bullet, which really defeats the purpose of the game even being an FPS.But despite these flaws, this still doesn't deter from the game being fun at all. If you allow the game to, you can definitely get a nice kick out of the storyline. So is the game worth its full price at $30?No.Wait for a price drop if you really want to try out its single campaign.And when I say a price drop, I mean a price drop.This game is worth no more than $5 to $10 at best, and I wouldn't suggest spending any more than that, especially with the multiplayer gone.I spent $2 on this, and I say it was more than enough money well spent for my 12 hours of gameplay, especially with my purchase being the equivalence of a small time indie games.That said, this game gets a thumbs up from me.But be smart, and buy this game when the time is right.

Posted: October 2, 2014
												Crysis 2, you would think that its going to be "awesome" and that crytek would be taking awesome to the next level. Nope. Instead of a Non Linear shooter, you get a linear shooter. You get reduced suit capabilities, enemies at distance can still take multiple headshots before dying( completely absurd). I haven't finished the game, but I played throught the original Crysis, and Crysis Warhead a few times. While those games are hardly paving new territory in the FPS genre they still offer an unconfined type of game play.  Crysis 2 is the opposite, and in my opinion Crytek has had long enough to be able to offer a unique sequel to Crysis.As of now I'm not that far into the game, trying to find Dr. Gold (really bad plot advancer) and  for the most part since I'm playing on the hardest difficulty, I have to walk around in stealth mode ALL the time, which means I'm basically crouch walking through entire levels, because the enemies have ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ unrealistic attention. This is basically how I play: Stealth, crouch walk, spot enemy, unstealth, headshot(repeatedly in some cases), restealth, crouch repeat. Wow thats seriously fun gameplay, totally not annoying, and obviously non linear and pushing the genre to new heights. Since I'm not but a few hours into the game I'm hoping that the gameplay expands a little bit, because right now its starting to get repetive. What happened to the orignal formula? You know what I would of liked to have seen? You have an awesome biosuit, that amplifies your strength and other attributes, how about  a complete melee, hand to hand option. How about super fast sprint that turns into a round house, or a super fast sprint into a haymaker, instead of slowy walking up to enemies for a LAME stealth kill. The options in combat are very limited and they really shouldn't be, theres no excuse at this point.What about using environmental objects for improvised weapongs, instead of just throwing them or kicking them? Like a pipe you can beat enemies with, or maybe objects to throw like spears etc. The suit should of at this point been able to combo sprint and jumps and other abilities. I vaguely recall what I think was a video from Crysis Warhead where the character was doing all this cool♥♥♥♥♥♥like sprinting very fast(because of the suit) then pretty much using the momentum from the sprint to jump really far, then some punching or something. There wasn't any of that in Crysis, or Crysis Warhead, nor is there any of that in Crysis 2. LAME.Obviously I'll continue playing the game because I ♥♥♥♥ing bought it. Would I recommend it? Uh, I guess.Edit:The game does pick up, or maybe I picked up the game play a little better as I progressed throught it.  I found the game to be a lot more fun a little while after I wrote this review. I think that maybe the gameplay with just the human soldiers is a little mundane a repetive, but once you get into mixed gameplay with the Ceph and also human soldiers it mixes it up a bit. Maybe I'll give it another playthrought to see how I fare again, and if its as repetive as the first time through, since now that I have a good grasp of the flow of the game and the suit stuff, and also weapons.Overall I will stand by my original review in the fact that the game doesn't offer enought new gameplay elements to really take it above its predecessor, but its fun once you get past the first segement of the game where you are just battling human soldiers.

Posted: October 2, 2014
												Crysis 2 is a game about a more horrifying idea of an alien invasion. One in which the aliens take a much smarter path in their invasion strategy and release a human-melting virus into the air of new york city, leading to martial law under the mysterious PMC forces of "Cell".It's an FPS, of course, but it does new things with the formula. The main hero, Alcatraz, is a man kept alive by a complicated nanosuit that gives him superhuman abilities. He can cloak, he has super strength, he can become mostly bulletproof and most of all he has one hell of a throwing arm. You can upgrade your abilities and weapons throughout the game to tailor your skills to your playstyle.The soundtrack is nothing short of amazing. Orchestral music done by none other than the famous Hans Zimmer, with songs that make just about any moment epic. There are many of these moments. While the game doesn't go full on over the top, there are many moments that are insane, whether it's escaping from a falling skyscraper or fighting a giant alien robot, the game is full of action and seems to be constantly trying to top itself.If you were put off by the first Crysis, I urge you to give Crysis 2 a shot. It's clear they managed to find their stride.

Posted: January 16, 2013
												WILL IT RUN CRYSIS? That famous catchphrase known in PC gaming. As for Crysis 2, I'll do a two-shot review as I did played the game at release and now, two years later.1) So, at release, I would say I was totally disappointed with this game. Very consolized, lack of PC functions and worst, no DirectX 11 support. So technically speaking, the game was lackluster and underwhelming. Aside from the specs, the gameplay was also underwhelming as what made Crysis known was the more freedom of approach to the missions. In C2, it is very linear. Close to no exploration. Little to none "driving/piloting".What was even more irritating was the dismissal of NOMAD, Crysis 1 protagonist. Apparently, he got killed "offscreen" in a Comic, right after the events of Crysis Warhead.Release rating: 6.5 / 102) Now, having played the game two years later AND with the full potential of DirectX 11, thanks for the patch Crytek, I'd say the game is impressive. Granted I've got a better PC to enjoy the full high-end graphical options, I was amazed by the details as everything looked good! Gameplay speaking, sure it's not as fun as C1 but I got past my disappointment and did enjoyed the game lately!Current rating: 8 / 10PROS:-Nanosuit makes you feel truly powerful (a walking TANK with the .50 cal)-Gorgeous visuals with DX11 (post-release)-Cat & mouse play with enemies-Suit UpgradesCONS:-At release, no DX11-Noticeable bugs-Poor story-No recap of the story so far... wiki recap's it better!-No mention of Nomad and Psycho from previous Crysis & Warhead-Streamlined controlsCurrently, I do recommend this game for anyone seeking a decent action game.

												Watching the trailer, I have to say I'm a little disappointed. I love the Crysis franchise, but I can't say I'm excited for this one. The whole futuristic thing with robots and stuff just doesn't seem right in Crysis. I think Crytek needs to find that line between innovation and sticking to the Crysis formula that made this sieres so... awesome. I can see how some of this future technology would play well into kill streaks, perks, etc. in multiplayer, but I hope they don't go overboard. I'm gonna be watching for more trailers, but from what I see so far, I don't think I'll be picking up this game; At least, not for $30. On the other side, I can't wait to find out more about ZOMBIES in BO2. I do think zombies would be pretty epic with all these new futuristic guns and robots and stuff like that. Overall, I think that if Crytek can find that line between innovation and sticking to the formula, then they can use that platform to create some awesome weaponry and have some room to get creative. If they go overboard on the futuristic thing though, it could turn into a scrambled mess that is plain disappointing to long time Crysis fans. I guess we'll have to wait and find out

Posted: October 5, 2015
												The poor-man's Halo is back, though this time he might be considered middle-class.  This is a marked upgrade from Crysis 1.  It's still not quite as polished as it should be, considering the production value in other areas here.  The backstory is still mostly left unexplained.  If you were hoping for answers for the first game's questions, you will be disappointed.  It doesn't stop the game from delivering on present events, but the past is just as shrouded as ever.  Unfortunately Nomad is gone.  You're not told where he went or what happened to him.  In fact, only one character from the previous game is in this one, and it's the one who was mostly missing the whole time.  Go figure.  The suit's interface is much more polished this time around, with hotkeys available for the suit modes should you require them.  It's still an unfair advantage for anyone remotely good at stealth gameplay, but even with run-and-gun the game probably cannot be considered difficult on "Normal".  The game practically throws enemies and weapons at you, but you can actually skip most of the game since the suit is more efficient now, if you're so inclined.  The game threatens to break the very necessary bonds of its own ideas and concepts.  It feels as though at any moment you could break the game, if you so choose, so you almost feel bad and might alter the way you play because of it.  Pacing is erratic, but you are always given the tools to compensate.  Gone are the annoying godda** helicopters from the first game.  I experienced some weapon-mode switching and audio bugs towards the end of the game, but it isn't the mess that Crysis was.   Still pretty epic.

   Another Crysis must play   Crysis is one of the best single player FPS ever released, if not the best, and expectations for Crysis 2 are pretty high. Having played the first game intensively I was excited about the second game and I was not left disappointed.GraphicsVery realisticVery detailed texturesGreat lightingSoundEpic soundtrackWeapons sound very goodVery good voice actingBalanceDifficulties all extremely well balancedPlay as fast as you want to - if you want to finish a level fast, you canGame helps you with tactics if you  needAtmosphereReal placesAmazing cut scenes in player view instead of loading a videoMost areas have no humans in them whatsoever, they're simply empty and yet you are told at one point that the city is full with people, really?UINano-suit extremely easy to use and get  used toNot able to save whenever you wantContentPretty long single-player for a FPSYou can replay the game since there are different ways of solving missionsCollectablesLevel designDetailed levelsThe levels are very diverse, sometimes you're underground, in sewers, in buildings or streetsSome levels are longAITake coverCall for assistanceNot many different types of enemies, soldiers or aliens and there's only 2-3 types of aliensWeaponsExtremely interesting nano suit conceptWeapons can be modifiedAble to upgrade nanosuitSome of the upgrades don't make sense in the single playerStoryGreat startAllies keep changingSadly no real final but rather a cliff-hanger for the next gameConclusionCrysis was an amazing game and so is Crysis 2. Unfortunately it is not as good as the first game and yet it still is a game that really anyone needs to play. If you can lower your expectations from the first game you will see that this is an epic game with great game play but also story and even addicting soundtrack. I would recommend this game to literally anyone even if they don't actually enjoy FPS games. Crysis 2 is very different and excels at so many things that it is difficult to even compare it to the average FPS. The  nano suit is an experience in itself while the story will make anyone curious. It does not matter whether you have experience with FPS or not as the easiest difficulty literally allows you to sprint through levels while barely shooting anyone. I have finished this game within around 7 hours but admit ignoring a lot of enemies or using stealth to avoid lengthy fights. Summary ReviewYou're an unstoppable machine that makes all your enemies blow themselves up because you're too much of a badass.Detailed ReviewObviously this game no longer works for multiplayer, so the only thing this game has worth is its single campaign.Synopsis----------------You play as silent protagonist, Alcatraz, a marine soldier who is sent to extract Nathan Gould, a former employee who has vital information in defeating the aliens that gave everyone the spook in the first installment. However, the situations immediately escalates for the worst and  the aliens kill all of your men. As for you, you barely survive the attack and a man by the name of "Prophet" saves you, and then everything fades to black.When you come to, you find yourself in the very suit that "Prophet" was in, but "Prophet" is now dead. He says in a recording that he was already infected by a virus, and says that you have to continue where he left off. And now the game begins with you off to save the world.----------------If this is your first time playing Crysis, I would suggest watching youtube vids of Crysis 1. It gives you a lot of insight to the story and (personally) makes the game a lot more enjoyable to play.I went through the game for 2-4 hours completely detached from the storyline only because I didn't know who was "Prophet", what the nanosuit was for and why I should even care that there were a bunch of Squidwards fighting against us. However, when I got to Gould, I finally took time to look at a recap, and the story became more enjoyable because of it.Granted, the story's not groundbreaking. It doesn't do anything too unique to stand out from most other storytelling games, but it was enjoyable enough for me to care for the characters to a small extent, which was more than enough for me to allow myself to want to play from beginning to end.As for the gameplay, it has its moments of being entertaining, especially at the beginning.You're given the option to do things that no normal soldier can do, which is being able to go invisible, have super armor, kicking cars on their side like it was some kid's bike and punching people in the face harder than a heavyweight boxer.However, this is also the game's weakness.Due to these features, the game feels too easy regardless of difficulty, and more than half the time, the enemies will make it easy for you, even when you're doing nothing at times.The AI is...special. They will shoot at you, and if you go into cloaking mode right in front of their eyes, they will immediately forget that you were even there.Their attention span is equal to that of a hamster. They will see you, and forget that you actually exist until you show up right in front of your face.Also,  I guarantee you that unless it's a mission where you're forced to fight, you can honestly just cheese through the game in cloaking mode without having to throw a single bullet, which really defeats the purpose of the game even being an FPS.But despite these flaws, this still doesn't deter from the game being fun at all. If you allow the game to, you can definitely get a nice kick out of the storyline. So is the game worth its full price at $30?No.Wait for a price drop if you really want to try out its single campaign.And when I say a price drop, I mean a price drop.This game is worth no more than $5 to $10 at best, and I wouldn't suggest spending any more than that, especially with the multiplayer gone.I spent $2 on this, and I say it was more than enough money well spent for my 12 hours of gameplay, especially with my purchase being the equivalence of a small time indie games.That said, this game gets a thumbs up from me.But be smart, and buy this game when the time is right.

Posted: March 18, 2016
												By far one of the prettiest games out there. If you have a computer that can support max graphics, Crysis 2 is a solid title. The gameplay is best summed up as a "superhero simulator". You can cloak, resist bullets and cut through enemy lines with ease. It's an empowering feeling being behind the controls of the nanosuit and leaves an enjoyable experience with the player. The graphics are fantastic for a game it's age but the facial animations are sometimes wonky.However it is not without flaws. The biggest problem is AI, which often ruin your stealth and commit blunders in combat, making them a cakewalk on normal difficulty. (I played on medium/normal) However, if you're the kind of player who likes to go in guns blazing (I do) then this game plays like an action movie. I did find the pacing of the story somewhat strange. You often find yourself in what seems like a "final battle" kind of scenario only to find out that the game still has about an hour or so to go. The fact that sprinting drains your energy makes stealth difficult and means that you have to manage the energy meter to not get caught out in the line of fire. It's a frustrating feature that thankfully got patched in Crysis 3.Unfortunately the multiplayer servers are no longer supported (I think) so it's just single player but that's okay with me.Overall, it's an amazing game that is fun to play and a treat for the eyes. For the low price and the occasional sale, it's worth the money.

Posted: September 25, 2016
												Originally posted April 18 2011 gameaday-ish,blogspot.comAt the point Central Park is held aloft in huge earthly chunks settled atop writhing masses of metal tentacles, Crysis 2 turns to the player and shrugs in exhaustion: “That’s all I got, kid”.A multiplatform follow-up to the PC-killing original, Crysis 2 makes significant trades in gameplay and environments in order to excel visually on consoles. However, even when using a walled garden approach where most maps are open expanses designed for multiple avenues of attack, Crysis 2 is a metric crap-ton more fun to play than any COD clone, including COD:BLOPS.Unlike the original Crysis, where the player was dropped onto an island with a full suite of nano-suit abilities that allowed for increases in strength, speed, armor or cloaking and given leave to play in a giant sandbox, the sequel parcels out abilities over the first half of the game. Speed and strength are no longer selectable and are enabled by default. Using the energy remains of deceased enemy Ceph allows the player to upgrade the suit abilities throughout.Like the first game, the story is an incomprehensible mess only set in Manhattan rather than a North Korean island. Flora and fauna are replaced by concrete and vehicles, creating impenetrable mazes of steel and glass, rather than flowing expanses of green. Playing as Alcatraz, a voiceless, personality free cipher of a marine, the player wakes from black (the first of a half-dozen overused transitions), embedded in the suit. Immediately mistaken for the suit’s original owner and apparently incapable of independent thought, Alcatraz begins a series of guided journeys, each lead by a different voice transmission.The alien Ceph of the first game are succeeding in destroying New York City and only the nanosuit has the ability to stop them. Led through a series of switchbacks and double-crosses, Alcatraz blindly follows orders, leaving one to wonder if he had played too much Bioshock when not at work as a marine.Epic and troubling imagery leverage the lingering memories of 9-11, as the city collapses during the journey beneath above and beyond, leaving the player slack-jawed. Unlike the seemingly endless vistas of the first game, Crysis 2 is also beautiful but limited. Particle effects and motion blur are used liberally to mask the limits placed on the engine and while the framerate does waver, it does so rarely.Using the suit powers allows and even requires the player to use some strategy when engaging groups of enemies, especially early on as the enemies become more varied and more difficult, but never smarter. Unfortunately, common glitches manifest where a death-and-reload will cause scripted enemies to become frozen in place, robbing the game of challenge. Diligent hoarders of Ceph energy will also soon find themselves able to nearly max out the suit upgrades, leading to late game moments where a cloaked sprint can avoid engaging the enemy altogether.Crysis 2 lacks the open world of its predecessor or Far Cry 2, causing it to fall into a nebulous middle where it is influenced heavily by Call of Duty but not yet as horribly linear, leaving it a refreshing change from claustrophobic corridor shooting.Shame about the story.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												The ruins of Manhattan here are how destroyed London should have felt in Mass Effect 3. Sadly, there are no hot alien chicks to flirt with. Or Biotics. Or Garrus. Or manual saving. God damned checkpoints; on hard difficulty I found stealth to be the least frustrating way to play this game. Otherwise you (read: I) die too fast too often and keep refighting the same battles, until it gets too tiring and you just use invisibility to avoid combat altogether and finish it. Strangely, there didn't seem to be the same amount of variety as the first Crysis. Fights became repetitive. Seeing New York in rabbles is cool, but overall it was a mediocre experience for me. Hard difficulty funnels your play style towards the quiet approach, lack of proper tutorial made me understand most of the mechanics and small touches only around halfway into the game - how to use which weapon and the advantages of your binoculars – and I felt no desire to explore the levels. There are collectibles, yes, but they weren't nearly interesting enough to encourage you to hunt them down. Nothing as engrossing as BioShock's audio logs, for example.If you want a shooter with a bit of a creative touch in the form of the Nanosuit and its abilities (cloak, speed, armor), it might be enjoyable. Even then, though, you get the gist of it very early on and the game doesn't evolve enough to keep battles exciting. If you're looking for a rich experience with captivating characters and an intriguing storyline, skip this one altogether.And if you imagine you're playing Shepard in London rather than Alcatraz in Manhattan, it both remedies a bit of the sour taste left in the end of Mass Effect 3 as well as makes Crysis 2's environment more exciting.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												"Crysis 2," where Master Chief travels to New Vegas and encounters The Flood.I swear, that's what this game felt like."Crysis 2" borrows a number of tropes from sci-fi and sci-fi gaming, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. It feels like Crytek was pretty appreciative and respectful about how they borrowed from other stories, and that's something I can appreciate.In terms of visual design, this offering is really quite impressive. The environments are huge and detailed, even though your traversal of those environments can be a bit limited at times. (Much like "Crysis" and "Crysis Warhead," where there was a sprawling island in front of you...and lots of mountains or cliffs which prevented you from going too far afield.) What's even more jaw-dropping is the impression that all of the hugeness probably had to be built (largely) by hand. A natural environment lends itself to certain kinds of procedural generation, whereas a ruined city is something that demands much more manual crafting.Where the game does not truly impress is in how it all knits together as a whole.The story is actually a pretty good "yarn," but the telling of it is a little clumsy and not quite paced in the right way. The acting tends to be wooden, and what really ought to come out "in game" tends to be rendered instead as exposition over "cheap" cutscenes. I call them cheap because most of them are just "tactical overview" videos or "nanosuit rebooting as it struggles with alien strangeness" sequences. In a certain way, the presentation ends up giving a person the impression that it serves mostly to cover up the bulk of loading the next level. It all ends up being a little disjointed, and there's no emotional core. Even when you do meet up with the actual characters in the game, they quickly go back to being little more than voices with Internet connections.The basic gameplay is pretty good, with you having to balance your suit's limited power with what you're trying to achieve. The stealth energy management returns to good effect, with you having to think about where you can get to before your cloak drops and you become easy to spot. The ability to customize the suit's upgrades to your preferred playstyle is a nice touch.However, the gameplay is only "pretty good." It's not stellar. The weapons generally lack punch, especially against the aliens. While this does encourage you to think tactically, it also tends to punish you disproportionately for when you inevitably do get into a full-on fight. Further, the overall lack of hitting power combines with the long spaces between checkpoints in an unfun way. Combat tends to be a relatively slow-paced, repetitive, hit-n-hide grind...which, if you screw up, affords you the opportunity to do that grind ALL OVER AGAIN. AGAIN.It's not like the "Halo" series, where combat was dynamic and entertaining - and even dying had an element of fun, because it tended to be so over the top. In comparison to that experience, "Crysis 2" feel like a chore. To be brutally honest, I was tired of the game by the end.I also have to ding the "stealth kill" mechanic. Coming from "Far Cry 4" and "Blood Dragon" to the "Crysis" series, I definitely felt that not having a takedown system subverted the stealth aspects of the game. When I saw that "Crysis 2" had added its own brand of takedowns, I was initially elated. That elation quickly faded, though, as I experienced how finicky and unforgiving the stealth kill system is. The radius for it to work is miniscule, with a very sharp "falloff." That is, it's easy to find yourself in the transition range where a tiny bit of movement is all it takes to change "stealth kill" to "melee." It's far too simple to end up doing something you didn't expect to do, and even if you do end up initiating a stealth kill, your cloak drops for the duration of the animation. It turns out that stealth kills aren't all that stealthy at all. You are very likely to be seen and "lit up" by the unfortunate enemy's buddies, which is a pretty dangerous situation.I DO recommend the game because, for its flaws, it's still an interesting way to spend about 10 hours or so. It's not a bad game at all - it just isn't a genre defining title, because it sometimes gets in its own way. I say, give it a shot when it's on sale, and enjoy the enjoyable bits.

Posted: November 16, 2013
												If you like FPS games, you'll like this, because it's every other FPS, all at once.* You're the only survivor of your team, which is killed off before you're actually briefed on your mission.* You're special, because you've got this super armor.* There are soldiers, working for an evil corporation. In a shocking twist, you use their weapons against them.* Also, aliens.* Also, there's a horrible disease and the city is quarantined, using extremely brutal yet totally ineffective methods.* US flags fscking everywhere* You have to rescue some guy, who keeps giving you orders, and who somehow knows in general everything that's going on within a few miles of his location, but can't explain anything in detail.* Also, guy who needs rescuing keeps getting angry at you because you're taking so long, despite your near-death with the rest of your team, your having to travel miles on foot through all sorts of absurd side-paths, and your having to single-handedly defeat several hundred soldiers.* Hey, ammo cache! I wonder if there's a big fight coming up?* Hey, laser-guided RPG! I wonder if I'm just about to fight a helicopter gunship?* Occasionally, the game pauses for a bit of tutorial, pointing out that you have tactical options -- which are extremely difficult to actually pull off, and don't offer any advantage over the standard tactic I've used in every computer game I've played in thirty years, which is to work around the edges and pick off enemies in detail, because sneaking through the middle always means you just fight everyone at once.Uniquely, and perhaps a first for any FPS, CRPG, and for the entire meta-genre of speculative narrative, the horrible disease does NOT turn people into zombie. At least not so far -- I'm only a few hours into this game.The graphics are quite good. The designers are of the school of thought where there's incredible detail and extent, but you don't feel you can actually explore much. It's almost the opposite approach of Bethesda-style games, in which there's far less fine detail, but lots of time and space to explore.The game has several glitches. For instance, I often find I'm unable to switch between semi-automatic and full-automatic on my weapons. At least once, I had a scripted event fail to trigger. Both these problems were solved by exiting, and going back to a save-point.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												I rate the game Crysis 2 4/5. Good but not truly great.This first-person perspective action game has the absolute best sound effects I have ever heard in a game. The numerous gunshot and explosion sound effects in the various environments are all the best I've ever heard without being so overly strong that I feared for even a second that my speakers would be hurt by the tumult of sound. The really excellent sound effects are of an even higher quality than the advanced visuals this game offers.+Amazingly excellent sound effects which mix well (and easily) with the dialogue and music.+Outstanding, often bright, sunny graphics (but good rainy weather effects occur once too). The game runs even better than the original Crysis game did also.+The music is at least adequate and pretty epic in places with a good main theme.+Good (though fairly linear) level design.+Great, chaotic, visceral (but highly scripted) action sequences throughout.+Good weapons with nifty attachments you can pick up throughout the game.+Good power armor upgrades you can get over the course of the game.+Excellent menu options including the ability to turn of any annoying crosshairs.+Mission objectives are usually very clear.+No bugs (other than the crappy enemy AI if you use stealth tactics).+Nifty and realistic seeming urban environments for battles to occur in.-If you play the game in a methodical manner (particularly if you use sniping and stealth tactics) the enemy AI is STUPID. It doesn't matter if you are fighting human characters or alien characters, they all act STUPID, usually dismissing hints of your presence too easily and wandering around in the open while you pick them off from a distance. Up close the AI is adequate but even then the enemy tactics are seldom surprising.-Despite all the effort the game displays at trying to make you feel otherwise the levels are all fairly linear (and by and large they are much smaller and closed in than the areas in the first crysis game and its add-on Warhead). This game also has only one ending (its an adequate ending though)-The characters feel a bit generic and the dialogue is often boring.-The plot is all-too-often a convoluted mess full of contrived and stupid reasons for why you are somehow always the only person in the game with a nifty power-armor nanosuit which should have been distributed to a lot more people by now.-The aliens and their vehicles are less creative (and generally less dangerous seeming this time around. The highly effective cryogenic weaponry they exhibited in the first game and its add-on are completely absent this time to be replaced by a sort less terrifying rip-off of Nano-Black from Unreal Tournament 3.-Limited replayability due to the highly scripted action sequences in this game and once you find out how much it pays to be stealthy (and how poorly the enemy AI copes with such tactics) the game's apparent difficulty (and length) drops dramatically.-The enemies are more generic than they clearly could have been and they act, react, coordinate and generally seem to think too much like normal human soldiers. Several effective and intimidating units (particularly the giant alien squid armor suits and the giant walkers with the snakey limbs) are conspicuously missing from this game.-The final boss fight is a bit of a let-down (just a bunch of even more elite soldier aliens)

												Crysis 2 is a thoroughly entertaining romp-especially when played on a gaming oriented PC hooked up to a large screen with some dope audio. The story is so-so and the writing hilariously poor at times, it is the technology though that really shines, Cry Engine 2 when paired with the Direct X11 based overhaul that came about in 2012 is quite thrilling. It is comparable to blasting through a hollywood blockbuster, the audio/visual effects and overall atmosphere are so rich that you'll forgive the identikit enemies and senseless story in serach of the next epic and hugely satisfying shootout.A very different animal to the first game and not half as clever by design, one of gamings guilty pleasures. Combat scenarios usually offer several options with many alternative tactics possible, stealth kills, heavy weapons, sniping etc almost 80% of the time though the game demands a no holds barred guns blazing approach.It's a power trip fantasy not far removed from Duke Nukem Forever in my eyes. Limited replayability even with the gorgeous graphics but absolutely worth at least one play through. The wrecked beauty asthetic of New York is still a landmark achievement in gaming fidelity. The AI is generally quite smart on the higher settings and very quick to react, combat feels weighted and fluid with all of the weapons and modifications providing excellent feedback, nano suit mods is nice and well implemented addition.A very handome game indeed and several thousand times better then the abysmal third title. Buy it, play it, enjoy it.

Posted: April 7, 2016
												Would I recommend Crysis 2? In a word: Yes. There's no reason not to. Sure, it's never going to be my favourite game, but objectively it is a well crafted, well rounded FPS that builds on the things that made Crysis 1 great, including the graphics. It may be more pick-up-&-play than I would like in a plot-centred game, but it definitely passes muster as a worthwhile game to play through.I think my issue is that Crysis 2 is too slick for it's own good, getting the player into the game so swiftly that the basic building blocks for the plot are never really laid down for me. I know your character is armed with very little information at the start but several characters talk about things that they obviously expect me to understand but the game hasn't actually explained any of it to me, so I really struggled to get into the story.Add to it the characters that don't get enough time with you for you to care, despite the fact that several of them I was itching to know more about. My last minor gripe is that during level changes, you jump locations, & on a couple of occasions, the events surrounding that transition sound really interesting or would have been a great opportunity to really develop a character, in particular Commander Lockhart, who could've made an excellent antagonist on top of the general threat from the aliens. However, all of this pales against my biggest criticism & probably the source of my lack of satisfaction with Crysis 2: how do we get from the events of Crysis 1, & the blue floaty aliens, to the events of Crysis 2 with red tentacle armour aliens? At no point is this resolved & left me rather disappointed.Sadly, because of all this, I'm left just plodding through the game until it finished. Unfortunately, I wasn't pulled into the game enough to really care whether humanity won or not, hence why I was glad it was over.That's not to say the game is bad. I really liked the nanosuit being a character in itself, the difficulty balance feels really good, maybe a touch towards easy, the visuals are great & mercifully, the awful final boss fight set piece of the first game is not repeated.The game also ramps up nicely, with the plot stepping up a gear at several points & I did enjoy large chunks of the actual shooter bit. There is a wide choice of weapons & mods to tailor your combat & there are nano-mods; alterations to your suit that are unlocked by nano-catalysts which can be activated to suit the situation. The only annoyance is these are collected from dead aliens like ammo. Why? No idea, & I didn't like that as a game mechanic. I didn't make massive use of the nano-mods, but the few I did use were subtle but useful, the main one for me was a bullet tracker, making enemies much easier to target.I also really like the sense of doom surrounding the “Suit Drivers”, the bloke actually inside the nano-suit. You play a US Marine called Alcatraz, who is supposed to infiltrate New York, which is under attack but he & his team are ambushed & he is left badly injured. Later the game reveals the extent of said injuries. You are rescued by Prophet, returning from Crysis 1, who places Alcatraz in the suit to complete his 'mission' as he is infected with a virus that is killing the inhabitants of New York & is dying. We later learn that Prohpet's mission is basically a suicide mission that needs the suits capabilities & an expendable someone to man it. Basically, as long as the nano-suit can do it's thing, you living or dying is not even remotely important.Like the first game, you are left to make your own tactical choices, stealth is usually an option, but so is blasting your way through, with the risk of reinforcements arriving. I chose to use a silenced sniper rifle to clear as much as possible, then sneak through. Sometimes it worked, other times I ended up blasting away. The game does over plenty of advice, giving hints about stealth routes, ammo caches, sniper points etc & allows you to track enemies by marking them through the Visor (Binoculars) function. Being able to track enemies is really handy but the tactical hints just smacked of trying to hand-hold the player & while I ignored that function, it irritated me ever time the game told me to check the visor for tactical advice.In a nut shell, I personally do not like Crysis 2. I don't know why, it's a pretty good game, but unlike Crysis 1, I was glad when I reached the end of Crysis 2. I can't really explain what is wrong with it though. All the essential ingredients from the first game are present, the suit functions work as seamlessly as ever, customisable weapons, & a good plot so maybe I was just expecting too much. Still recommended though, especially for more casual gamers.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												Just like its predecessor, Crysis provides both a unique and engaging premise for its campaign and top-notch graphics that once again raises the graphical benchmark for gaming. Well, kind of. It may not appear as instantly striking in terms of awesomness the original did with its lush, tropical setting but it's in the finer details and when things really escalate in the single player that will blow your mind. The sheer 'destructional' splendour of New York under alien siege has to be seen and played to behold. Seeing screenshots and a few gameplay trailers does not do it justice unless you're sitting there, at your desktop, plugged into your HDTV or whatever, with full surround-sound and maybe even 3D, escaping a sinking sub yourself. This being said, graphics don't make a game. And with such refined gameplay, it sure as hell doesn't make Crysis 2.For the core gameplay of Crysis 2, I was initially disappointed about the nanosuit's powers being reduced to stealth and armour. That quickly changed, however. Having a button for each made switching between the two far more fluid than Crysis 1. On top of this, it adds a lovely twist and breath of fresh air to what is essentially your typical combat multiplayer affair. That being said, it is a step down from the large scale frantic antics of the original. But it's this added layer of depth to the tried and tested 'CoD-style' multiplayer offering that lends it an advantage.But it was the single-player, like its predecessor, I bought it for. The original garnered some criticism to its rather basic plot, but having never seen it done so well, or in a videogame for that matter, it didn't hinder the experience one bit. Crysis 2, however, propels the Crysis universe onto a whole new level. It's obvious a hell of a lot more thought has been put into it. It's more complex, deeper and smart and makes for infinitely more compelling game. Couple this with the unique and shockingly-real depiction of an apocalyptic New York and well... I can't even begin to explain how awesome it is... 10/10

Posted: June 8, 2012
												Crysis is one of those franchises that I wonder what ever happened to it. Sure, the first installment was well known because of its lush detail and that ultra settings for computers at the time would send them into a meltdown and even today is used for benchmarking computer builds. Crysis 2 happened and somwhere the developers were told to either optimize their game or somehow tone down the detail because this game does not have the same reputation as its predecessor. There is also a Crysis 3, which was sold on Origin because reasons, and from then on the developers decided to go the free2play route for other games.I'll put it bluntly. Crysis 2 is more or less Call of Duty set in the future. New York City gets overrun first by some evil biotech firm that has armed mercs and then an alien invasion happens. Gameplay is what you expect; just shoot the bad guy. I get it that shooting the bad guy is the point of FPSes but most good FPSes stand out because they have something going for them; be it the storyline, an open world environment (which Crysis 1 apparently had), or something. Sure, it is easy to make a game with great graphics; there aren't any big name games out there that do have terrible graphics, but ultimately it doesn't do much for the game. Here, the gameplay is linear and repetitive. Any time you see an ammo or grenade cache means that you are going to face some sort of enemy. Rarely are there instances where enemies keep spawning indefinitely, and thus you can pick off enemies and then go about your merry way. Also, I have not noticed much of a difficulty spike between "recruit" and "soldier" settings. If anything, enemies on "soldier" difficulty have a bump in HP, but other than that there is no difference in AI. I get that most people prefer to play on hard because of the challenge, but there really isn't one. Hard just means your bullets go through faster. In addition, I did not see any third difficulty setting. Maybe I missed it at the beginning; who knows. One plus side that the game has are the graphics. For a 2011 title this is still a great looking game. However, there was no real immersion in the game. Compare that to Deus Ex: HR, also a 2011 title, which had much better immersion and the graphics were just as stunning. I get that immersion differes from person to person, but graphicswise this game just did not have that punch that I would've expected from a big name title, let alone a Crysis game. Major spoiler alert incoming, but it needs to be discussed. There's no getting around it; the ending of the game SUCKS. It's probably the dumbest thing I have seen in any video game (though granted I did not play Mass Effect 3). At the end of the game you have to go to Central Park, because apparently that's where the aliens are based. Great! This means you have to fight some sort of final boss, right? Well no; the enemies are just basic aliens you've come across, including the more paladin-like big aliens that take forever to kill. So, just pick off those aliens, destroy the control modules (which you had to do torwards the middle of the game; why the devs decided to repeat what you have done is beyond me), and then go to the spire. Then you face 4 cloaking aliens. This part I found ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t because A: they have ♥♥♥♥♥onnes of HP, B: they cloak, and C: they hit pretty damn hard. Now what I am guessing the game wants you to do is use the KVolt guns provided at the end to stun and then kill the aliens, using your thermal vision to target them. However, since they hit hard, using that and your armor buff means you're going to be wasting energy. Ultimately, the best thing to do is find the aliens, stun them, and then melee them to death. There really isn't any other way that I can think of. It's just dumb, really. Now once that is all done you can go into the spire. Great! Does that mean there's a boss? No; just a series of quick time events (which the game loves) and then a cutscene with Prophet, who supposedly killed himself in the beginning of the game. Do you fight Prophet? No...the next scene shows the aliens eradicated from New York and then a happy ending with you waking up in Central Park and getting a call from someone spurring the events of Crysis 3. That's it. No final boss, no decisions, nothing. It's linear gameplay at its worst, and the ending was anticlimactic as anything I have ever seen.I know this game can be bought on Origin, but don't bother, really. This isn't a bad game by any stretch of the imagination. There were a few features I did like about it, such as managing your nanosuit as well as your weapon attachments, but other than that, there was nothing. Save your money, honestly.

												Crysis 2 is a stunning visual experience, way above the first edition which was already a milestone in video game visuals. But this is about the only point where Crysis 2 does better than its predecessors, Crysis and Crysis Warhead.The gameplay has become a boring ultra linear corridor, cut scene, corridor, cut scene, QTE, cut scene. You could expect from a highly visuals driven game like this to have exciting cut scenes at least, but unfortunately the incredibly bad story telling makes them look contrived at best, missing completely the epicness they try so hard to convey.The game also comes with a couple of frustrating game design decisions, like a hud you can barely read, vehicles you can never drive for more than 100m (compare that to the epic vehicle scenes in Crysis Warhead), or a climax ending on a ridiculous QTE.All in all, Crysis 2 is a decent game, with decent action and superb visuals, but compared to previous episodes, it just doesn't deliver.

												The Basics: Very pretty disaster porny first person shooter with a cyborg suitPrevious Time Spent: 27 minutesExpectation of learning Curve: lowWhy I bought this: Extremely cheap steam sale (long enough ago that I don't remember it)First Impressions: This is a good looking game, but my first impressions were marred by expecting it to be fairly boring/boilerplate. I found myself frustrated by the long, live-action CNN/Fox News intro, and the standard tutorial which slowly unlocks controls. I did find the submarine escape in the beginning kind of thrilling, but I ultimately found it to be more annoying due to loss of control than anything else. For a game that seems to be really about a cool cyborg killing small squads of soldiers, it spends a lot of time pretending that the audience is interested in it's story.  My 3 hours: I spent the entire 3 hour playthrough in the singleplayer campaign, figuring that a game this old would probably end up not well-supported on the multiplayer front. The game takes place in 2023 in NYC, with the main character as a marine who takes on the mantle of a crazy cyborg (nanosuit) suit of power armor. This power armor confers a bunch of special abilities to the player, including cloaking, resistance to damage, and seemingly extreme strength. In a lot of ways, it plays like a more violent, sprawling version of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Much of the gameplay is focused on advancing from checkpoint to checkpoint while dealing with environmental hazards and squads of soldiers. These challenges escalated in a pretty satisfying way during my 3 hours with the game, and did a fairly good job of introducing the player to new tactics/ideas in order to surpass them. The bread and butter of it is often finding cool places to hide/shoot soldiers from, while taking cover when appropriate, and sometimes turning invisible to feel like the Predator. The main character feels extremely powerful in the suit, bringing me back to old-school shooter games and the feeling of being a one man army. The story that's told in the game is one of an alien virus and a harsh crackdown, and much of it feels pretty standard issue, but some of the environmental storytelling great. The scene that immediately follows the opening, allows the player to slowly acclimate themselves to a New York city that appears to be under martial law, between audio records on laptops, and the horrible remains of living people. It then allows the player to slowly make their way from Battery Park and head north. The game is at it's best when it's providing interesting combat challenges, or allowing one to feel like a tourist in a believable near future New York.   My Highlight: For me, the greatest joy I had with the game came fairly early, and is pictured above, a mix of combat and infiltration set in Castle Clinton, bringing me back to one of the early missions of my beloved Deus Ex. As you can see above, the historical marker is even legible, and the attention to detail shown in the environment conveys a clear sense of place. The game introduces the stealth mechanic there, which is pretty fun, and allowed me to feel like The Predator.  My Verdict:I generally kinda liked this game, but much of the joy I got out of it, I think I got because it reminded me of things I liked better. It made me think of Deus Ex and Half Life 2 the most, between the sprawling levels, the near-superpowers given by nanites, and the environmental storytelling. I can't strongly recommend it, but I think it's a game that is good at what it intends to do .

Posted: April 15, 2016
												3/5 Uh. What can I say about Crysis 2? I definitely didn't enjoy my time with this game. I didn't HATE it, but I struggled to finish this game. The plot got to be a bit too much for me, but I guess with super soldiers fighting aliens, how can you do anything but go too far? The environment is beautiful but now the game is a lot more linear, and certainly no longer as open-world as the previous game. There is also a lot more handholding, and the game tries to give you options to do things but there's usually an "obvious way" to go that is clearly the Occam's razor (am I using that phrase correctly?) and most simple and effect method of completing the current mission. With the exception of becoming a bit of a hallway shooter, the gameplay is about the same. Also there is a "leveling system" in the game where you gain levels by absorbing the DNA out of killed aliens. I found this to be a terrible addition because now instead of trying to save the world, I was constantly focusing on trying to remember where certain dead bodies were so I could go back and level up once I finished killing all the aliens in a certain area. One noticeable change is that you are no longer a secretive super soldier skulking around a tropical island uncovering a hidden mystery, but now you're in the middle of a chaotic war zone trying to stop an entire alien invasion. But the plot isn't what concerned me--it was just the gameplay was so repetitive and felt endless and exhausting. I kept checking my play time and I even looked up online the average time it took others to beat the game. I hated "leveling up" because it distracted me and I hated the linear paths to the ends of the levels (at least after experiencing the more semi-open world environments of the first game). No more sneaking around the entire map to flank the enemy from behind--now you just walk down a New York street and try to sneak behind cars right in front of the bad guys. That being said, the game wasn't terrible--it was just a lot of negative changes from the first game. The ability to upgrade the suit was a nice addition but poorly executed. Also making the game into a hallway shooter was also a bad decision. If you enjoyed the first Crysis, then this isn't the game for you.
